documents.commentText: I have been using kratom intermittently for close to a year now. It has helped enormously with my generalized anxiety and depression and has helped me to avoid my previous attraction to more addictive, dangerous, and illegal substances. I use kratom as a dietary supplement alongside other more well known supplements such as chamomile, passion flower, and melatonin. By using kratom on conjunction with these other supplements I have found a more comfortable method to prevent my tattered home life from tearing me apart mentally without feeling dependent on any specific substance. I used to have to attend therapy once a week and was at one point dependent on benzodiazepines because of my generalized anxiety. After finding a therapist interested in treating the cause of my issues as opposed to treatment of the symptoms I was able to address my dependence on illegal or pharmaceutical substances and work out a harm reduction plan that would also help alleviate some of the symptoms while I work on the cause of the symptoms. Using this system I have successfully overcome issues that seemed otherwise impossible and have become comfortable enough to address my issues without constant therapy. I hope you can understand how kratom has helped me and I hope you don't intend to prevent it from helping others that could be in a much worse situation than myself.

documents.commentText:
Hello DEA representatives ,
     With knowledge of a close friend who has suffered from opiate/pain medication withdrawals in the past due to Chrohn"s disease, and other stories I've heard through podcasts it,  seems very harsh to ban a plant that has been beneficial to woman, men, veterans, and others alike. People who have suffered from pain, suffered from addiction , suffered from ptsd, suffered from other ailments ,have found their cure.  it seems as though kratom has been the safe answer to relieving symptoms and helping people get back on track to a happy and successful life. I'm not saying this plant should be out for everyone to grab, matter of fact I think there needs to be more research period , but to be considered a schedule 1 drug is absolutely ridiculous . I am not hippocrate , I have personally tried this substance now a handful of times , from personal experience smaller doses such as .3-.5 mg to .8 mg I have felt muscle soreness relief, headache relief, and uplift in mood. The only side effect I have noticed is nausea and vomiting due to lack of knowledge on dosage , it wasn't the end of the world and matter of fact once I threw up I was back to myself , unlike experience with alcohol that has left me hours or even days hungover . This plant may not be for me,  but knowing that it can save lives and prevent addicts from going down dark depressing paths is enough evidence for this drug to be investigated and utilized for its benefits . I understand that with new, hardly investigated substances , it's easy for one to label this as a drug and prevent people from getting their hands on it ,  and rightfully so if you are concerned about health and prevention of injury , but it is well known that this plant is not causing problems otherwise people wouldn't be on forums like this pleading to keep it legal. If anything, the long term effects are something unknown, and for that reason it is time for research to begin . I respect your time , and ask honestly to please reconsider this ban . I know it must be a tough position on your end , but please don't let greed override you , don't let money be a factor on you . Enough is enough, plants are not dangerous, it's people that are dangerous, anything and everything can be abused , it takes education and leading by example to help others around us . There are certainly drugs out there that deserve to be labeled as schedule 1, but there are plants / natural substances , amidst that list that are life changing , and beneficial To people , to us! Enough of the boundaries , one nation one love . Thank you

documents.commentText:
I am a 59-year-old Medical Technologist working in a large multi-specialty lab and have used Kratom for pain associated with a severe spinal injury, both pre- and post-op. I felt highly compelled to find a safe, non-addictive alternative to the potent pain medications (Oxycontin and Fentanyl) that were being prescribed. After much research, I found a promising natural herb called Kratom. I was able to obtain it from a reputable vendor and found it to be highly effective at relieving my pain. While awaiting surgery and through the lengthy post-surgical recovery I was able to successfully manage my pain using Kratom, with none of the adverse reactions associated with opioid medications. It did not interfere with my ability to think clearly and I had no need to increase the dosage over time due to the tolerance or dependence that often develops with opioids. When I recovered and no longer needed pain management I was able to discontinue using the Kratom with no withdrawal symptoms and no lingering effects. 
I, along with many others, have found Kratom to be a safe, effective, non-addictive alternative for pain management with none of the unpleasant or dangerous side effects associated with opioid medications and no loss of mental clarity. Claims that Kratom has no meaningful medical benefits have been made without taking the time to analyze existing research, conduct further research or study anecdotal evidence of the positive effects Kratom has to offer. Given the current opioid crisis, it is worth doing the work to investigate the possible benefits Kratom has to offer, particularly as a safe alternative to these dangerous and highly addictive opiate medications. However, placing the active components of Kratom, mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine, into a Schedule I would effectively halt further scientific investigation due to the stringent federal licensing required and the inability to obtain enough Kratom to study once it is banned. Therefore, banning Kratom for having no accepted medical use makes it unlikely a medical use will be found due to the inability to research it further once the ban is in place. Please do not let this happen. Let my voice and the voice of many other Americans who have benefited from Kratom be heard.
 
Thank You for your time and consideration,
Kimberlee Bonnell
Newberg, Oregon

Hello, my name is Tim Stansell and I am 36, a husband, a father of 4, and a Worship Pastor at Desert City Church in Phoenix, Arizona.  I have suffered from chronic back pain since I was 16.  Kratom allows me to live a normal life without the worry of pain pill addiction or possible overdose.

I do not believe that the DEA should place Kratom on the Schedule 1 list of controlled substances and thereby restricting the citizens of the US from being able to benefit from this amazing plant.  

I have taken Kratom 4-6 times every day for the last 4+ years and have never felt sick or had any negative side effects.

I also wanted to comment on Kratom and how it has helped me in my life.  I found out about Kratom by searching online for natural pain relievers.  I had racked up several thousands of dollars worth of debt at a Pain center, and a chiropractor, neither of which helped me much at all.  It was unsustainable for me to continue receiving treatment at those places when it wasn't really helping me.  I took Tramadol and Diclofenac for 3 years, up to 9 pills a day (6 tramadol and 3 diclofenac per day) to manage my pain.  I began to worry that I was damaging my body by taking so many prescription pills.  WIth long term use of Diclofenac, there are dramatic increases in fatal heart attacks. 

Once I started taking Kratom, I slowly stopped taking the prescriptions.  They weren't helping me nearly as much as Kratom was and it was costing me too much money to continue getting pills.  After a year of taking Kratom, I was able to stop taking any pills at all!

I have tried almost all of the available treatments that I could basically afford, from physical therapy to massage/chiropractics, even had a medical marijuana card for 2 years.  Marijuana didn't help nearly as much as Kratom so I didn't renew my card.  Nothing has helped my body like Kratom has.  

There are many people that I know in the same situation, who have had back surgeries or other chronic pain.  I introduced them to Kratom and they stopped all of the other remedies.  

Kratom really has improved my life dramatically.  My pain affects my ability to work, to be present with my family, and whether I can get out of bed or not.  Because of Kratom, I know that I can live a normal, productive life and serve our city and our church worry free and almost pain free.

I urge you at the DEA to consider the negative implications of making this plant illegal.  PLEASE do not ban Kratom.  It helps too many people with little/no risk of hurting anyone.  I'm proof of that.

Thank you for your consideration,
Timothy K. Stansell

documents.commentText:
To Whom It May Concern,

I'm a fifty-year old home-owning, married, hard-working, law-abiding, tax-paying, American citizen, whom has been ingesting the 100% natural herbal-plant known as 'Kratom', for over a year now. Unlike alcohol, I have found Kratom to be a 100% safe, non-harmful, non-sedating, light-stimulant herbal tea. I am a chronic sufferer of clinical depression, and similar to coffee, Kratom helps to keep me healthy, and in a positive state of mind, so I can continue to be a productive member of society. 
Scheduling or banning such a mundane, and helpful plant, such as Kratom, would not only be a travisity of justice, I fear it would set an extreamly dangerous prescient for the future of our constutional rights as Americans, when there are so many other extreamly harmful, dangerous, and deadly substances that are 100% legal, such as... alcohol, cigarettes, energy-drinks, artificial sweeteners, processed sugar, food-preservatives, vitimens, etc.

For the record; I am responsible for the development of military simulation software, and electronic entertainment, which has helped the recruitment, and positive reinforcement, of US military personal, for well over two-decades. It was recently brought to my attention that many of these combat veterans, whom suffer from (post-combat) PTSD, Anxiety, Depression, Alcoholism, and Opioid Addiction, have been greatly helped by Kratom. Again, I was extreamly disapointed when I hear that the very government, in-which these great American have dedicatedly served, want to hurt these service members, by making them criminals, when all they want to do is maintain being honorable, productive, law abiding members of society (not unlike myself).

I sincerely hope that the DEA and FDA can produce a logical, legal, unbiased, and rational clinical study of the plant known as Kratom, before moving to schedule and ban such a harmless and helpful plant from our great nation. 

Sincerely,

Chris Borders
US Citizen, Humane Reporter, Casting Director, Interactive Developer, and CEO.

documents.commentText: Let's be real here for a minute. Kratom has benefited hundreds of thousands, if not millions of Americans and citizens across the world for decades. It is not synthetic. It is not a drug. It is a leaf from a tree, indigenous to Southeast Asia. It is known to aid in the relief of dozens of ailments from pain, anxiety and depression to digestive issues, PTSD, and withdrawals from opiates. Consumers range from the young,  to the middle aged, to the eldery. They are moms, dads, military veterans, teachers, law enforcement, doctors, lawyers, disabled, and those looking to rid their lives of dangerous narcotics. Prohibition doesn't work. The war on drugs was fought and lost. The vast majority of kratom consumers are responsible adults, capable of making educated decisions about what they do or don't put in their own body. You know the deaths you reported were not due to kratom alone. You know there are doctors, scientists, and researchers emploring you to reconsider your stance. You know this is not an imminent threat to the public. You know there are perfectly legal substances from Tylenol to laundry pods that have done more damage every year, than what you reported on Kratom in the last five years. If you want an age restriction, fine. If you want special wording on packaging and no brightly colored packaging, fine. If want vendors to be registered, fine. If you want quality control, fine. Do NOT take this away from the millions of people whose lives have changed for the better. Do NOT require a prescription. You CAN'T make it a prescription. You can try, but you will not succeed in recreating all of the benefits from a plant with more than 2 dozen alkaloids, but using only a few. Also, while reading through all of these comments, I surely hope you don't base your final decision on the language some of the average laymen may use. It is widely known, based on fights in other industries that you should not use medical claims or use words like treat or cure. Doctors should know this. Scientists should know this. Vendors should know this. Don't expect Jane and John Doe to know it. Obviously, Kratom doesn't cure anything and saying so is irresponsible. The word "treat" is debatable. People treat a bad mood to a night out with friends or a ride in a car with the radio blaring.  People treat anxiousness at the end of the day, to a cup of chamomile tea. So how about just listen to their story and how this plant benefits them instead. Please focus on real, serious issues like the current heroin epidemic and leave this safe,  natural herb and it's many consumers alone. We will fight you every step of the way, for as long as it takes until we are given our god given right to choose what is in our own best interests of our health and happiness.

documents.commentText: Beginning at the age of 20, my life became suddenly plagued with depression and anxiety. This included being completely exhausted 24 hours a day, avoiding people, inability to keep a job or maintain friendships. This happened very suddenly for me. I had always had many friends, very outgoing, I actually very easily  made new friends everywhere I went. Then for no reason at all, everything became very difficult. Being happy became difficult. Over the next 7 years I would try several different antidepressants, ADHD medications, and anxiety medications. All of which failed to work, made me feel worse, or worked but then stopped working. These medications include Paxil, Prozac, Wellbutrin, buspar, pristiq, Zoloft, straterra, adderall, and klonopin. I had dropped out of school and was successfully going nowhere in life. One day a friend told me about something that he thought would help; Kratom. After first trying it, my fatigue lifted, my anxiety vanished, and I felt genuinely happy for the first time in years. This has led to daily use for the last 8 years. During this time I have earned 2 degrees and served as a graduate teaching assistant in my graduate program. I have also maintained an amazing relationship over the last 7 years. Kratom  is extremely safe. There is a limit as to how much one can take to receive benefits.  Too much will just make you nauseous and lazy. I have had one bad experience over the 8 years I have been taking Kratom, and it was because I bought from a new vendor that sent me something else other than Kratom just to make some money off of me. Like any medication, it can interact with other things and those interactions need to be studied and made public. Any serious health issues related to Kratom come from kids or irresponsible adults stuffing their bodies full of things they know nothing about. Before you make your decision please understand that if you take Kratom away,  you are dooming me to roll the dice on pharmaceuticals that have failed me too many times before. I don't have time to put my life on hold while I find something that works. Please make your decision based on evidence by the scientific community and by those of us that have used it responsibly to better ourselves and the lives of those around us.

If you take Kratom away from we the people, you will see hoards of Heroin Addicts going right back to Heroin, you will see retired soldiers and civilians both turning back to prescription drugs and if those aren't available you will see the illegal drug market soar, it will not be good and you will be to blame 100%.

documents.commentText:
My name is Aaron Horner, I am a 35 year old husband, father and an Operations Manager for a Fortune 500 company. I suffer from Fibromyalgia. 

My story started in 2003 I was racing bicycles and had huge sponsors including a major energy drink manufacturer. I used to drink one a day and that was it. I was young, in shape and no health problems. 

The energy drinks ended up eroding my stomach lining and I ended up getting a bloody ulcer that erupted and I lost 3 pints of blood. I blacked out and the last thing I remember is my mother tell me to hold on. 

Fast forward six months. First symptoms started to appear. Pain that I cannot even explain, problem after problem, symptom after symptom. 25 emergency room visits, 57 doctor visits. Nobody could figure out what was wrong with me. 3 years I suffered with pain. It hurt me mentally, physically and emotionally. I suffered, my family suffered, my career suffered. 

Finally one doctors visit they decided to test me for something called fibromyalgia. It was positive. 

The only FDA approved medication for Fibro was an anti-depressant (undoubtably that is the answer to everything). The one thing you DON'T do is put someone who is not depressed on an anti-depressant. 

I cannot even begin to explain what that medication did to me mentally. The pain went away but so did my sanity. I have never once in my life ever even thought about suicide. I did on that medication. 

Luckily by my side is an amazing woman! My wife is the glue that held this family together. She did so much research trying to help me. She found a fibromyalgia forum and one of the people on there told her about an all natural plant that was having very positive results. 

After doing some more research and hearing all the testimonies I decided I was going to quit the horrible medication and I was going to give this plant a try. 

The first day of trying it, was the first day in a very long time I felt like my old self. NO pain, no hurting, no fog, nothing. I felt like me. Energized, happy and I did not feel high. I felt like me!!!!!

That was four years ago. My family and myself struggled for so long and to be normal has really changed our life. I now run a Fortune 500 company and my life couldn't be better. Best of all I haven't had a single pain or any other symptoms for four years!!! 

This is all thanks to a natural plant called Kratom!!!! 

All of this started because of something that is legal (energy drinks) but has been resolved by something you are trying to make not.

I beg you, I plead to you! Do not ban this plant. I do not want my life to go back to the way it was. I do not want the pain or any other symptom to come back.....I love my life!!!!

documents.commentText:
I've suffered two motor vehicle accidents and have a painful degenerative condition known as spondylitis. As such I've been prescribed codeine, tramadol, morphine and oxycodone and have been quite dependent on them while tolerance increased rapidly. I experienced side effects ranging from constipation to depression and spent most of my days in bed, unable to work. When I quit those I started using kratom. I found few side effects and that I was able to manage my pain better. In fact I felt motivated to exercise, swim, and do daily yoga, all of which help with my conditions and alleviate the depression and anxiety I struggle with. There are many common herbal remedies I have tried over the years. Kratom has been most beneficial, and has caused me fewer problems than things commonly available on the shelves of any drug store. Of course it's not without some small risks, but they are less than Tylenol. 
I will admit a vested interest. I eventually gained employment at the location I purchase my kratom. Daily I deal with happy, functional people who have their lives back after descending into addiction to opioids, alcohol and benzodiazepines. With the first of these, many had tried methadone or suboxone and relapsed or were unable to tolerate it. Their stories can be quite graphic and heart wrenching. I and they feel strongly that kratom was a valuable ally in emerging from those diminished states. I fervently hope they needn't descend back there should their herbal supplements be unavailable. 
By all means, regulations that test for adulterants and truth in labeling are a benefit for all, but a complete ban will not serve the public interest or health and will exacerbate a crisis that has claimed and continues to claim far too many.

documents.commentText: My wife is a wonderful person, she loves her dogs and spending time in the her garden. She works hard part time as a house cleaner and is trusted and loved by her clients. For 15 years she has suffered with Fibromyalgia which has no effective medical treatment, nothing available has worked. Doctors still don't even know what causes it. About four years ago my wife discovered a natural supplement Kratom that has been used by people safely for centuries. She did her own research, learned about people's experiences and eventually made the decision to try it. Adding it to her healthy lifestyle she was able to start living her life again, not perfect..just possible. It doesn't cure or treat her fibromyalgia, but has given her a new lease on life, and hope. I have never tried it. I did my own research and decided it's not for me. Living in a free society means taking responsibility for one's own choices. My wife has been responsibly and legally consuming Kratom for years and I can't argue with the results. There are no negative "drug" highs, she is not nodding off or staring into space. She is herself again, the woman I married.  The real issue is the negative consequences criminalizing a safe supplement will have on thousands of honest law abiding citizens. These are good people who are suffering and benefit from this natural plant. Those who benefit, our beloved spouses, mothers, fathers, grandparents and siblings may lose the one hope they had for something of a decent life. Thousands of responsible people including Veterans who fought for our freedom- are standing up demanding the right to continued legal use of this well established natural supplement, their loving family members are standing with them and so should you.

This issue should not be politicized

documents.commentText:
I am a 48 year old father of 9, 5 of which we have adopted out of the foster care program.  I am the owner and operator of a small landscape maintenance business, and am building a beef cattle farm from raw land.  In October of 2001, I was diagnosed with Lyme disease which has profoundly impacted the course and quality of my life.  Despite years of intensive antibiotic therapy, I remain unable to rid myself of this disease. Of the myriad symptoms that I experience on a daily basis, severe joint pain and crushing fatigue are omnipresent.   Additionally, a lifetime of hard labor, and several traumatic accidents has left my back with significant chronic pain.  
I have been taking prescribed opioid pain medication since 2002.  While these substances do provide some relief, I have found the quality of the pain management to be significantly lacking.  Now with all of the government interference in the healthcare industry, particularly with opioids, it has become a significant burden to obtain my prescribed medication. Due to new regulation, only one month supply is dispensed at a time, and an office visit must occur for refills.  The time demands and financial burden was significant. Indeed, these difficulties in providing for adequate pain management had brought me to the verge of having to give my physically active career and lifestyle. 
About one year ago I discovered the herb Kratom, and it has significantly changed my pain management protocol, and outlook.  Kratom useage has provided me with unrivaled reduction in my pain level, and has allowed me to dramatically reduce, and at times eliminate my use of the prescribed hydrocodone. After enduring 16 years of daily, severe pain, the periods of a near absence of pain provided by Kratom leaf is a gift that I had thought I would never again experience. This herb also provides a boost in energy and mood that is a welcome respite from the daily grind of Lyme disease.  The financial savings to my family from not needing to visit my doctor monthly have been significant.  Being able to order such an effective tool over the internet , and have it show up at my door is a godsend of convenience. 
It would be my great preference that the government keep its hands out of my healthcare, and leave Kratom alone. I do however realize that government will never restrain itself, and that some form of regulation is forthcoming. I would urge that any regulatory actions be limited to quality assurances, and age restriction.  In case you have not noticed, the American people have just expressed, in a very significant way, their frustration with government.  This recent attempt at emergency scheduling of a LEAF is just another example of how far removed we are from a state of liberty, and why so many people are so frustrated with the federal government. Please respect the rights of the people to choose whatever botanical tools they may wish.  Any actions by you that preclude the ability to freely obtain this herb will result in a dramatic reduction in the quality of my, and many others lives.

documents.commentText:
I am a current police officer in Houston Texas. On April 21st 2014 I was on duty and gave chase to theft suspects. I jumped a six foot fence and landed on my right leg. When my right leg made contact with the ground I heard a loud snap and felt my knee give to the right. Naturally when loosing balance the human body attempts to regain balance so I replaced my foot on the ground and again my knee gave to the left which caused my left leg to loose footing causing me to fall on the ground. As I sat there waiting for the pain to come I pull out my firearm in case someone wanted to take advantage of my injury and attack me.

After a few seconds I stand up and begin to walk "baby steps" to see how injured I was. During this time my knee snapped several times and I had to hop on one foot to the fence I jumped to hold myself up. I didn't want to call dispatch over the radio because quite frankly no matter how many people showed up I don't think they could get me across the fence. I look around and see a small four foot cattle fence. I hop to and roll my body over the cattle fence. I hop up someone's back yard and into the street. After an hour I get back to my patrol car and get transported to the hospital.

I get an MRI later in the week and discover severe damage in the Meniscus and ACL was completely severed in my right knee. I had no choice but to have surgery. After surgery this is when the pain became unbearable. The hydrocodone I was prescribed was not working well enough and felt like needles in my right knee when I would move it. I took hydrocodone like M&Ms because it simply did not work for more than 3 hours. My tolerance to hydrocodone grew and to really manage the pain became even more of a challenge. Around this time I discovered Kratom and with nothing to lose tried it. I would take kratom before my physical therapy sessions and was able to move better and work harder than before. Unfortunately it didn't help me sleep at night but at least my knee wasn't on fire. 

Today I have full function in my right knee and I owe it to the effect kratom had while I was in physical therapy. But unfortunately for me the Meniscus in my right knee was so bad the only way to fix it was to have a knee replacement which I was too young for. Today I take Kratom two times a day once in the morning and once at night. Without it my knee becomes inflamed after a jog and to be honest I can't afford to be a limp duck when I place myself in a life threatening situation everyday. I can't afford to have severe knee pain when at any minute I may have to run after someone or God forbid a shooting. Kratom is not perfect. My knee is not perfect with kratom but it definitely becomes manageable. Sometimes my knee gets really tired but for the most part the kratom helps. I owe my safety and ability to this amazing herb. I've taken kratom ever since and my tolerance has no grown significantly. I don't know what I would do if kratom became scheduled. 


Sincerely,

Brooks Cash

documents.commentText: My name is Eric Hutton, and I'm a 37 year old Doctor of Pharmacy working in a retail setting. Ever since graduating school and assuming a full-time position (an "upright" one, at that), I've dealt with a significant amount of back pain--significant not in its severity, but in its unrelenting presence--as well as the fatigue and stress that come with any job where your entire day is spent on your feet, often with the phone pressed between your shoulder and your ear. After several failed attempts to find something "wrong" with me (X-rays, MRI, ultrasound, etc.), I was starting to consider seeing a pain management specialist (and there are several in the vicinity of my work, so I was familiar with the types of treatment they offer). Still, I was hesitant, because without an official diagnosis, and an unwillingness to "play up" my pain level on command, I doubted they'd take me seriously. Plus, I got to see the cycle of dependency on a daily basis--patients who started out with a broken arm or some surgical procedure being prescribed short-term opioids, which gradually turns into long-term use, until they're referred to pain management where regular, around-the-clock opioids become a staple of the patient's regimen indefinitely (unless they're weaned off with an expensive prescription of suboxone, which often turns into an indefinite treatment itself). Luckily, it was right around this time that I discovered kratom. I was extremely skeptical that it would do anything, but within 30 minutes or so of consuming it for the first time, there was a mild but noticeable lift in my mood and energy, which then seemed to make the nagging pain more tolerable. After an initial period of finding the right level for me, I was able to take it at work, and get reliable relief that was just enough to enable me to smile and be engaged with our patients, even at the end of a 12 hour shift. The effects are about as noticeable as a strong cup of coffee (maybe two), but instead of being solely a nervous, jittery buzz, it provides a balanced sense of clarity and well-being. I've been taking kratom for nearly four years now, and have not had to escalate my usage to achieve the same effects. I've discussed it with my primary care physician, and he is thrilled that I've found something natural that alleviates my discomfort without putting me at the unnecessary risk associated with prescription pain killers. If a kratom ban were to go into effect, my quality of life would be significantly reduced without access to this safe, beneficial herb. Beyond that, I fear the quality of my care towards others would likewise be diminished--it's hard to be a truly good listener and problem-solver when all you can think about is how badly you want to sit down. With tobacco-related health care costs in the billions and ~480,000 deaths annually (CDC figures), I cannot understand why *this* harmless plant would be seen as posing an "imminent threat" to public safety. Additionally, considering the scope and severity of the current heroin/opioid epidemic, in my professional opinion it would be significantly *more* harmful to make a safe, natural alternative unavailable. I urge the decision-makers to look at the science, look at the data (not just in isolation, but as part of the bigger picture), and ask yourselves where the imminent threats to public safety TRULY lie. Thank you for your time.

documents.commentText: I'd like to thank you on my behalf that I can speak my feelings on this matter(also that my phone number is ANONYMOUS). I'm a Florida resident just trying to make an honest living and live a peaceful life. I own a small pressure cleaning business while working for a wallpaper installation and painting company. The work I do I enjoy yet life has some major downs. Growing up has not been fun. As a child I had a Schizophrenic/Bipolar mother and an alcoholic/drug abusing father so my grandmother adopted me due to me being abused. In school I have been bullied a lot. Plus my uncle got the same condition as my mother and he lived with us on and off. Life was scary as you can tell. Because of that I was diagnosed with Depression and ADHD. While in college someone I was close to introduced me to Kratom. I looked into it yet I have't taken it till I had knee surgery. It was excellent for natural pain relief. The pain pills were habit forming so this kept me safe. Through out the years I have found this plant to ease my suicidal thoughts, reduce alcohol consumption, give inner solace, control my compulsive behavior, eases pain after a hard days work, get me away from pornography, etc. Since medical marijuana has been made legal here as well as many states it would be contradicting to say the least that Kratom gets banned while cannabis is legalized. Kratom has helped me obtain a functional life where if it were to be banned I'd have to suffer Depression while taking medication with harmful side effects. Please understand that many people are suffering and want to be happy and life in peace without getting their minds totally wrapped. That is the beauty of Kratom; it gives a euphoria while remaining sober! A truly beneficial supplement that should be sold in health food stores and local pharmacies  in the herbal section. If such a ban were to ensue then we could see a major rise in serious illicit drug abuse, not to mention the suicides from depression. Life in this world has become more challenging so something needs to be there for the people. The harm that the pharmaceuticals have done is why I avoid them. Another thing I wanted to mention is that when I introduced Kratom to my father he benefited from it for his arthritis as well as his pain pill abuse. Sadly this year though he passed away while the pain pills were ruining his life. I wished I introduced this to him earlier. I'm grateful that there is such a plant on this planet so why make my life more depressive? I just want to be at peace without having to take illegal drugs like heroin or cocaine and pharmaceutical  drugs like Haloperidol where there's tooth loss or Prozac where it can increase violent tendencies. If you truly care about the people such as I of this world , please consider my and everyone else' feelings on the matter. Thank you!

documents.commentText: I am goimg to be completely honest which is a matter of embaressment and has been kept private as part of my past. Living in Texas I was In an accident and placed on hydrocodone for over 3 years, my doctor finally took me off of them but by then i was very much addicted to being pain free and the high they produced. The physical pain withdrawing off of 30mg of hydrocodone a day (that is 3,10 mg pills. not considered alot by addict standards) but thats how little of the drug it takes to be addicted to hydrocodone oxycodon etc.)so I went to a pill mill doctor to continue taking them to me it was so i could live life be an active mother for my kids the high was a side effect personally i didnt care for so per my request we lowered it to 1,10mg hydrocodone pill a day. Thats all I took for the next 3 years just enough to not feel the pain or detox, I was a housewife with 2 children I was not a danger to my kids i did the best i could to stay in control on just 1 a day. I just could not take the pain and sickness of quitting them completely. A doctor helped my pain from a serious accident prescribing them and unwittingly created a 6 year addiction. When I moved to Florida I was given 3 month supply. I lost my heakth insurance when i moved & continuing on hydrocodone was going to cost too much pain management is 200$ a visit plus your script cost, so I was going to attempt to quit again. The last time i tried to quit i was on 30mg a day and cold turkey day 3 I was still curled around my toilet vomitting, intense cramping , coupled with sweat and crying out for help then I went into a seizure my son called the ambulance, rushed to the hospital and while I was unconscious pumped me full of morphine, found nothing in my system but a little marijuana that had helped me through the first 2 days of withdraws a friend gave to me 3rd day I had no more and being illegal while hydrocodone is legal which is insane, I would never as a mother go looking for illegal drugs but I seriously considered it and understand why so many are addicted to heroine. ..when the hospital released me I was back on hydro and assumed that was how I would have to live the rest of my life imprisoned by 1 pill a day in fear they could be stolen or I lost them or anything happened to them i could seizure again.So there I am new to Florida no new doctor and running low and knowing what is goimg to happen when I run out but determined to kick them for good (btw I broke my back in that accident and the pain will always remain but I hoped to find a pain solution that was not dangerous to my health or held me captive) a friend of my dad's told him about kratom... I looked into it studied it researched everything about it realized it was a legal alternative from all the testimonials  and decided to try it. I ordered them and was scared to take them with the remaining hydros, so when I took my last hydrocodone I waited 24 hours before taking the Kratom to be safe the hydrocodone was out completely I began the shakes and direah pain everywhere in every joint and sweating and this is off of ONE 10MG HYDROCODONE A DAY THATS ALL I did not experience vomiting nor was the detox as intense as detoxing off of 30mg a day I can not even imagine the stories of people I know who withdrew off of 100mg a day habits and turned to cheap street drugs..on day 2 I woke up with a sweat imprint in my bed and immediately had to run to the bathroom then I got out the recommended amount of kratom capsules which was 3 for withdraws I took them and I felt relief from detox symptoms AND back pain within an hour I did not feel any fuzzy headed high I was clear headed! I cried woth joy and thanked god for his creation. They are not only safe but they saved my life from what is truly a seriously scary drug unless you are terminally ill.. if anything is being brought up to be made a law in this country it should be lawsuits against the pharmaceutical companies that stated "hydrocodone is not addictive or dangerous " how do you allow such an outright lie to be told to the public? There is an epidemic of addiction to heroine and prescription drugs in this country & kratom could greatly reduce that as alternative medicine for injuries that require pain management for long term but especially short term. I've been taking kratom for 3 years now sometimes I don't take them at all and take a few naproxen(aleve) there's no withdraw symptoms I am not a prisoner any longer the only thing I experience when I don't take them is back pain and that reminds me I'm alive ..when the pain becomes intense I take powdered kratom in a capsule and find relief for my intense pain only when needed  without any high or dependancy . Please dont take away the 1000s of people who have found the freedom of living productive drug free lives with a plant that is 100% safe as we are all living proof while others dont know an alternative exists to an addiction to pain pills & turn to a cheap alternative such as heroine.

documents.commentText: My name is Austin Mastronardi, I am a 29 year old registered nurse. I am not a user of kratom, but fear that classifying kratom as schedule 1 will stifle the ability to perform research about possible medicinal uses. In the United States we are in the middle of an opioid epidemic. Anecdotal evidence shows that kratom my be beneficial in helping treat opioid addiction. As a person who regularly sees people suffer through opioid withdrawals in a professional capacity, I find it irresponsible that this plant might not be fully studied for its potential medical value.

documents.commentText:
As a harm reduction advocate, mental health therapist and professional in the field of addiction treatment, I strongly encourage the DEA to reconsider the intent to place Kratom on Schedule 1, and consider regulating it in a way that leaves it available for researchers, physicians, and the general public.  Whether kratom needs to be regulated as an herbal supplement, a prescription medicine, or a recreational substance is yet to be determined.  Kratom does not pose an imminent risk to public safety, and it does appear to have significant medicinal value.  

Kratom has potential for abuse and dependence, more like caffeine than opioid medications, and between those two extremes, it appears to fall somewhere closer to caffeine on the spectrum of safety vs. risk.  Daily users of kratom will have some withdrawal symptoms when they stop taking it, as do coffee drinkers when they decide to go caffeine-free.  

A small number of users develop dependence and will need help to stop taking kratom.  These risks are low compared to the known and potential medicinal benefits of this plant which has been used for thousands of years in SE Asia.  As others commenting have reported, kratom helps with pain control and opioid withdrawal.  More research is definitely called for rather than a total ban on the plant.  

Kratom is not a lethal substance- all the reports of deaths related to kratom have been due to toxicity of multiple substances, often a mixture of opioids and benzodiazepines (which can be deadly) and mitragynine was also present.  Placing this medicinal plant on Schedule 1 would do much more harm than good, and would divert our limited resources to prosecuting pain patients and safe recreational users.  It would negatively impact many communities across the US, pushing those in search of pain control to use more dangerous prescription and illegal opioids, leading to increased rates of incarceration and addiction to opiates like heroin, fentanyl, and oxycodone.

Kratom is NOT dangerous enough to require Schedule 1, but more research and regulations are needed to make it safely available to those who need/ want it.  Let's work together to determine how our communities can have safe access to this medicinal plant and how we can provide the public with the information needed to safely use kratom as they choose.  An outright ban is not the answer and would cause significant harm to a large number of people.  

Some suggestions/ options other than Schedule 1:  
Place mitragynine as schedule III or IV and require physician prescription.  
Make kratom available as over the counter restricted to 18+, or 21+
Leave it to the FDA to regulate kratom as an herbal supplement available over the counter. 
Allow states to regulate it as they do cannabis, tobacco, and alcohol.
Require businesses that sell kratom to have a license/certificate to sell it and include harm reduction information to customers.
Do nothing yet, and encourage researchers to learn more about kratom and mitragynine before any further action is taken regarding its legality.  
Release educational material to the public so we can make informed decisions about whether or not to use kratom.  

 Instead of banning a natural plant medicine that's been used by human beings for thousands of years, let's learn more about it through research and provide those who already use it with as much information as possible so they may continue to treat their symptoms as they choose, as safely as possible.

documents.commentText:
Adults in America are given the opportunity's everyday to do a countless number of things in an irresponsible manner. Taking away all the things they can be irresponsible with is treating them like children. That is not consistent with having a free society. I do understand that somethings are just to dangerous to allow people to even experiment with because they are so addictive or so dangerous that there can be no expectation of responsible use. I think that is the real question and I see Kratom as a substance that falls well into the area where responsible use can be the expectation for the general public. 

The fiduciary responsibility of the FDA is also a point of concern. So the question regarding that is, Will allowing the use of Kratom, by the general public of adults, cost more then the tax revenue it produces? I see no evidence that that is the case but of course I have no access to records that could prove otherwise. Speaking exclusively from my experience I do not see how that could be the case. Should the costs of Kratom eclipse the tax revenue, like I expect tobacco, alcohol, opiate base meds., ect do, an appropriate tax to cover those cost would be in order as it is with said examples. The cost for court expenses to determine the legality of Kratom will likely cost the tax payer more then the effect legal Kratom will ever have on the tax payers when offset by the tax generated by the sale of Kratom. I would dare to say it would be much more likely to generate revenue then deplete it. This based on the revenue the legalization of marijuana has produced in every state that has legalized it. While marijuana use is much more widely spread the effects of marijuana are dramatically more profound causing an altered state that likely results in more of a burden on tax payer then Kratom ever will. I would argue that the addictive properties of marijuana eclipse that of Kratom as well. This is also would less encumber the total tax revenue. 

I would like to encourage a less costly resolution that could happen by finding ground both the DEA and Kratom users find responsible and prudent, out of court.

I am writing to also comment about my experience with Kratom and to encourage it's continued legal use. I have used Kratom for about a year now for chronic pain. I have torn cartage in my hip that require surgery that I cannot afford. The costs are looking to be somewhere in the $20,000 area. With heath insurance coverage changing all the time and the government being an unreliable source for determining the future of insurance, it is an importance option that I have Kratom as a way to live life until a better solution arises for me. It is not something that gets me high by any means. I am not feeling altered or unsafe when I use Kratom. I do sometime feel a short lived feeling of uplift in mood. It is subtle most of the time and I rarely notice it if I am working.

 Kratom is on par with Caffeine in my assessment. The effects are profoundly less assaulting then alcohol, prescription medications like codeine, energy drinks(unless you have a tolerance for these drink. I shake. feel anxious and cannot sleep if I drink these type of drinks) or marijuana and even moderately less pronounced then antihistamines, sleep aids, and diet pills. Of course like any of these products, when using them for the first time the effects can be felt more aggressively and I believe that is true for Kratom as well. 

Personally I believe Kratom should remain legal. Though I can see why it would be regulated for adults only. I believe energy drinks should be regulated for adults only even more so. I have never had any dangerous or harmful effects from the use of Kratom. In my experience if I use more I do not get more of an effect. It instead will make me sick to my stomach, which I am susceptible to feeling with many consumables. It is a much preferred solution then pain meds. for me. Pain meds. are addictive, much more dangerous, in fact people become addicted to and die from pain meds everyday. Kratom is a soft ,subtle, natural, solution I am comfortable with. 

Kelly Combs

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.
Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6
About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v
There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...
The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?
As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

Greetings,

I am writing this to the DEA to express my opinions and experience with Kratom, and to urge them to not reschedule/ban it in the USA.  First I want to state that I am a healthy 32 year old male with gainful employment, a long-term relationship with my soon to be fianc, and plenty of healthy relationships with family and friends.  I take Kratom often; I find it to be very useful for pain relief, mood elevation, and energy in a non-narcotic fashion.  I love Kratom personally and know that many people can benefit from its use.  It is a fantastic alternative to much harder pain relieving medicines that have MUCH higher risk for abuse, overdosing, and dependency, especially opiates.  It is pretty benign at worst and incredibly helpful with very low risk at best.  It is much less taxing on the body over other pharmaceuticals.  

With that being said I don't take any pharmaceuticals and essential my experience with Kratom would fall in the recreational side of things, even though I do receive some medical benefits as well (pain relief, anti-depressant).  I have encountered people who use it for serious medical purposes and have used it to overcome opiate addiction even when the doctors were still pushing meds on them.  Like I said before it is benign for recreational use, and has serious medical uses as well.  PLEASE LEAVE KRATOM UNSCHEDULED.

documents.commentText:
Docket No. DEA-442W

Kratom public use should be banned

Dr. Rene Perez - family physician

Kratom should be classified as schedule 1 due to :
1) Abuse by opiate addicts to overcome withdrawal symptoms of abuse of opiates. This makes it harder for addicts to actually overcome their dependence on opiates as long as it is readily available and used to be able to continue to abuse other opiates with the least undesirable effects as possible

2) In my clinical experience as a physician I see that the rate of relapse to using opiates among addicts is higher with kratom than with other DEA approved medications for the treatment of opiate dependence. This may lead to the dangerous risks of relapse and overdose, including death.

Self-medicating with kratom is dangerous without the necessary pre-market approval process set forth by the FDA and the time tested safety of physician use and monitoring

documents.commentText:
The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement

 kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...


Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.


Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6


About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v


There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...


The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,

My name is Myles Cooney and I am a 26 year old technology professional living in the Chicago area. I work in a technical sales role at a software technology company. I would like to write a few words about the positive effects of Kratom.

Throughout my life I have experienced mild anxiety and at times a lack of focus. I started taking Kratom on and off about 1.5 years ago to combat some of these negative cognitive effects I had been dealing with. Since starting to use Kratom I have garnered the focus to  accomplish following:

-Learn full stack software development to the point where I have helped local businesses build systems and web tools needed. 
-Start public speaking and performing stand up comedy. Since I have let go of the taking of kratom and can get on stage without any use of it. However, it helped me get started.

I can say with 100% confidence that I am not dependant on Kratom whatsoever. Just like I can stop drinking coffee or alcohol, I can stop taking Kratom no problem and my life would be okay. My take on Kratom is that sure, it can be considered a drug. But so can caffeine, nicotine and marijuana, which is increasingly becoming considered harmless and made legal in many states in the USA. 

Just like these the aforementioned substances, Kratom is not harmful. What are harmful are the drugs such as ritalin, vicodin, and other mind altering drugs that doctors prescribe day in and day out. My brother was prescribed ritalin growing up. I have no doubt that he didn't need it ,and could have used something much more mild such as Kratom with better health and cognitive benefits.

What I can't understand is how the US government can have such an extreme reaction to a plant such as Kratom? I have taken it on and off for the last year and a half and at no point have I thought, "Well, this should definitely be considered in a class of drugs with cocaine, heroin and methamphtamine." 

I kindly ask you to consider the regulation of Kratom just as you have with substances such as alcohol, nicotine, and how some states such as Colorodo have done with Marijuana. You will without a doubt save the lives and increase the livelihood of hundreds of thousands of people without harming anyone.

Thanks for your time.

Best,
Myles

documents.commentText:
Dear all,

I want to tell you my whole life story and why kratom helps me, but with only 5000 words I have to choose carefully.  My entire life I've suffered from severe depression and generalized anxiety disorder, as well as gastroparesis and spondylolisthesis.   Since adolescence doctors have put me on a wide range of pharmaceutical cocktails, many of which cause more negative side effects than benefits and very few have helped the underlying problems.  SSRI antidepressants such as Lexapro and Zoloft, benzodiazepines like Xanax and Klonopin, antipsychotics Seroquel and Ability, NDRIs like Wellbutrin, SARIs such as Trazodone and an endless list of stomach medications (i.e.: Promethazine, Reglan, Megestrol, etc).  This is nowhere near the full list of prescription medications of which side effects I have suffered through in hope of relief from my psychological and physical pain.

Kratom is not a perfect "drug" ("drug" being a word that encompasses anything from morphine, marijuana and xanax all the way to tylenol coffee and tea).  There are side effects and it's not right for everyone.  But there is an enormous list of positive uses for it that the DEA turned a blind eye to and instead chose to focus on the negatives, even discounting a large base of scientific evidence and thousands of years of historical use in Asian countries.  

Depression is a horribly debilitating condition: it drains motivation and creates an immense dissatisfaction with life.  At times, my depression has been so extreme that I was suicidal and hurt myself.  The medications prescribed cause me to live in a tired, mental fog and reduce my range of emotions.  Sure, I feel less sadness, but my levels of happiness are significantly lower, as if there's a ceiling preventing true joy.  

Anxiety keeps me from achieving goals and experiencing social life.  It keeps me at home alone to avoid the painful feelings that come with anxiety.  For those who don't suffer from anxiety, it seems like a silly problem but I assure you it severely limits what I can do with my life.  

For me, kratom is easily the most beneficial substance I've ever found for my depression and anxiety.  It helps motivate me, gives me energy and allows me to feel more confident so I can achieve the goals I've put off for so long.  With kratom, I'm not dragged down by my feelings of sadness or fear of not fitting in.  I feel good about myself instead of feeling like an inadequate failure due to my past, things I wish I'd had the courage to do and unbalanced brain chemistry.  An added bonus is that it also helps with the pain I experience with gastroparesis and spondylolisthesis.  In the past I would take above average doses of Advil and Aleve many times daily.  Advil and Aleve put stress on your digestive system and so, while this helped with my back pain, it would cause even more discomfort in my stomach.  I've always been underweight and unable to get into the normal range.  After a year with kratom, I've gained 20 pounds and am now considered "Normal".  My doctor was amazed because I have never weighed over 135 lbs, and as a 5'10" male approaching his 30s, this is an extreme achievement.  

Please do not make Kratom illegal.  Obviously, like any drug, regulation would be a good thing.  Too many "headshops" have sold kratom with adulterants which caused hospital visits and this is unacceptable.  But there are many reputable vendors online whom sell pure, high quality kratom and many customers benefit greatly from this plant.

I beg you to reconsider the plan to make Kratom a Schedule I drug.  Doing so would take relief out of many peoples' lives and cause them to return to the unpromising pharmaceutical industry.  Hopefully, one day our pharmaceutical industry will reach a point where the negative side effects are reduced and medications treat conditions effectively.  But until then, many of us need kratom.  After years of searching for relief, I've finally found something that truly helps.  Please don't take that away.

In regards to Docket No. DEA-442W, I'm asking you to please leave kratom alone. It is the best tool our country could have to battle the opiod & heroine addiction crisis not to mention the PTSD & suicide rate of our veterans. I've spent the last year exploring it and am much better for doing so. 

For over 10 yrs I've been prescribed painkillers, muscle relaxers and anti depressants and nerve pills to combat various ailments. The Rx drugs were compromising my health & quality of life not to mention my family's. My digestive system has been damaged and I'm not sure that can be fixed but the narcotics that used to be the best choice for my pain management caused it.  My teeth have also become weak with the pills and that really feeds my depression and anxiety.

Kratom sounds like a miracle fix all but it's not. It helps tremendously with physical pain, some mental anguish and gives great energy. I think it'd be a grave mistake to schedule it, for all Americans, especially with the opiod & addiction crisis we face here in the states.

documents.commentText:
The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement
kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v

There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

I walked to the bus stop to pick up my 10 year old daughter, she was so surprised. We walked home and she says "Mom! You're not limping! You're smiling! Did you get the kraken, kartom....um kratom?" I said "Yup!" She stopped walking, tears in her eyes and says "You're back! The you that was you is back!" I even felt up to going out to dinner for our anniversary. My husband; who is one of the most stoic men you'll ever meet, hugged me without fear of hurting me, looked into my eyes, his eyes gleaming with tears and said "I've missed you so much. documents.commentText: I am a veteran of 5 years of the U.S. armed forces and the global war on terrorism. After receiving an honorable discharge from my branch of service, I set forth to utilize my GI Bill and receive an education. Finding my way back into the normal way of living as a civilian was and continues to remain challenging for me. Not only did I have strong anxiety when dealing with people, I had suffered injuries in service that required some form of pain medication to subside. When I went to the VA for treatment, they did not hesitate to prescribe me pain medication. However, as I have many colleagues and friends who have gone down this route before me, I decided that I did not want to become reliant on these medication as I have seen the unintended effects the pharmaceuticals can have. With that in mind I searched for natural remedies and stumbled upon the plant in question. I began using Kratom leaves once a day to ease my pain and cannot express how much it has helped me in my life. Not only do I have to live in constant physical pain, I no longer struggle with the anxiety I have had when being in groups of people, that before kept me distant and to avoid all social situations. I was worried about dosages and a potential addiction, but have found that in my 4 years of taking this plant once a day, I have never had to increase the dosage to produce the same effects, nor have I had any negative side effects or issues with removing this plant from my diet. I strongly disagree with the notion that this plant is dangerous to our society and its members and believe that it can only produce positive effects, in helping veterans like myself as well as other people who have severe anxiety and depression to feel normal again and return to their communities whole. I state my case solely for the raw plant form and not any synthetic creation nor extract. I have concern about individuals who produce synthetic forms of this chemical and extracts of the plant for these not only promote bad behavior but introduce issues, as all extracts can be dangerous depending on their potency. However, I would urge to keep the plant in its raw form available for the public as in its natural form, it cannot be hazardous to one's health. I have never felt that my government was truly harming my life until the news of the intent to ban this plant. Without it, I will have to live in pain, or give into pain medications with life threatening side effects, and live with crippling social anxiety that may force me to give into even more medication with seriously grave side effects. Having seen the alternatives, I believe the natural methods are the most safe and productive for our society. Thank you for considering my comments. I hope you keep all of our comments and lives in mind when considering to your decisions.

I truly hope that the option of kratom isn't taken away from people, when I and so many others have found it to be such a help. (NOTE: I am resubmitting this message with my full home address and contact information; please feel free to delete the duplicate: DEA-2016-0015-0006)

DEA Staff:

I have been using kratom to help me with symptoms ranging from pain to depression, and no other medication has helped me more consistently, and with no side effects, interactions, or other issues.  I estimate that I have taken over 100 doses in the small- to medium-range (and I have a log of every time I've using it, including date/time, strain, and amount).  I have never felt the need to take increase my dosage, nor have I felt any adverse effects of not taking kratom for days or weeks at a time.  Simply, it provides near-instant relief in safe way, and helps me concentrate, experience moderate relief from chronic pain, and to maintain a productive lifestyle.  If there is any issue, it's rare, and usually results in mild, short-lived nausea.  I cannot say that about many other drugs and medications that you consider legal.

I was shocked to learn that the DEA single-handedly determined to put an "emergency" ban on kratom sale in the U.S.   The DEA has blocked perfectly safe herbal medications for decades, and even now, you have restated that marijuana - a drug for which there has never been any true risk, and where illegality was based on a century of race-inspired policy, misinformation, myths, and anecdotal fears.  You must realize that, where marijuana has been legalized, there have been no major problems, and a growing super-majority of the country supports its legalization.  Working against that causes a loss of credibility in your organization, your judgment, and your objectivity.  That will also increase a general mistrust in the objectivity and policies of the DEA, something that might lead to actual, real danger.

Now, more than ever, I implore to take a science-based stand on medications.  You're not only potentially harming the American people and keeping them from risk, but the message you send to other countries in the world will cause them to create criminals out of people that are using a perfectly safe (and affordable) medication.  You will make it nearly impossible to research, benefitting only large drug companies, and doing a major disservice to the many of us that benefit tremendously from kratom.  Please reconsider your actions, based your policy on science, and do what is good and right for Americans and the entire world.

documents.commentText:
I am 27 yr old and hold a graduate degree from an Ivy League university. I've been taking kratom regularly for 9 years with absolutely no negative side effects. There are enumerable misconceptions about this supplement, and I urge you not to fall victim to the misinformation of the press and online forums. While taking kratom, I've held a 5 yr relationship, graduated with my BA and MA degrees, and happily work in the advertising industry in a major northeast city. I say this because the people you would be arresting for possession of this substance are not criminals, thieves, violent offenders, nor are we junkies itching for our next fix. On the contrary, we are some of the most significant contributors to society. We are people who hold power in our industries and if this law gets passed despite the people's opinion, I assure you we will oppose this action in any way we legally can. The DEA is over-stepping and is unaware of the damage this will cause to individuals and families. It was such a  fight simply to get a public comment period, costing thousands of dollars and protests just to practice our right to get our voice formally heard in an online text box.

Though I strongly believe an increase in medical research on Kratom would be beneficial, it does not make logical sense to ban an herbal supplement simply because we don't know much about it. The 15 "deaths" behind kratom ALL involve an additional substance (heroin, cocaine, etc.). I implore you to present a single case of death caused SOLELY by kratom. In addition, the DEA sites about 600 calls to the CDC within a 5 year period relating to kratom, as if this were a high number. If anything, this is such a low number that it could actually be presented as evidence to keep kratom legal. Hundreds of thousands of calls are made to the CDC in a SINGLE year for Tylenol. This number of calls is not a solid argument. If anything, I urge the government to regulate this industry, calling for labeling standards so consumers know exactly what they are getting.

Placing this on Schedule 1 would be in line with making coffee Schedule 1 before we knew what it's effects were. Imagine if someone went to prison for life because they had a 16oz bag of coffee...; not to mention kratom is in the same plant family as coffee. This would be unjust and cause great outrage among kratom advocates.

Thanks you for taking the time to read my comments and for opening a comment period as is the people's right. I urge you to permanently withdraw your notice of intent, regulate the industry, continue medical research, and keep a close eye on this wonderful herb's effects on society. I have the utmost confidence that this plant is safe, that I urge you to try it to form your own opinion instead of getting your information from online reporters and random users on web forums.

Regards.

documents.commentText:
Docket No. DEA-442W

Hello. Thank you for opening this issue up for public comment, and for your time and consideration. I am a 29-year-old female and I work as a Social Media Manager and Assistant for a local artist. I am writing to say that I oppose any ban or scheduling of Mitragyna Speciosa (Kratom) or any of its alkaloids.

I have experienced varying degrees of back pain for as long as I can remember. Approximately three years ago, I was diagnosed with Degenerative Disc Disease and Scoliosis. I'm told that I am "too young" for this. Many of my pain management options seem rather scary and bleak. I have so far chosen to forego painful spinal injections, and after witnessing three different loved ones undergo failed spinal surgeries leaving them permanently disabled, I would like to avoid that avenue for as long as possible. Pain medications bring their own set of risks and seem to be out of the question because of my age. Over-the-counter medications sometimes help to an extent, but they are hard on my stomach and aren't meant for long-term use. Thankfully, I have found kratom tea to be a benign yet effective alternative to help manage my pain.

I have participated in physical therapy. I practice yoga and stretching. I like to walk, ride my bicycle, and swim for exercise. I have a relatively healthy diet, I very rarely drink alcohol, caffeine, or soda, and I do not smoke. I am able to be this active with the help of kratom and I have returned to a healthier weight as a result (from 170lbs down to 140lbs). I use a heating pad, ice pack, back brace, and TENS unit (a therapeutic device that uses low-voltage electrical currents to stimulate nerves for pain relief) as needed. Kratom is one of many tools I have found to help ease some of my spinal pain. It is not a panacea and some days are still tough. I understand and accept the minimal risks as an informed adult and I believe I should be allowed to make that choice for myself. 

I fear the ways my life would change if kratom were no longer available to me. My daily pain would increase and my physical activity and productivity would suffer. Many days I would be unable to sit or even stand up straight. I would end up spending significantly more time in bed. Without kratom, I fear what limited options would be left available to me. Without kratom, I would be faced with choosing between the side effects of potentially harmful pain medications, painful invasive procedures that give only temporary relief, and surgeries where the risks outweigh the benefits. Kratom has proven to be a valuable, effective tool for me in managing my chronic pain and maintaining the quality of life that I want. Living in nearly constant daily pain is not the life I want for myself. I really am too young to live like that. I want to be able to stand up straight and move around. I want to be able to go outside and exercise and participate in life without requiring days of bed rest to recover. Health food stores carry a wide variety of herbal teas that people use to relax, sleep, or feel energized. Kratom tea helps me be an active, productive member of society. Please don't let it also make me a criminal. I urge you to not make kratom a scheduled substance.

Again, thank you for your time and for allowing this public comment period. Please consider all research and do not ban this plant. Thank you for listening.

documents.commentText:
Thank you for your careful consideration of Kratom. As an emergency physician and medical toxicologist, my practice is finely tuned to the dangers of opioid addiction and overdose. Since 2006, my group has been following Kratom, reports of its use, assistance in managing addiction, and toxicity. Overall, this agent is a weak opioid that does have addictive potential. Yet, we rarely meet patients in the emergency department for complications of Kratom use, Kratom addiction, or evidence of Kratom toxicity. Severe adverse events (e.g., seizures) have been attributed to Kratom adulterants (substances added to the natural product). Recently we published a study on Kratom adulteration with a team at the University of Mississippi; we are concerned that Kratom manufacturers are "boosting" their natural products with chemical grade mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine (the active alkaloids in Kratom). The addition of extra mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine increases the risk of addiction and adverse effects. Overall, I do not believe that Schedule I status for Kratom is warranted or of significant public health importance; however, I worry that the lack of regulation of Kratom contents makes users vulnerable to adverse effects. 

Thank you,
Kavita Babu MD, FACEP, FACMT
Emergency Medicine/ Medical Toxicology
