documents.commentText:
Dear Drug Enforcement Administration:
I am writing in support of Kratom remaining a non-scheduled substance.  I am a psychiatrist, and have patients who benefit greatly from Kratom; only rarely have I seen patients have difficulty with Kratom, and in those instances they were actively addicted to other substances.  I have seen no instances of overdose or serious side effects from Kratom, though I am aware that cases of overdose have been reported.  Patients who benefit from Kratom are of two types:  the first are recovering addicts, typically opiate addicts, for whom Kratom provides stabilization of their mood and cravings.  Dose escalation is unusual, because Kratom has a ceiling such that a person trying to get high on Kratom will be frustrated, disappointed, and nauseated.  They may feel sick from ingesting large amounts of an alkaloid plant, but they don't die as do persons taking high doses of pure mu-agonists.  The second group of patients has chronic pain (who may also be in recovery from an addiction).  These patients eschew opiates for fear of addiction and their deleterious effects on mood and functionality; they also find that opiates used long-term are ineffective for pain control (which they often seem to understand better than their physicians).  In addition, many of these chronic pain patients have ruined their stomachs after years of NSAID use, so are no longer able to avail themselves of this major category of analgesics.  What remains for them are the anti epileptics (gabapentin, pregabalin, et al.) and certain antidepressants (duloxetine, TCAs).  And, for some, Kratom.  
The pharmacology of Kratom is not well understood.  This is an argument for continued study, not a shutting down of investigation.  What is clear to me is that Kratom does not have the typical problems seen with regular opiates.  Just today, I met a patient who reported getting addicted to opiates following Vicodin use after having wisdom teeth removed.  I hear the "wisdom teeth/Vicodin" story a couple of times every month.  And yet I've not once heard of a patient taking Kratom and then progressing to heroin or prescription opioids.  
Many of my medical colleagues reflexively oppose Kratom because they know little about it, and are quick to lump it in with the panoply of "new" Internet drugs.  This is a mistake, and I strongly encourage the DEA to take a step back.  Just because Kratom is new (at least in the US) does not make it equivalent to other new substances such as cathinones, designer hallucinogens, etc.   Let us not make the grave error of contempt prior to investigation.
Finally, I have heard the argument that the ingredients/purity of Kratom cannot be assured; this is a reasonable concern, but it is not a unique concern.  I am sure you are aware that many substances used medicinally are not what they claim, and that even some of our prescription medications are also not what they claim:  the FDA has acknowledged their inability to ensure quality in the supply chain, especially from medications sourced abroad, with the great bulk of generic medications never undergoing a purity assay on a random basis.  
I would much rather see the DEA devote its resources to better oversight of opiates and benzodiazepines, medications which destroy and end lives. I would prefer to see more attention paid to the galloping onslaught of cannabis legalization--we are only just seeing the first cases of a major flood of problems related to "recreational" cannabis use.  I would like to see better use of suboxone; how curious it is that suboxone prescribers are limited to the number of patients they may treat, but the prescribing of opiate medications is entirely unrestricted (shouldn't it be the reverse?)  Kratom is used benignly by large numbers of people and has potential in helping addicts to establish and maintain sobriety; I hope we can continue to use it.  
Thank you for considering my comments.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern-

I'm writing to voice my concern about kratom being listed as a schedule one drug. As someone who is mixed-race Thai-American descent I am well aware of kratom's history in Southeast Asia. The plant was originally used in Thailand, Laos and Burma as a way to break local people's addiction to opium - which in the early part of the 20th century was an absolute epidemic.
Kratom worked so well that the opium cartels in Thailand pressured the government to outlaw the plant as it was hurting their profits (and curing millions of their addiction).
As someone who has watched his best friend nearly lose everything thanks to an Oxycotin addiction, I see very many similarities happening now in the US. The Sachler family (makers of Oxy) have just entered into the Forbes wealthies 15 families in America - meanwhile their drug has destroyed much of the middle of my country. 
Please reconsider the ban of this plant.

P.S. - I close relative is a former DEA agent. I know the job you do is difficult enough and encourage your enforcement of truly dangerous materials.

The only other option for addicts is suboxone or methadone, which is unavailable to anyone without insurance. Even then the treatments are ridiculously expensive and the drugs are much more harmful than Kratom itself.

Kratom is the only thing that I can afford. I live in a low income area in Missouri, where there is a lot of prescription abuse. How can it be that these pills can be pushed legally, but when someone wants to get off them, the same system that hooked people, won't help anyone without getting their thousands of dollars first. Don't know if you guys know, but suboxone is being sold as a street drug, so people are getting high on it.

Please don't ban Kratom, it's my only hope.

I don't have health insurance. It's too costly for someone that makes minimum wage like myself. If you must do something regulate it like Tylenol, but even that will probably raise the price so much that it will become out reach for most of the poor addicts.

Banning Kratom or making it harder to get or more costly will hurt a lot of people. They will go back to opiates. It's a disease brought on by the pharmaceutical companies, that this plant can cheaply and effectively help a lot of people like myself.

So in conclusion please help me stay a normal person, leave Kratom as a dietary supplement. I've never been happier or healthier than I am now. I no longer feel like a junkie.

Thanks for reading my story.

documents.commentText:
Dear DEA, 

Please don't ban kratom because:	

-       Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
	If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
	Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
	Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
	Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
	Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

Thank you.

Melissa Harris, MBA
CEO, Telecom Training Corporation 
melissa@telecomtrainingcorporation.com

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern, 


	I wish to remain anonymous but am a thirty five year old medical student, wife and loving mother. I realize the move to ban kratom was made from a place of concern, but I implore you to research this herb thoroughly before making this decision. This herd has been a part of my daily life for a decade. After being diagnosed with multiple sclerosis and degenerative disk disease, my prognosis was bleak. I found myself under thirty years old and barely able to walk. My physician were kind and caring people, I have no doubt that they wanted me to recover some of my faculties; however, there is no cure for pain that comes with either of these diagnoses. Standard treatment for chronic pain leaves much to be desired. For a time I complied with my physician's orders, but found myself almost completely incapacitated. No longer could I responsibly raise my child since I spent most of the day asleep. My waking hours were like watching television in thick fog; it was no way to live for anyone. Then, completely by chance, I found an alternative that could possible give me a way out of my nightmarish dream life.	
 I will not say kratom has cured me, there is no permanent solution for my ailments. Be that as it may, kratom has decreased my issues enough for me to power through and become a productive member of society once more. Once again I am able to work and contribute to my family. This semester I hit dean list for my program in school, and am thankful that Im stable enough to attempt finishing my education. Honestly, I would rather not imagine myself without kratom. From what small patches of time that I do remember between onset of my conditions and my discovery, it equates to a slow, painful state worse than death. 


Thank you, 
Anonymous

documents.commentText:
In reference to Docket No. DEA-442W
My name is Theresa W. I am a 56 year old female with a bachelor degree in business who works as an application analyst. Please do not make kratom illegal or take it off the market for responsible adults. I suffer minor aches and pains from osteoarthritis and the effects of getting older. I have been taking NSAIDS daily since 2009, of which known long term effects include kidney, stomach, and heart damage; to address these aches until I tried kratom about a year ago. I found that Kratom tea relieves my pain so that I can be more active and sleep better. In addition, it helps me feel more motivated and in a better mood. I drink it a few times a week after I do yard work or exercise, for example.
There is ample experience sharing and information available on the Internet to set proper expectations for benefits and minor adverse effects if too much is consumed by accident. Consequently, I have never experienced a bad effect from it. According to reports, adverse effects are minor and resolve in a few hours. On a positive note, the minor side effects of over consumption serve the purpose of discouraging attempts to abuse it. I feel more confident that I am not damaging my heart and kidneys from using it, than I was when I took ibuprofen. Since I have been drinking kratom tea a few times a week, I have not had any colds or allergy flare-ups either. I see my doctor regularly, and my labs are consistently in the normal ranges.
I encourage kratom to be studied in regards to its nutritional analysis, as I suspect it to be as beneficial as other green vegetables such as kale or spirulina. In addition to its nutritional benefits, it appears to have minor energizing and pain relieving effects similarly to coffee. A study to investigate its safe use would provide the scientific justification of what tens of thousands of users over hundreds of years already know. 
Kratom has the potential to be a great benefit to society. It helps people avoid dangerous prescriptions and expensive doctor visits. This relieves pressure on the health care system and lowers insurance costs for all of us. Please do not take it off the market because of a few unscrupulous marketers and their outrageous claims of a legal high that alarm the authorities and encourage abuse by the ignorant. Please do not punish the large number of people who would benefit from this herb because of the misuse by a few.

documents.commentText: As a chronic pain sufferer with Fibromyalgia, degenerative disc disease, arthritis, spinal stenosis cervical stenosis and accompanying neuropathy, I was prescribed pain meds through pain management doctors and physiatrics doctors, in conjunction with physical therapy and Pool therapy. Those medications and treatments along with my willingness to follow medical advice and do my part to mitigate my own circumstances make it possible to function and be as active as I can. When I moved to Idaho it took quite a while for my medical records to arrive from California and because of the stricter laws,, doctors would not prescribe my pain meds without seeing the MRI and other proof of my conditions. I was thrown into a painful withdrawal process and suffered through that and all of the pain that are part of my condition s. In desperation, i researched natural cures for pain and found out about kratom and met with a botanical supplier who recommended a specific type of kratom to alleviate my pain and my discomfort from sudden cessation of long-term opiate use. It was like a miracle within minutes of my first dose and I truly don't know how I'd have managed without it, as I am responsible for the care of my grandson who was two years old at the time. I now use kratom regularly instead of prescription meds and I can even go days without it when I am not in a flare or having intense pain. This is how I know there is no accompanying addiction with kratom. I could. Or do that with opiates, as your body develops physical dependence even when taken as prescribed. I feel it was because kratom was legal and available without having to see a doctor that my suffering ended and it would be a terrible mistake to regulate this natural remedy. Nature has provided an answer for when she betrays our bodies. Please keep kratom legal and available to all of us. Thank you Christina DeVonne Alves

documents.commentText: I am a Naturopathic physician.  I first heard of Kratom at an Herbal medicine conference where itwas discussec in a segment on pain management.  I discussed the herb with a number of patients.  My experiance was that by taking very moderate doses, the patients were able to decrease pain levels and function in their daily activities.  There was no disorientation, drowsiness or cognitive dysfunction. documents.commentText:
This is an addendum (addition) to my first comment ID: DEA-2016-0015-4081. I am making this addition because it has only recently come to our attention that it seems the DEA is not being completely forthcoming when faced with a freedom of information request. Investigative reporter Anthony Roberts of MUCKROCK has requested all information on Kratom including any emails from FDA, DEA and pharma companies, and very specific sections of the intent to schedule, footnotes 17 and 18, 22. This information that the DEA is withholding is critical to the public mounting an offensive against such claims. It seems completely INAPPROPRIATE not to release all information, it's not like Kratom is a national security risk that warrants redacted documents or restrictions in releasing something?

These are his 2 most important articles, SO WHAT ARE YOU HIDING DEA?

https://www.muckrock.com/search/?q=kratom

https://medium.com/@anthonyroberts/dea-balks-at-latest-kratom-foia-refuses-to-provide-further-information-d725dc0ce170#.m4enfgn7k

It's in this 2nd one where the below excerpts are taken from. 

"On August 30th, 2016, the DEA filed a notice of intent to temporarily designate Kratom (specifically its alkaloids mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine) as a schedule 1 drug. That notice listed 33 footnotes/references, but the actual references themselves were not included in the document itself.
Later that day, I filed a Freedom of Information Act (FOIA) request for all of the data and documents referenced in the 33 footnotes. Specifically, this is what I asked for:
"I am seeking copies of all documents referenced in the 33 footnotes contained within the DEA's recently published notice of intent to temporarily place Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine into Schedule I...
This is a fairly straightforward request. The DEA wants to make this stuff illegal, and I want the public to have access to the same information as the DEA. Tens of thousands of people signed the petition to keep kratom legal (over 100k in the first week), and as a result, the DEA opened up a comment period for the public to respond. But in order to respond fully, we need to know what we are responding to. This means we need to see the information referenced in their footnotes, which is the evidence they're relying on to ban kratom.
The public has a right to see these documents.
In the case of some of the footnotes, I was asking for specific data they'd collected (from footnote (17 and 18, for example):
"...abuse of kratom/mitragynine[17] were analyzed by Federal, State, and local forensic laboratories.[18] According to data from the System to Retrieve Information from Drug Evidence (STRIDE) and STARLiMS (a web-based, commercial laboratory information management system), from January 2006 through March 2016, there were 293 records for kratom and/or mitragynine..."
In other words, I was asking for the actual data references in footnotes 17 & 18, respectively, i.e. if there are 293 records on kratom abuse from January 2006 through March 2016, and those records were considered when the DEA attempted to schedule kratom, then the public should be able to inspect them.
This is the most basic logic: in order for the public to respond (and build a case against the ban), we must have access to the same data as the DEA. This is why, in court, the plaintiff (or prosecution) is required by law to provide the defense with all of the evidence they're using to make their case.
But the DEA has refused to provide us with their evidence. In fact, they provided absolutely none of the data they referenced. Instead, they provided documents that were already available (FDA press releases, copies of federal laws and regulations, etc...), none of which I didn't already have a copy of; none of the ones that provide evidence that supports the DEA's attempt to ban kratom."

Did you hear that 2nd to last sentence THEY HAVE PROVIDED ABSOLUTELY NONE OF THE DATA THEY REFERENCED

Emails between FDA,DEA,Pharma NEITHER CONFIRMED OR DENIED ANY EXIST?

Footnote 22 emails between inter and intra agency memorandums which clearly exist NOPE NOT GETTING THEM?

THIS KIND OF BEHAVIOR IS NOT ACCEPTABLE TO THE CITIZENS OF THE UNITED STATES. 

PROVIDE US WITH YOUR FOOTNOTES........PROVIDE US WITH YOUR DATA......what are we supposed to take your word for it.......UNACCEPTABLE. 


It's because this substance is NOT AT ALL as dangerous as the FDA and DEA make it out to be. 
THIS SUBSTANCE IS SOCIALLY ACCEPTABLE AND IS USED TO MAKE PEOPLES LIVES BETTER!!!!!!!!!!!!

Over 7100 comments and 95-97% positive. The people and the science have spoken LEAVE IT ALONE AND REGULATE IT, TAX IT,.........ALL EVIDENCE POINTS TO THIS HAVING THE POTENTIAL TO BE MORE SOCIALLY ACCEPTABLE THAN ANY OTHER CURRENTLY LEGAL SUBSTANCE OUT THERE...alcohol, nicotine, even caffeine AND not to mention prescription opioids, and many more,most of which are infinitely more dangerous than Kratom. 

HEAR OUR PLEA'S!!!

STOP THIS INSANE WAR ON DRUGS.

I discovered Kratom nearly four years ago. I consider it a miracle tea, which has helped me manage chronic pain and depression. I safely and responsibly consume kratom tea 1-2x per week to avoid narcotic pain medications and overly sedating prescription muscle relaxers.

Sadly, kratom has recently been miscategorized and erroneously compared to dangerous street drugs like heroin. The recently publicized overdose numbers are grossly misstated. The bulk of the deaths attributed to kratom have included a variety of other more dangerous substances that are more likely to have been responsible.

The effect of kratom is quite simply an energizing uplift and general feeling of well being. I'd compare it to a less jittery coffee sensation with the added benefit of an improved, positive mood, focus and enhanced sense of motivation. This is by no means a plant that makes you "high," as recent media reports would lead many to believe.

Hastily moving this supplement to Schedule 1 would have devastating effects on a large community of users, who currently lead productive, normal lives thanks of kratom.

As a government organization whose primary objective it is to protect individuals and communities, it would be irresponsible to ban kratom and drive it underground to a more dangerous black market.

I really appreciate your organization's willingness to factor in public opinion about kratom before making any uniformed decisions to schedule it as a dangerous drug.

Thank you for your consideration.

To whom it may concern,
I am writing in reference to the DEA's decision to place Kratom on the schedule 1 list. I appreciate your time and effort in reading the many responses from people like me who use Kratom regularly to help deal with the many health issues we face. 
I was diagnosed with fibromyalgia in 2002. I have been on every medication used to treat the symptoms of fibro and many off label to try to get relief from this horrible neurological condition that affects the muscles, ligaments and every other part of my body. From Paxil to presently prescribed opiates, I've not found relief. They'll make me feel drowsy, but don't help with the pain and exhaustion that I go through everyday. You may have heard fibromyalgia is very hard to treat. 
About two years ago, I was on a Facebook group for fibromyalgia sufferers and someone mentioned Kratom. They said it was a plant from the coffee family and was not dangerous like opiates are. As you're well aware, opiate use and abuse is at an all time high across our great nation. Heroin and prescription pills are killing people everyday. I've personally lost two family members to opiate abuse. I did not want to become a statistic or memory to my daughter. 
I am one who has always been proactive in my healthcare. I researched Kratom for months before I finally found the American Kratom Association website. The group helped me find a Facebook group and there I found a vendor who has a safe and lab tested for safety product. My first time using Kratom still causes me to tear up. For the first time since I was a teenager, I felt like that strong man with his hands clawing into my upper back and shoulders had released me! There was no high, no woogly feeling, no spaciness; just a relaxation that came over my body. I cry everytime I think of it because I finally found something to help give me a break from the horrible pain I've felt most of my life! 
I learned about the different strains of Kratom, and found there was also one that helped people like me get energy. I tried it along with the strain for pain relief and I could clean my house! I could live!  All my daughter's life, I spent on the couch, curled up in pain. My pain costed her a childhood she could have had, had I known about kratom. As much as I tried to work 45+ hours a week, and be a good mother, I was just too exhausted to do much of anything else when I picked her up from daycare. 
Kratom has given me life! Literally life! My now 24 year old daughter and I can go shopping, and spend the whole day! Yes. I am exhausted and achy the next few days, but at least I can do it! 
Please take the comments of people who use this natural botanical in to consideration before you take it away. With the dangers we all face with opiates, this plant could be a saving grace for the millions dealing with pain and opiate abuse. 
Thank you for your time. 

Peggy Hall

Dear Sir or Madam,

I have never signed any kind of petition or written to any government agency prior to today. But I feel the subject of keeping Kratom legal is extremely important.  I feel that the driving force behind the effort to classify Kratom as a Schedule I drug is misguided and ill informed. Kratom is not the dangerous street drug that some are trying to claim. For years, my doctors readily prescribed opiates to which I, like so many became addicted. When the rules were changed a few years back and the belt was tightened on prescriptions and doctors cut people off on their scripts, when drugs like Lortab were discontinued, the result was the creation of many heroin addicts and criminals. So many of us cannot afford to put life on hold and go to detox and rehab. Kratom makes it possible to work and be productive while healing from addiction. Kratom is a Godsend, not a danger.

Thousands of people use this plant safely and responsibly every day. It literally saves lives. Please don't take that lifeline away from those who cannot or choose not to use proven dangerous and addictive pharmaceuticals to treat their ailments. The pharmaceutical companies have enough victims as it is. Don't force us to be slaves to those companies and the addictions they create.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern : 
I was deeply saddened to find out about the DEA wanting to make Kratom a Schedule 1 substance.  
I suffer from two difficult medical issues : Crohn's Disease and Avascular Necrosis of the hip joint, which was a result of being on the medication Prednisone.  
Both are issues within which I can manage to function, but I am in mild to moderate pain 24 hours a day.  
Discovering kratom has drastically improved my quality of life.  It is a powerful plant, and I think it would extremely beneficial to research it and look for opportunities to incorporate it into modern holistic medicine. 
Placing it in the same class as heroin is insane, and deeply misinformed.  
I do think you can call it a drug, in the same way that you can call coffee a drug (kratom is iin fact a member of the coffee family), but it is discrimination pure & simple to try to make kratom illegal while far more dangerous drugs like alcohol and tobacco are still legal and socially accepted.
I know that kratom can be used to assist in withdrawal from heroin and prescription opiates (while I don't have personal experience with this, I have a handful of close friends who do), and I know there has been a huge spike in prescription opiate abuse among the public recently, which often leads to street drugs, crime, poverty, and other destructive societal issues.  So why ban a harmless plant that can assist in breaking these cycles of addiction?  My  belief is that pharmaceutical companies are making millions off the suffering of prescription opiate users (such drugs are prescribed with alarming frequency and little warning as to the dangers), and "Big Pharma" doesn't want anything interfering with that. 
I beg you to turn your attention to where the real dangers are and away from kratom.  
Thank you for listening. 
SIncerely,
Dena E. Goldsmith

documents.commentText:
Thank you for taking the time to review this comment.  I am an educated, relatively healthy, 61 year old woman living in New England. I first read of Kratom almost one year ago.  I was interested in it because of the claim that it relieved depression and arthritic pain, of which I have both. While I had no experience buying herbs, I had plenty of experience with prescription anti-depression drugs.  Through the many years of taking different anti-depressants, my mood and depression were not relieved in any long-term or satisfactory way.  This is what lead me to try Kratom.  

After trying Kratom, I was surprised to find it had a mild, though distinctive effect, on my chronic depression, as well as an analgesic effect on my arthritis.  I was very pleased to experience this mild though effective herb! What is so terrific about Kratom is it's very gentleness. Does that make it ineffective? Absolutely not. It's effects are just enough to relieve depression and pain, but not enough to make you feel medicated, anxious, sedated, or to be used as a party drug. 

Please keep Kratom LEGAL!!  Do not give in to the fear and paranoia that controls politics. Let us move forward with science, not stay in the paranoia of our current regressive mind-set that fears all things that actually can improve, though in a small way, many people's lives.

documents.commentText:
Please reconsider this schedule 1 classification. It seems that there is some evidence that kratum might have been involved with some few deaths, but the usage numbers are unknown. There are anecdotes that it is helpful to people. 

I'm not a scientist, but I'm a fan of the process. It seems to me that there is hardly any more evidence than *none* that this substance is either helpful or harmful, and very little prior probability that it will be as harmful as, say, alcohol. 

There's no evidence of anything, and schedule 1 will severely retard the collection of any more. Please don't make this another marijuana situation. If real evidence becomes available that it is harmful, it could be banned. Until then, all we have are anecdotes, and they seem favorable on balance. 

Thank you for your time.

I was given a combination of opioid pain medication and chiropractic care. This was a huge help for my pain, however I choose to discontinue the opioids, as I did not want to take them long term. My Dr. initially prescribed me an opioid treatment, however he was unable to continue due to the negative stigma that has surrounded opioids, in my area. I was devastated, and the pain came back. Again, I could no longer hold my son.

I found out about Kratom and decided to try it. To my surprise, it was the most effective treatment yet. I could carry my son again and I no longer needed to take opioid medicines or visit the chiropractor. My second son is due to be born this Wednesday. Please consider my story and keep Kratom as a legal supplement for responsible and safe adults, like myself. I would hate to go back to a world of pain where I am unable to love and hold my children.

documents.commentText:
After a horrible motorcycle crash in 2006 that nearly ended my life and left me permanently disabled, I was prescribed almost every opioid in the pharmacopeia for my chronic pain, and always had my dosages increased when my pain increased. Doctors would throw more opiates at my pain, and as a result, I spent three years caught in a cycle of bed, to recliner, to bed,  a virtual zombie, absent from the life of my family. In 2009 I decided I'd had enough, and went to rehab to get off the opioids and find a better way to manage my pain that did not require me to surrender to somnolence. I was switched to Suboxone, which provided excellent pain relief (though it's usage as a pain control modality remains an off-label use to date, despite a proven track record in the rest of the world) without a clouded sensorium, but which was a tier 4 drug in my insurance plan, so it cost me $200 a month, which escalated to $300 a month in 2010, at which time my doctor switched me to generic Buprenorphine to save me some money, though it still cost me $120 a month. Still, it provided great pain relief, so I continued taking it until two months ago. Recent changes in Georgia law required me to move from seeing my doctor every 90 days, to seeing him every 30 days for buprenorphine, which added another $170 a month in office visit copays, along with urinalysis every other visit, though I have never used illegal or street drugs, and have never taken a prescribed medication in a manner inconsistent with my prescription. I decided to wean myself from buprenorphine. The thing nobody ever told me was how long the withdrawal period would be for buprenorphine as opposed to a traditional opiate withdrawal of a few days. Despite a very gradual taper, and ceasing taking buprenorphine only when my daily dose was down to .5 mg, the withdrawal was horrible. I ached everywhere, and I felt horrible. 

A friend recommended making a weak tea by boiling the dried, chopped leaves of the mitrogyna speciosa bush/plant. I obtained some leaves from a reputable vendor with a well-documented reputation for quality, and I made a decoction using approximately 4 ounces of dried Kratom boiled in a gallon of water for fifteen minutes. After the mixture cooled, I strained the leaves through a sieve and pressed the retained liquid through the sieve to extract all the liquid. I discarded the boiled leaves, sweetened the liquid with organic honey, and mixed it in a 50/50 ratio with regular iced tea. I started out with 4 ounces of liquid mixture, but had to gradually increase my quantity to 12 ounces before feeling any effect. When I did finally feel an effect, I did not experience any clouding of my sensorium, nor did I feel any increased alertness. I only experienced two effects from drinking my Kratom tea:  My withdrawal symptoms completely subsided, and my chronic pain was reduced to the same level I experienced when taking buprenorphine. There is no discernible "high", and no likability with Kratom tea. I drink my 12 ounces, and for eight to ten hours I am not only pain free, I am able to participate in life and raise my son without depending on pills, prescriptions, doctors or changing regulations. The real value of kratom is that it makes real relief available to the average citizen. As far as the risks associated with its use, I can find only seven anecdotal tales of reported harm to people using Kratom, and all of those were people using it for recreational purposes and taking it to excess. Even the National Institutes of Health's Liver Toxicity database contains only ONE documented case of liver damage attributable to recreational usage taken to excess. A similar search for acetaminophen returns over five-thousand cases of hepatotoxicity in a single year. Clearly a bottle of Tylenol is more dangerous to the average American than Kratom. 

I urge the DEA and the FDA to allow Kratom to continue to be sold, possessed and used in states where it has not already been declared illegal. A simple comparison of the risks versus the benefits would clearly show that a great many more people are helped rather than hurt by the effects of responsible Kratom use. In this regard, Kratom is no different than coffee, cigarettes or alcohol. I agree it should not be legal for minors to use, possess or purchase Kratom, because their lack of discretion might potentiate irresponsible use, even though Kratom is in one way a self-limiting drug, as excessive consumption simply makes the user vomit, removing the Kratom from their stomach and forestalling any serious adverse events. Please do not deny me and every responsible user of Kratom the freedom from pain and pharmaceuticals we currently enjoy through legal and responsible consumption of this overwhelmingly helpful plant, which is in reality a close cousin of coffee, which has been responsibly consumed and enjoyed for its effect for centuries, just as Kratom has throughout the world. 

Thank you for reviewing my commentary.

Just as many states has legalized marijuana for both medical and recreational use the DEA should back away from this action of putting Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine into Schedule I class of drug.

documents.commentText:
My name is Joshua Sturm. I'm a thirty-one year old New Yorker and CNC programmer/machinist. I graduated in 2003 and went straight into the trade. Minus a brief layoff period I have been working for the same shop ever since. I would just like to say how kratom has changed my life and what it was like without it.

I used to love my job when I first started machining. I had begun training back in high school in a vocational class. There is still a ton I can learn after thirteen years but after about ten it started to take a toll on me. The environment I work in is loud, repetitive, and tedious. I started out feeling down or grumpy depending on what day it was. Over time it got to the point that I was lashing out at coworkers.  A few years ago I had decided to seek professional help due to stress and anxiety. In early 2014 I decided to try anti-depressants and stuck with it for a couple months. I didn't like the way it made me feel at all or the side effects. The doctor recommended trying other drugs and groups of inhibitors so I did. I went through a number of different pills over the coarse of the next year or so. The way they changed me and the withdraw I had when I stopped taking them was frightening to me. After that I decided I might just be better off with a career change. It's hard to walk away from a well paying job when you worked your way up for over a decade. One of my life goals was to get my own place. I felt like such a pathetic person for wanting to give up on something that so many people around me would be proud to have. It also seemed ignorant considering I only have a high school education. It was around December 2014 when a friend recommended I try kratom. I was very reluctant at first and had a lot of questions. The worst part is most of the information you can find about it is by reading forums on the internet!!! Well I have always double, triple, and quadruple checked peoples opinions when it comes to sources like that. Even though my resolve was just about tapped out I wasn't about to resort to something I would regret. It turns out a large percentage of people who had taken it had only positive things to say so I tried two 750mg capsules. It made me feel like all my anxiety just vanished. The best way I can describe it is I felt like I was having a really good day. It was the exact thing I had been searching for the whole time. As time went on I continued to use it daily and also built up a tolerance fairly quick. Once I got to about six grams a day I started to get concerned. I realized there is no doctor telling what is okay and how much is too much. I knew from my reading that six grams is about average so I stayed right there for the time being. It was working so well for me I was putting in overtime at the shop and everyone around me got a little relief as well. In June of 2015 I finally bought my first house!! It's a beautiful little place on lake Ontario. I lived happily this way in my new home for months until me and my girlfriend started arguing about money. I slowly started increasing the amount I would take little by little until I realized if I bought more I couldn't pay my mortgage. This is the first time I had stopped taking kratom in more than six months. Over the coarse of the next week I felt sore, tired, and irritable. It wasn't so much I couldn't do my job though. After the first week I was back to normal and decided to give it a little time. Ever since then I have stuck with a routine to avoid budget problems and discomfort. I don't believe it's the kind of thing you can abuse too much because you build up a tolerance very fast. I'm also perfectly happy with my lower dosage. I noticed the higher it got the more ill effects came along with it. It was kind of like coffee in the way that if you drink too much you just get jittery and realize it's just not benefiting you anymore. 

The only reason I am writing this today is because I feel that kratom can be more safe than any prescription pill. I learned on my own how it effects me but it doesn't have to be that way. It should be embraced not shunned. I understand the efforts of the people who have lost loved ones and want to find the cause. I think the evidence that it can be safe speaks for itself but also more evidence is obviously needed.

documents.commentText:
Hello,

I am a 51 year old single father of my 14 year old son. I have been an electrician for over 25 years. Eleven years ago I started having back and neck pain as well as leg and hand weakness. I went to a doctor and found out I was having severe nerve compression in my cervical and lumbar spinal cord areas.
I was too busy trying to build a business and couldn't afford to take time off to heal from the surgeries and I was always taught you just have keep going and no whining, everyone has problems.

By 2012 my symptoms were so bad I couldn't go on like this anymore. I went back to the doctor and found out the problem had worsened to the point where I could die if I fell. I was having accidents from falling and my arms and legs were getting so weak that I could hardly make it through the day anymore without a lot of issues.

I have had several spinal surgeries that have left me partially disabled as a result of severe and permanent spinal cord damage and in addition to six laminectomies, a cord tumor was excised as well.

After surgeries I was left with even more severe back pain that makes it very difficult to walk. In addition I have been losing function in both hands making it impossible to use tools or do basic simple daily tasks we all take for granted.

My neurologist and neurosurgeon had been treating my symptoms with narcotic medications for years to help with the pain and spasticity. I was having to deal with awful side effects and in addition was developing symptoms of situational depression. I was not dealing well with what was happening to me. The drugs were making me sick and I was really having a difficult time with where my life was heading.

A friend told me about a dietary supplement called kratom. This is a natural herbal tea like leaf that helps me live my life without having to rely on chemicals prescribed by a doctor. I have gone from using a handful of pills everyday to a minimal amount. My 30 day oxycodone prescription now lasts me more than ten weeks. I no longer take fentanyl, butrans, gabapentin,diazepam and antidepressants. I no longer have to take pills to help relieve the symptoms caused by the other pills.

I have been taking kratom daily for the past three years and have been able to manage my pain, depression and anxiety symptoms without pills. There are no side effects, I am not addicted to it, I have zero withdrawal symptoms if I don't take it every day. I can function as a productive member of society without putting synthesized chemicals into my body.

I am able to feel better without drugs and the horrible side effects they were causing me. If there was truly any kind of risk to my health or well being, believe me I would not be taking kratom. I do not use alcohol, tobacco or illegal drugs. I live a healthy lifestyle and pay close attention to my diet and I exercise every day.

I should be able to feel better without the government telling me I have to use a pharmaceutical drug instead of a natural herbal supplement. I should have the right to make my own decisions as a citizen of the USA. This is a free country and I feel the FDA and DEA are not taking my freedoms into consideration. This ban is unconstitutional and an infringement of my rights. I feel like I have a right to be heard and I strongly oppose this ban. I sincerely appreciate you giving me this opportunity to express myself.

The government is supposed to work for me and not against me. This decision would adversely affect the lives of millions of people just like me. There is far more proof that suggests kratom is safe. I have done a lot of research over the past couple months regarding kratom and I see that the opponents of kratom have provided false and baseless comments that do not tell the truth. It is obvious there are people more concerned with money than health. This is absurd and an absolute abuse of power and should not be allowed to continue.

Please consider the results of a full and fair investigation from experts who will prove there is no imminent risk to responsible citizens and their health.

Thank you.

Sincerely,

Cory A.W. Johnson

documents.commentText:
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it. 
If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.

Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.

Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.

Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.

Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.


The War on Drugs has had a catastrophic impact on the trust between law enforcement and the communities they serve. We need to restore that trust, and allowing for research and regulation of drugs like kratom will be a significant step.

I believe that Kratom dose not need to be on any scheduleing. because there is not sufficient evidence that it is an imminent public health threat.

www.trevena.com/TRV130-how-it-works.php

So that YOU Rosenberg can get FAT kick backs from them by cornering the market on reaserch and development. I find this reasoning  to be a complete disgrace to the American people 

At most there needs to be.
 age limit on the purchaseing of Kratom  (21) years old
 a law defining how labeling should be made 
 large penalties to those who do not fallow labeling laws

I believe the labeling should be similar to honey 
www.honey.com/honey-industry/honey-testing-and-regulations/honey-labeling/

LABELS MUST COMMUNICATE THE FOLLOWING:
The "Common" Name of the Product
The word "kratom" must be visible on the label. The name of a plant or strains may be used if it is the primary floral source. Kratom must be labeled with its common or usual name on the front of your package. (i.e. "Kratom" or " Maeng Da Kratom")

Net Weight
The net weight of your product (excluding packaging), both in pounds/ounces and in metric weight (g) must be included in the lower third of your front label panel in easy-to-read type. (i.e. Net Wt. 16 oz. (454 g)) When determining net weight, use the government conversion factor of 1 ounce (oz) = 28.3495 grams or 1 pound (lb.) = 453.592 grams. Round after making the calculation - not before. Use no more than three digits after the decimal point on the package. One may round down the final weight to avoid overstating the contents. When rounding, use typical mathematical rounding rules.

Ingredients
Single ingredient products (such as Kratom) do not have to name that single ingredient when already used in the common or usual name on the front panel. However, if there are ingredients other than Kratom, you must list them in an ingredient statement. Some exceptions are spices, flavorings and incidental additives (additives which have no functional role and with minimal presence in the finished product) which have special rules.

The type size for ingredient listings must be no less than 1/16th inch as measured by the small letter "o" or by the large letter "O" if all caps are used in the declaration. There are exemptions that allow smaller type sizes for small packages.



Contact Information
The label must let consumers know who put the product on the market and how to contact that person. The name and the address of the manufacturer, packer or distributor of a packaged food product are required to appear on the label of the packaged food. This information, sometimes referred to as the "signature line," must appear on the front label panel or the information panel. If space permits, include full address and telephone number. The information must be in a type size that is at least 1/16th inch tall.

documents.commentText:
As a pharmacist I see great potential for kratom as an over the counter product for pain relief. In fact, I could see pharmacists playing a major role in educating how to responsibly utilize Kratom. 

I practice in Missouri and there is an opioid epidemic in this state that is destroying lives. The scope of the problem is clearly larger than the state of Missouri but I can only speak to what I have seen. Prescription opiates and heroin have become interchangeable. If addicts can not obtain one, they obtain the other. It is a public health crisis. I know many people who have utilized kratom and it has changed their lives. 

Studies and anecdotal evidence indicate that yes, kratom has the potential to become habit forming but it does not compare to the destructive and addictive behavior of aforementioned prescription and heroin abuse. This does not mean it needs to become a schedule I narcotic. This line of thinking will get us nowhere in society. Alcohol and nicotine are extremely unhealthy when used in excess but because of the profit they generate and their long term use in our society we for the most part let them slide, even though they have enormous impacts on healthcare cost every year. Overheating and the obesity epidemic are very similar. As a healthcare professional it seems ridiculous to me to consider banning kratom. In that case alcohol, nicotine, and fast food should be banned as well.

Lastly, I suspect this "ban" was largely pushed/encouraged by pharmaceutical companies. It is hurting their profit margins. Also, rescheduling it as a schedule II and letting pharmaceutical companies reap the profits is a terrible idea. There are thousands of people in this country that benefit from kratom. Taking it away will cause many of them to revert back to more dangerous drugs and behavior. 

I took an oath when I became a pharmacist and it as is follows:

"I promise to devote myself to a lifetime of service to others through the profession of pharmacy. In fulfilling this vow:

I will consider the welfare of humanity and relief of suffering my primary concerns.
I will apply my knowledge, experience, and skills to the best of my ability to assure optimal outcomes for my patients.
I will respect and protect all personal and health information entrusted to me.
I will accept the lifelong obligation to improve my professional knowledge and competence.
I will hold myself and my colleagues to the highest principles of our profession's moral, ethical and legal conduct.
I will embrace and advocate changes that improve patient care.
I will utilize my knowledge, skills, experiences, and values to prepare the next generation of pharmacists.
I take these vows voluntarily with the full realization of the responsibility with which I am entrusted by the public."

I strongly suggest taking some of those points into consideration when debating how to handle this issue. Let healthcare professionals work with the public and allow them to utilize this wonderful plant to do good. Don't make the same mistake that's been made time and time again. Thank you for reading.

-Derek Barker, PharmD

documents.commentText:
Ah youth! I did rather extreme sports right up until middle age and never got hurt. Then a gardening accident (standing up suddenly after weeding for hours) followed by an embarrassing yoga accident did me in. Go figure! I was in severe pain for well over a year as arthritis set in and all my dreams of an active retirement turned to dust along with my joints.

The one bright spot in this dismal scenario was my discovery of kratom, the most amazing herb on the planet for effective pain relief, lack of side effects, and safety. Now there are many varieties of kratom, so let me make it clear that my only experience is with red vein horned kratom and red vein Borneo which were recommended for pain relief.  I can't speak to the effects of other varieties.

Once you receive your packet, you will notice that it looks like tea, which, I guess, is what it is.  Unfortunately, it's pretty awful tasting tea, but I will share with you my method for getting it down painlessly.  But first, we need some ground rules to prevent overindulgence and unhappy effects.

I just had two ground rules: "You only take this stuff if you wake up in the night in pain and can't get back to sleep. Also, you are limited to one level teaspoon in your tea."  I'm not saying this form and amount of kratom will get you back to sleep but you won't care because you will be pain free and feel relaxed and rested up to four hours later.

Okay, if these are your ground rules, you are going to need to be prepared since you will be groggy should you wake up in the night in pain.  Get a one cup jar with a lid and place one teaspoon of dry kratom tea 
inside.  Have a thermos or Contigo mug handy, full of the most delicious tea you can find.  Hibiscus mint tea sweetened with a little stevia works great.  Now, all you have to do is pour one quarter to one third cup of tea into the jar containing one teaspoon of red vein kratom, screw on the lid, and shake.  

Alternate taking a swig of the kratom tea with taking a swig of the plain tea and, after  four or five gulps, you'll have it down with no problem.  Now lie down and relax.  This will take about fifteen minutes. After all, you haven't been injected or taken an IV; it has to get through your stomach.

The first thing you will notice is the absence of pain.  This is likely to amaze you, because you will not notice any other changes.  It's not like marijuana.  You won't feel stoned or in any way out of control. There's just no pain. 

The second thing you will notice, after a few more minutes, is a feeling of being embraced in a state of utter peace.  Okay, that may sound a little like an opioid experience and, I admit, you will want it to last because there is no thought involved, just drifting in a universe where nothing seems to be wrong.  

The next stage is one of free association.  It's sort of like a waking dream, but you are totally in control if you want to be. It's nothing at all like hallucinating.  Rather, it's what you experience every night right before sleep, but in this case, it lasts much longer.

The only negative experience I have had the next morning is an occasional  slight headache which goes away as soon as I start moving about and have something to eat.  Then again, it may have just been seasonal allergies.  

I have never gone beyond one teaspoon which has continued to do the trick, providing complete pain relief.  You may read about people doing three teaspoons, but you are much less likely to develop tolerance (need 
more to get the same effect) if you stick to one teaspoon.  

Now go sign any online petitions that are out there to keep kratom legal.  This is your safest bet for effective, safe, relief from pain if you stick to your wise ground rules.

documents.commentText:
Schedule I is too harsh a level of regulation for these compounds.

Codeine itself, which could be called similar in many ways, is only Schedule II; combined with aspirin or paracetamol, codeine only rates Schedule III restriction. In cough syrups, codeine can be regulated as a Schedule V substance.

The pharmacology of Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine when administered as kratom is worth more study and a reasoned, considered scheduling. When you schedule these compounds, please consider the lives of people with fibromyalgia and other conditions who face chronic pain. Please consider how restricting kratom would affect the quality of their everyday lives.

I have been an advocate of natural health and remedies for almost 20 years.    Having used and explored several hundred different herbs, I can say with confidence and sincerity that Kratom is one of the safest herbs I have used with a wide range applications. 

While mostly used for safe and non-addictive pain management, it is also successful in treating depression and anxiety. After finding no success with pharmaceutical or natural  remedies for my depression and anxiety, I discovered Kratom which I have been using for the last 3 years.  It is not only effective, there are literally no side affects and I have not experienced any kind of tolerance. Therefore I have been using the same amount daily without the need to increase quantity for 3 years now.  I found it much more effective than St. Johns Wort - a well known and effective treatment for depression. I personally know of 3 other people who use it for the same purpose with equal success. 

In addition to relieving anxiety and depression, it also reduces pain in my body -  I no longer need to take pain medication for a spine condition that I have had or over 15 years. Prior to discovering Kratom I was depressed and in pain all the time. Kratom has quite literally saved my life and given me a quality of life I could have never imagined prior. I personally know of 2 other people who regularly use Kratom for pain relief with great success and zero negative side effects. 

I beg you to consider all the benefits of this plant and the many, many people who have been helped and who share a similar story to my own.  Taking it away and making it illegal will undoubtedly only create more criminality as honest and good people will be forced to break the law to seek a safe treatment for their ailments.  Do we really need a war on a safe and effective herb? I hope not.

documents.commentText:
Greetings,

I write now to express my sincere opposition to kratom being categorized as a Schedule 1 drug.

As an emergency and primary care physician, I am in a position to have carefully weighed the pros and cons of this very important and potentially dvery harmful decision.

Kratom has been used for centuries as a practical and safe way to improve function in those who suffer from chronic debilitating pain. Many patients are also discovering the value of kratom in decreasing or eliminating their dependence on prescription pain medications.

The pharmaceutical industry has a vested interest in debunking methods of pain management which do not further its own agenda. I certainly hope the influence of corporate pharmaceutical lobbyists is not a factor in the DEA's decision making process. No doubt big pharma is chomping at the bit to make kratom "their own", furthering their already astronomical profits, at the expense of the health and wellbeing of the American people.

The fact that the number of poison center calls regarding kratom has rapidly increased in no way translates to a need to schedule this plant. It merely suggests more people are discovering it's value and wishing to gain further information. 

The DEA loses credibility when it fails to responsibly assess it's decisions in a manner consistent with good science. Evidence of harm from this plant is so vastly outweighed by innumerable reports of its efficacy. If for no other reason than reducing prescription drug abuse, the DEA might please consider leaving well enough alone! The use of plants to improve the human condition began thousands of years ago, and will continue. 

Has the DEA still not acknowledged the failure of the "War on Drugs"? Kratom has not demonstrated sufficient harm in a significant number of people to warrant efforts to eradicate it's use. These efforts will result only in harm by denying legal access to many thousands of legitimate safe, responsible users who deserve the freedom to choose. 

Are there no potential risks to kratom remaining available without criminalization? Of course not! But until the unlikely day that it's use is shown to harm more people than it helps, it is unjustified and irresponsible to make it a controlled substance in an era when there are so many bigger fish to fry.

As a physician, a patient, and an American, I implore the DEA to more carefully evaluate the evidence (or lack thereof) and allow kratom to be used without criminalization.

I sincerely appreciate the DEA's recent decision to allow discussion of this matter. 

With Thanks and Respect,

Ely Zaslow MD

I'm a thirty year old medical biller living in Montclair, NJ. My job requires me to be up pretty early in the morning, so shaking off the sleepy feeling can be tough. As I've never been a fan of coffee or tea I've always been on the lookout for something that could perk me up without resorting to energy drinks. Kratom has been perfect for me. documents.commentText:
Hello,

My name is Kristoffer Jones. I have used the plant mirtrygenine speciosa, also known as kratom, for approximately 4 years.  I am a 34 year old resident of Texas, and work in commercial pest control. I make $60k/yr currently, and have been one of the top ten employees for the Texas district of our company for 6 months running. I save a large portion of my paycheck each period, because my wife and I are saving for a house. In every way, my life has become better since I began using kratom.

I had a troubled childhood, and was prescribed antidepressants from the age of ten on. That is normal for some reason nowadays, but at that time it was unheard of. I had terrible anxiety, anger, and a lack of self esteem and self control.  I got into drugs and eventually ended up with a drug possession charge at 18, for a joint found during a traffic stop.  I was a good kid, but a loser.

That followed me, and i had to work menial jobs and pay my way through community college on my own dime. Heading to work one day, pulling out of the driveway onto a highway,  my father and I were rearended by an SUV going 75mph.  We might have been going 5mph.  The vehicle rolled three times and the cab was crushed in. My father was wearing his seat belt,  and ended up with a brain injury. I wasn't , because I had a bad habit of buckling up as we started down the hill . I was thrown violently around in the vehicle but miraculously I wasnt thrown from the vehicle. My father was determined to be at fault because he was accelerating up to speed on the shoulder. Neither of us had insurance, so I opted to not be taken to the hospital with him. I knew i was in pain, but compared to my father i thought it was fine. I wasn't.  My back and shoulder have never been the same. 

I turned to opiates. It helped with the pain and also made me a happier person when I had my drugs. I wasted most of my twenties in this cycle of relapse, depression,  poverty.  I wanted out  

I did exhaustive research. Methadone and suboxone are supposed to be the answer. They arent.  We used to LOOK for those on the street.  They make you a slobbering mess and if you didn't have them you went through worse detox than morphine.  It's longer and wrecks your mind. 
Eventually I happened upon kratom on a detox forum.

It is a partial Mu opioid agonist.  Even if you  saturated all your receptors,  you wouldnt suffer from the respiratory depression that kills addicts. It doesnt get you very high, and taken to excess you just feel terrible and then throw up.  Its addictive, but not in any way like true opiates.  You feel tired and crave it, but I never felt the compulsion to do what i would to get a fix like true opiates. Ive gone weeks without it, waiting for my prefered source to become available.  I was fine in 3 days and never missed work.

  Most importantly,  its legal and affordable.  I spend $50 a month, instead of a day. I can  moderate my use and be a productive citizen and a good husband. I don't put myself in danger to obtain it.  My mood has improved,  and I dont take antidepressants anymore.  Sometimes the back and shoulder pain acts up and i am forced to *gasp* take a Tylenol along with a dose of kratom to really put it down.  Knowing Im not a criminal is great peace of mind. It gives me the confidence to keep looking up. I want to start a company soon. If I can come up with a good idea I'll do it.

Here are the facts: Kratom is a slightly addictive substance. It can be abused like alcohol. Some people will ruin their lives huffing Glade. The fact that its possible to have a problem with using Kratom doesnt make it inevitable.  Most people who use kratom use it for a medical reason, mental or physical.  It was used in Thailand for hundreds of years with no issue. The only reason it was made illegal was to make way for opium. Please don't make the same mistake the thai made. Please don't regulate it to allow pharmaceutical companies to dictate pricing and availability.  We pay taxes when we buy it and we buy it in a way that has integrity. My supplier tests each batch for potency and to make sure it doesn't contain pesticides or adulteration.

If you want to make it safe as possible,  keep it legal and require proof of age (21)  and batch analysis from the sellers. This will cover all bases. No one will do without and no one will get hurt.  The only instances of any harm were in poly drug deaths involving other CNS depressing substances. The chemicals in kratom may lead to better drugs for pain management.  Keeping it legal makes it easier for companies to study. 

Thank you for reading this if you have taken the time.  I want to believe that you have our best interest in heart.

documents.commentText: Hello my name is Casey Chmielowiec and I have been drinking kratom tea for over three years. Before that I was a full time heroin addict for 10 years, homeless and scraping by to get high. Now I can't credit kratom alone with the fact that I am now a certified caregivery, a fully functioning member of society on the path of recovery with his own car, apartment, and future to look forward to, but it has definitively made a difference. I have an anxiety disorder that has kept me in a cycle of self medication my entire life. Kratom not only relieves this burden but also energizes me unlike the dangerous oft prescribed benzos Dr.'s love to give for anxiety these days. Kratom also helped me kick my opioid addiction by helping me "stepdown" off a gram a day heroin habit without any of the side effects of Methadone or even suboxone. With my current kratom dosage, 3 - 5 grams of leaf powder brewed in hot water, I don't even feel "high". Just a little energized and relaxed like chamomile and caffeine. To completely ban this incredible plant would be a great loss in the war on drug addiction and would bar any potential research regarding the medical potential of the active alkaloids in kratom. I heard a certain statistic cited  in favor of the ban which mentioned the increase in kratom related calls to poison control centers to over 600 in a five year period. This is amusing when compared with caffeine related poison control calls which numbered over 2000 in 2005 alone. Are we going to classify caffeine as a schedule I narcotic? Doubtful...

My Name is Rich, 45 year old who has been in the construction management industry for over 25 years both physical and desk work combined, in 2009 my back pain was severe enough for back surgery and of course Norco which was suggested and prescribed by my Dr. and having to wait for 3 months before a surgery could be scheduled, the drug had time to take over my daily being. After surgery temporarily relieved the sciatic pain i decided with my doctor that the pain killers were no longer needed and the withdraws and dark, dark times took over my life. after pleading with my Dr to re-prescribe the opioid he refused and instead prescribed a Benzo to subdue the effects of withdraw. Horrible times were with me and my young family and out of desperation and many hours of research i discovered Kratom and decided to order, again through desperation. Instantly through minimal doses i could feel the "light" come back to my life. My family and social life completely changed as if i had won the life lottery. All the side effects which included: lower blood pressure, better sleeping, eliminated anxiety, elevated mood and energy. I am not a doctor but have discussed with him what i have researched and found and he agrees with me as an individual but not as a doctor. This scares me not only for the fact that opioids overdoses are at an all time high.
 https://www.drugabuse.gov/related-topics/trends-statistics/overdose-death-rates 
but that it is still heavily handed out by the doctors worried about social reviews and future business (my doctors words). I have been through the loss of a family member pass from opioid addiction and a destruction of her immediate family over the loss. I have a best friend who suffered the same back issues and after suggesting Kratom he avoided surgery and the opioid epidemic and was back to work with some minor physical therapy.
I used Kratom for three years controlling doses and even trying different strands discovering many positives throughout. 
In closing, I am a law abiding citizen and would not be writing this if otherwise. so I am pleading with you to not turn Kratom into a schedule 1 drug, it is not addictive, not psychoactive, yet in my case a life saver!
i do agree that kratom should be researched by scientist and not the profit driven companies. 
We need to make the right decisions for the people affected by the opioid issues and help save lives and families. 
have people like me help in the research and development to help all and there are more than just me willing to pay it forward to help save a life!

Very sincerely, 
Rich

documents.commentText: My name is Nate, I'm 29 and work as a Behavioral Health Case Manager and Peer Recovery Support Specialist. I've used Kratom for about a year an a half. I believe that it is not dangerous in any way. I first heard of Kratom through my Vape shop and have continued using kratom off and on since then. Before trying kratom, I did research online and deemed that it would be safe for me to try it. I feel that kratom has helped me with anxiety, stress, and focus. I am not a drug addict and never have been. In the time that I have used kratom I have never felt any withdraw symptoms at all. I work in the Mental Health field and feel that kratom could be beneficial in the future. It's not severe like opiates and other medications on the market now. I've seen more of my client's overdose and in some cases die from benzos or other drugs that are legal. I think kratom should remain legal because it is natural, it's been used in some parts of the world for millenia, and the documented "deaths related to kratom" are inaccurately reported. More people have died from heroin overdose, alcohol related incidents, and other prescription drugs than from kratom alone. I would love to see more research go into kratom, but scheduling it and banning it seems unnecessary and overkill. I have struggled with depression and anxiety for a while now. I was taking prescription medications to help with those symptoms, but I stopped after realizing it was causing weight gain, high blood pressure, and the pharmaceutical companies were making millions while I was still suffering from a mental illness. After I stopped taking my medication and started using kratom, I have never felt better. I am content with my life, I'm focused, and hard working. Part of how I achieved that has to do with kratom and the other half has to do with my support system. I don't believe the DEA should ban a plant that is natural on this earth and has continued to benefit people for many years.

documents.commentText:
Do not Ban Kratom!

I am a 50+ year old former healthcare worker and would like to tell you about my kratom experience. I started using kratom about 2 years ago after contracting Lyme disease and developing chronic fatigue syndrome and fibromyalgia as a result. Prior to Lyme I was an active  and healthy; afterwards, not so much. In fact, I was barely able to get out of bed, let alone function normally.

My doctors and I tried everything--and initially I was hopeful: NSAIDS, anti-anxiety, anti-depression, over the counter vitamins and supplements, injections, creams and lotions, opiods, physical therapy, yoga--until it just felt like an endless, hopeless cycle. Finally, at one of the support groups I attended, someone mentioned a natural supplement: kratom. I did my research--of course I was skeptical, but willing to try it.

Since then, I use 1-2 teaspoons/ day in juice in combination with my prescribed treatments and medications. I have been able to decrease my pain medications significantly, sometimes never needing them at all! My activity level has also improved, even though it is not near what it was prior to the Lyme. Is it possible that it was all a coincidence that I started feeling and doing better once I stated taking kratom? Yes. However, I find that unlikely.

I think it would be a mistake and very detrimental to the thousands of responsible kratom users like me if you severely banned it. I certainly support more investigation and research into its use and benefits, but not a total ban that would cause many people like me to suffer needlessly.

Sincerely,

Mary Buchatsky

documents.commentText:
The DEA's desire to classify the kratom plant as a Schedule I drug is grossly misguided and impulsive. As both a researcher and a citizen, I implore you to permanently reconsider this stance for a number of reasons:

First, to label kratom as an opiate is severely misrepresentative. While the plant does provide some euphoric effects, these are not the same type of effects found in other opiates. Kratom merely provide mood-enhancing effects, which are similar those produced by caffeine. Kratom users do not experience a "high" or any sort of cognitive or behavioral impairment while the compound is in the body. Kratom is more accurately an opoid, which is simply a "compound that binds to one or more of the three opioid receptors of the body" (much the same way over-the-counter pain reducers and anti-inflammatories are). Kratom has been used for centuries around the world as a natural pain-relieving alternative.

Second, there is no substantial and clinical evidence that kratom has any substance dependency side effects; that is, it has not been found to be addictive. In fact, kratom are often used to help those with drug addictions become non-dependent and return to happy and healthy lives. In fact, kratom are used in limited trials across the country in drug treatment centers and rehabilitation programs as a way for the body to more easily transition off of street drugs. Of the dozen or so reported cases in the US in which kratom was attributed to drug overdose and death, it should be noted that the vast majority of those individuals also had other illegal drugs or highly addictive prescription drugs in their systems at the same time. To associate their overdoses with kratom is presumptive and non-evidential. 

In many cases, kratom also provide a safe alternative to millions of Americans who have long-term disability and require daily pain-relief management. Rather than turn to highly-addictive and over-priced pharmaceutical prescription pain medicine, millions of Americans rely on kratom as an alternative. In limited trials, kratom is being used to help treat veterans of our country with symptoms relating to PTSD. For individuals like veterans with prolonged physical and mental injuries that require life-long pain management, kratom provide a safe, effective, and affordable alternative. Kratom also provide individuals who cannot afford pharmaceutical medications an alternative - and one need not look too far to see evidence of the pharmaceutical industry's price-gouging techniques.

The DEA's original letter of intent also hinged on the presumption that kratom is currently unregulated. However, most kratom are sold through normal, honest American businesses run by honest and hard-working Americans. One's ability to purchase the product through retail and online distribution channels provides both economic benefit to American industry as well the ability for companies to continue to produce an honest product. Classifying kratom as a Schedule I drug would inevitably result in the type of behavior the DEA has said it is concerned with - namely that if kratom becomes illegal, it will certainly begin to be circulated through less transparent channels. The DEA, in effect, might create the very thing it was attempted to thwart if it chooses to classify kratom as a drug. The DEA and FDA often allow individuals to purchase unregulated health and nutrition products/supplements without pause.

Kratom is a natural, non-addictive, and effective alternative for millions of Americans who want the choice to manage their day-to-day pain. Kratom allows individuals an alternative to expensive  pharmaceutical drugs (both prescription and over-the-counter) - drugs that have also been found to create dependency, damage the body's liver and other vital organs, and leave people in a state of impairment while in the body. Kratom is not a drug, neither in the normative and non-normative sense. And to label it as such will have drastic negative and unnecessary implications for millions.

documents.commentText:
To the DEA, 
My name is Brian Mallon. I am 29 years old, an organic farmer, and a kratom user. I have been using the substance for just under a year now. I take 1 teaspoon in the morning nearly everyday. 
I started using kratom when I learned of its use in Pacific countries as a productivity booster for farmhands. 
As you may know, farming is physically demanding work. I work long hours, 6-7 days a week, often in ergonomically stressful positions, pulling weeds for hours or harvesting greens on my hands and knees. I have found kratom to be quite effective in boosting my stamina and flexibility, relaxing my muscles and allowing me to remain efficient and mentally positive while tackling mundane tasks. I have been farming for 6 years now and this past season has been my most productive, both in terms of my physical output and my outlook on the future of my career. 
This past season was also my first season farming independently. My first 5 seasons were spent apprenticing under other growers, and this year was the first year of my own business. Starting a business can be stressful, especially contending with the uncertainties inherent in agriculture, and I have found kratom to also be effective at handling that stress and anxiety. Not in the sense that it allows me to ignore the stress or become numb to it. Rather, that it interrupts the physical symptoms of anxiety, the tightness in my chest, the butterflies in my stomach, and frees my mind to look objectively at the sources of that anxiety, allowing me to tackle the stress rationally and with a level head and relaxed body.  
I oppose the scheduling of kratom and urge the DEA to reconsider. Much has been written about the potential of the plant to help those with opioid addiction. I have personally been affected by opioid addiction as both friends and family members have struggled with prescription pills. I don't have experience with using kratom in this capacity but it seems worth researching, especially considering the epidemic of addiction in our country. 
This article -- https://www.scientificamerican.com/article/kratom-drug-ban-may-cripple-promising-painkiller-research/ -- details the research already being conducted which suggests the medicinal potential of kratom. These studies directly contradict the qualification of 'no medical use' for schedule 1 drugs. 
For these reasons and the profoundly positive impacts that kratom has had on my own life I urge the DEA to halt the ban on kratom. Regulate it, impose age restrictions on purchasing, require those selling the herb to undergo the regulations that other supplement companies are subject to, but do not make it schedule 1. There are too many responsible, productive members of society who benefit from this plant.
