Kratom is marketed as a safe natural alternative to other medications as well as a health supplement but the truth is it is far from safe.  Deaths and injuries have been documented from the use of Kratom.  Kratom has no approved medical uses.  Many use it as an alternative to other illegal addictive drugs, but switching from one addictive dangerous drug to another is not a victory in the battle against addiction.  Crack addicts switching to heroin wouldn't be a reason to make heroin legal and so it is with Kratom as an alternative to pain medications.  Furthermore Kratom is accessible to young people not able to purchase alcohol.  They mix Kratom with cough syrup, sodas, and ice and use it for recreational use for a high. Furthermore bars serving Kratom allow the users of this drug to get on the road and endanger the rest of the population because there isn't the same stigma or public knowledge as there are with other drugs.  These businesses are profiting from addicts, people in pain, the depressed by falsely promising Kratom as being safe.  This dangerous drug is most similar to opium in its effects both on the individual and society.  Thailand and Malaysia have banned it and the USA should do the same in order to protect our youth and our general population despite the protests of profiteers and addicts.

documents.commentText:
I live in NJ, a state that has always been a very prevalent place for opiate use, particularly heroin. I have literally lost friends and family members to heroin and opioid addiction. These people that are gone from us forever went through the ringer trying to get clean: courts,rehabs, 12 step programs etc. and none of them worked. 

Many addicts in their quest for sobriety and a normal life chose to switch over to synthetic alternatives such as suboxone only to find even longer and more pronounced withdrawals. As it stands now, there is NO viable answer for opioid dependence by traditional medicine or the institution. The answers we get from them are either highly potent and addictive substitutes in methadone or suboxone, or more jail time. Neither of these is an effective answer for society.

On another hand, we have a natural,legal, and safer plant that grows naturally and has extremely diminished abuse potential when compared to opioids. That plant is kratom. For me personally, it entirely eliminated all cravings for opioids and withdrawal symptoms within minutes of ingestion. Not only that but it also lifted the depression that was hanging over me for months trying to quit opiates and suboxone. For overcoming opiate dependence kratom is a more effective treatment than any pharmaceutical that we have available. I literally have hope for the future and my life back, and kratom was the plant that enabled me to get to this point. This plant can do so much good for others, I don't doubt that if it was more widely used it could greatly reduce the suffering felt by addicts, families, and communities nationwide. 

This plant should be the number one choice for those quitting opiates. It should be available to anyone in the public. I'm not exaggerating when I say it literally got me off of the streets in Paterson as an addict. It can help others too. With this plant we can help addicts get back to society and back to productivity. To ban this substance would be to enable millions to suffer and cause social harm through using heroin and other opioids. I would liken it to treason upon your own people. 

Getting rid of this plant will only enable more heroin users. Heroin is both the most dangerous and most addictive street drug. It's the most evil substance and the most difficult to stop using due to excruciating withdrawals. This plant kratom helped me gain my humanity back, and I want to help the fellow suffering addicts and families get the same help. There is another way that's herbal and inexpensive! Do not ban Kratom!

documents.commentText:
Hello,
I recently heard of Kratom and have never had a personal experience with the plant, but have become interested in it effects and possible uses. I have yet to come across strong evidence of negative side-effects or of it being habit forming.That is not to say that there are no draw backs, but rather that more research needs to be done in order to find out what they may be.
From a medical perspective I avoid taking any drug, Whenever possible I would prefer to take natural drugs over lab made pharmaceuticals. I don't think lab made pharma doesn't have a place in modern medicine, but when there are options available with a lower risk of dependence or other side-effects, those should be the first option. Placing this on the schedule 1 drug list would reduce the options for the medical research that is needed.
From a recreational perspective I am not an active user of anything, I don't even drink coffee on a consistent basis. But just because I don't enjoy taking them doesn't mean that others shouldn't be able to. 
As a society we need to start learning from the mistakes we have made in the war on drugs. We need to start basing out collective actions on science and facts, not scare tactics and misinformation. Lets do the research and this plant  warrants it, then put it on the schedule 1 list, but not before. 
Also, I have seen a lot of, what I'd consider, conspiracy theories about this being moved so quickly to schedule 1 because of pressure on the government from big pharma. If this is the case please remember that this country is supposed to look out for the people best interests, not companies financial best interests.

documents.commentText:
My name is Rachel, and I am a 36 year old mother of three. I work in a retail environment performing merchandising tasks, maintaining audit controls, and ensuring inventory compliance, and I am also a violinist and music teacher.  I have never been arrested, I don't smoke, or do drugs, and I rarely use alcohol.  For many years now, I have suffered from severe migraines, and joint pain, and I have recently been diagnosed with adenomyosis, and large dermoid cysts on my ovaries. I have tried many prescription medications including Imitrex, and Tramadol, but I suffered severe side effects and none of them provided relief.  I have tried every over the counter migraine and pain relieving medication available over the last ten years, but have only achieved minimal relief. I have also looked into supplements and other vitamins to try and build up my body's natural defenses and they have helped, but not enough to reduce my dependence on ibuprofen and other pain relievers. As a result, I have suffered severe depression and anxiety in addition to my pain, and my quality of life was severely reduced to the point that it was affecting my work performance, home life, and limiting the interactions with my children and husband.
My husband discovered Kratom and used it to manage his severe spinal pain, depression and anxiety.  It enabled him to reduce his anti-depressant and anxiety medications, and begin functioning as a normal adult.  As a result of watching this change and commenting on his progress, he encouraged me to try it for my issues as they were steadily getting worse.  
Kratom was the only thing that enabled me to function.  It gave me more relief for my joint pain and body aches than anything I have ever tried, it controlled the pain associated with my migraines, adenomyosis, and cysts, and enabled me to manage my depression and anxiety without prescription medications.  Because of Kratom, I was able to be fully functional at work, I was able to concentrate with my students, and interact completely with my children and husband.  I was not addicted to it by any means and there were no adverse side effects, withdrawals, feelings of dependency, or extra pain like there were when I reduced my ibuprofen intake, or if I miss my morning coffee.
I ask you to keep kratom off of the controlled substances list to provide opportunities for further testing and exploration of this amazing plant, and help the thousands of people like myself that depended on it for relief so that we can lead healthy productive lives, free from the side effects and dependency that are caused by most anxiety, anti-depressant, and prescription pain medications. documents.commentText:
I am writing in regards to the proposition of making a botanical called Kratom a Schedule 1 drug. I am a registered nurse of 17 years with a bachelors degree, working on a master's. I am also a "Kratom consumer". Years ago I had a series of back injuries from lifting patients. This led to an autoimmune disorder called Ankylosing Spondylitis. A disorder that primarily attacks the spine. I have worked in various departments, from OB to ICU. Caring for thousands of patients over the years. I tried every therapy available, from pain medication and injections, to acupuncture and herbal remedies. Nothing helped. I found myself no longer able to do my job effectively. And have had to since take a "desk job" reviewing charts. I still suffered immensely despite the biologic therapy (Humira, Remicade, and now Cosentyx) and as of last year was seriously looking into disability. Which would make me no longer a continuing member of society, and a financial burden to taxpayers. But last year I was introduced to an herb called Kratom. 
      I researched the plant extensively before even attempting to try it. I am personally against any recreational use of any substance and to this day have never tried a single illegal drug, even when I was young. After my research, I tried it. I found not only did it help with my pain, but I could think clearer and function better than I had in years! The worst side effect was constipation. I was able to wean off of prescribed opiates, which did help with pain but made it impossible to do my job. And as a nurse, I can not have any mind altering substances in my system while caring for patients. Since Kratom doesn't cause the drowsiness or alter my thinking process like opiates, I am now able to work better than I ever did before. My fear is, that when this plant becomes illegal for US citizens, I will no longer be able to do my job effectively and will have to once again look into disability. So I personally have a lot to lose when the scheduling goes into effect. 
    I have several other agendas. The first being that I have family that depends on this herb to function. One with an autoimmune disorder similar to mine, and several others with back injuries as a result of construction jobs and motor vehicle accidents. All have said that they cannot function well without Kratom. Not because of a dependency, but because of pain. And these are hard working individuals that have tried every other means available, including surgery and various medications. The other agenda I have, is I lost my spouse to suicide when he could not get the pain relief that was so desperately needed. We have insurance and he literally spent years trying every treatment and medication available to no avail. He despised drug use and never took illegal drugs in his life, and rarely took prescription pain medication either. It is believed the drugs Gabapentin and Cymbalta contributed to his suicidal ideation. I often wonder if this herb could have saved his life. He was disabled for our entire 10 years of marriage and leaves behind a 9 year old daughter I now raise by myself. 
    I have personally seen many lives changed by this botanical for the better. I have also followed the heroine epidemic we now have, and notes the vast increase in use. Specifically in states where Kratom was made illegal. As a professional, I see Kratom as far less dangerous than marijuana and safer than any prescription medication we have available to treat pain, depression, and anxiety. I take several days where I do not consume any Kratom at all, to check my pain levels and prevent dependence. In 9 months of use I have not experienced any withdrawal symptoms, even though my dose is comparatively high. I did, however, have severe withdrawals from Tramadol, Oxycodone, and Methadone. All prescribed to me for pain. They all only worked for a short time, so my physician typically switched medications. And the surprising thing was, the tramadol was the worst withdrawal I had ever experienced. It took me 3 months to wean myself off of methadone. It took 6 months to wean off of tramadol. Yet physicians are prescribing this drug in large amounts because the abuse potential is supposedly lower. Many friends with the same disorder I have, have experienced being cut off of their pain meds abruptly with physician's citing the DEA. I am sorry to say many have turned to illegal substances. A few have found "synthetic marijuana" which is "legal", however watching their behavior while on the synthetic is extremely concerning to me as a professional. I have never seen this with those that consume Kratom. 
   I am writing with a plea, that you consider the thousands of lives at stake when the herb is made illegal to American consumers. I am very concerned for the amount of deaths that will be reported not only from heroine abuse, but to prescription opiates as well. Kratom does not decrease the respiratory drive like opiates. It saves lives.

documents.commentText:
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.

Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.

Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.

Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.

Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText:
I am writing to implore you, the DEA, not to institute a ban on Kratom. As a 37 year old sufferer of congenital hip osteoarthritis who has been told I will need multiple hip replacement surgeries during my lifetime, I would hope that my country and medical community would take every opportunity to research and explore the real possibility of alternative plant based treatments. 

Kratom should and must be researched, tested and reviewed in a rigorous, scientific manner. The shoddy prescription drug propaganda that has been bandied about thus far in an attempt to protect corporate pharma profits is  designed to monetize medicine in the worst and ugliest manner.

As a nation, we should learn from our collective mistakes--from the prohibition on alcohol, to the absurd assignment of cannabis as a schedule 1 drug; there is no harm done by letting the scientific community research these natural plants that human communities have been utilizing to great benefit for countless generations. As a nation, it's time we stop being on the wrong side of history. I urge you not to ban kratom.

documents.commentText:
To Whom it May Concern:

I am a 43 year old recovering drug addict with chronic pain and anxiety.  After a neck surgery in my twenties, I spent many years of my life addicted to opiate-based pain medications. After having thirteen years of recovery in a twelve step program, having had several major life crises, I was in need of a medication to help me deal with my crippling anxiety. I was prescribed Xanax. Having had thirteen solid years of recovery from opiate dependency, I did not anticipate that I would wind up in the same place I was years prior, but I was. I had to go a residential treatment program again to get off of the benzodiazepines. The issues that I had prior to my doctor prescribing the Xanax, were still unresolved and being in my active addiction had caused even more problems for me to overcome.  I have almost one year clean off of any benzos and any other controlled substances. 

 I have been taking Kratom since June of this year for neck pain and anxiety. I have held down a full-time job working in a hospital emergency room with patients, do regular service work in the community, and contribute to my family.  My use of Kratom has never interfered with my life nor my ability to handle high stress situations. I was never able to do any of these while I was on any benzos or opiates.  

With opiate dependence and immortality rate at an alarmingly high rate, it does not make sense for the Federal Government to put Kratom on a list wherein people don't have access to it.  If the United States is TRULY a government for the People, they would look at the simple numbers that show Kratom in and of itself as not dangerous. In my experience, and, according to the numbers released by the Poison Control Center, prescription drugs are far more dangerous than Kratom. 

Please do not ban Kratom use.

documents.commentText: First let me start by saying that I am a father, homeowner, and career driven, gainfully employed licensed professional. I have, in the past, dealt with alcohol and drug abuse issues both personally and within my immediate family. I was able to get and stay clean off of opiates for years through rehabs and 12 step programs but I was always plagued by cravings and desires to drink, depression, and social anxiety in bars, clubs, and other social settings where consuming alcohol is a focus. I began using kratom over a year ago and for me it has essentially eliminated all of those hindrances with no notable negative effects. I consume it with or in place of coffee in the mornings for energy and a mood boost, I use it as a pre workout for added stamina in the gym, and I use it in the evenings or in the aforementioned social settings to help with relaxation and anxiety. I have never found it to have any negative side effects not has it ever made me feel the slightest bit impaired or intoxicated. I still consider myself to be clean with regard to drugs and alcohol and I am still involved in a 12 step program. I know numerous recovering addicts who have found that kratom plays a helpful and in some cases vital role in their sobriety. With numerous members of the scientific and medical community suggesting that this plant is not an opioid, not a dangerous or highly addictive substance, and something that offers great potential for aiding people in a number of ways, it seems like a huge mistake to make it a schedule I substance. The number of calls to poison control are insignificant when compared to many other legal substances that are marketed and sold for human consumption. All deaths being attributed to kratom for which information has been made available  are instances where the deceased was shown to have numerous substances in their system. If you use the logic that any substance in a persons body when they OD contributes to their death, then Vitamin C and other such common OTC vitamins and minerals could be tied to hundreds of deaths annually. OTC pain killers already are directly linked to hundreds of deaths annually. There really is no sound logic behind and no benefit to the scheduling of this plant.

documents.commentText:
While I have personally never tried Kratom, given its relatively long history and lack of adequate evidence for extremely harmful negative side effects, I believe that scheduling the alkaloids mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine that are found within the Kratom plant to be a mistake.  As far as I know there have been no known deaths where Kratom ingestion was the only active substance involved, all of the known deaths have been cases where multiple drugs had been ingested.  Kratom has long a history of use in South Asia and so there should be anecdotal evidence of dangers of this plant, yet I have not found any evidence or anecdotes about Kratom deaths in South Asia.  Another reason to postpone a judgement on Kratom would be a lack of scientific research. One of the few studies on Kratom actually showed that it does not have respiratory effects, respiratory depression is generally the cause of death in opiate overdoses.  Making Kratom illegal, by scheduling the alkaloids mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine would stifle scientific research.  Finally the potential that Kratom, and its main active alkaloids, has on helping the many millions of people who either suffer from opiate addiction or the millions more people who suffer from chronic pain is so great that removing this product from the market is unethical.  
Sincerely, 

William Legrain

documents.commentText:
A year and a half ago, I was diagnosed with Inflammatory Bowel Disease (IBD). That was the easy part.  Prior to that I had suffered terribly for months, unable to eat more than crackers, lost almost 40 pounds in a two month window and the pain was intolerable.  I was put on Steroids to reduce the inflammation in my intestines and never truly felt better.  Fast forward to March of this year (2016), many doctors appointments and emails back and forth as to why I continued to feel like I had been hit by a semi-truck and many other problems which I couldnt possibly list, to be told I have Fibromyalgia.  Some days are so bad I couldnt get out of bed because the pain had me in a fetal position while I cried. Not an easy adjustment for a woman that was active just turned 49 this month and was a soccer manager/mom for 12 years.  I was always on the go until this struck me.
I have worked for the State of California for 10 years and have a very fast pace job that I enjoy doing and am proud of.  My life has dramatically changed over the last 2 years, I barely have the energy to go to work on my better days but there is no energy left after work and the pain from sitting most of my work day is horrible. My quality of life is terrible (who am I kidding there is no life), my only goal is to get to work and get back home to rest. I have since depleted all of my sick leave hours and the only thing I am given for pain is Tylenol.  Tylenol doesnt even touch this kind of pain that my Fibromyalgia causes and I cant even begin to attempt to explain it.  You cannot even concentrate with the chronic pain that I have on most days, not to mention the muscle spasms, migraine headaches daily and the list goes on.  I currently have an average of two decent feeling days a month and I use the term decent loosely. I have been petrified that I wont be able to continue working because most of my symptoms are similar to MS and extremely debilitating.
After a conversation with a friend of mine regarding my diagnosis and my symptoms he mentioned a friend of his that has been in the same boat and was taking something that has been a pseudo miracle for her.  He made a call and told me Kratom.  Id never heard of Kratom prior to that day.  So, once again I started on my research quest to find out what this Kratom is and couldnt believe the information and testimonials I read and videos I had seen.  I was at such a desperate time in my illnesses that I wouldve given anything a try at that point.  I ordered Kratom tea with not a lot of hope it would help me but had to at to at least give it a try.  It was the best thing I couldve ever have done.  I am getting some of my life back!  My daily pain is tolerable; the Fibro Fog you experience from being in chronic pain has mostly subsided and fewer of my daily migraines.  I can actually make a dinner plan on occasion and get some of my household chores completed after work that I havent been able to do in a long time. Ive now been taking Kratom for about a month and overall I have to say its been a bit of a miracle for me. Now I am in fear of having this bit of quality of life taken from me because the DEA wants to reschedule Kratom.  I am begging of you to not allow this to happen. Fibromyalgia is not a fatal illness but the number one cause of death due to Fibromyalgia is suicide.  Most people cannot take being in pain all day, every day nor should they have to. If Kratom is rescheduled Im in fear of being a felon for taking a natural plant based herb (similar to the Turmeric capsules I take) because the DEA making a hasty decision.  I would love to tell people about my Kratom experience but because of the stigma right now around it, I wont. Please help us with chronic pain and hold off the DEA until the proper research can be done.  Ive only recently gotten my life back and would hate to be back in bed for the 10 hours I am home after work, possible lose my job that I love due to absences from the pain and being able to be a little social.  Ive been locked up in pain for too long and hope, no beg that you will reconsider.
Sincerely,
Georgia L. Kattenhorn

I am writing to voice my strong opposition to putting kratom on the list of schedule 1 controlled substances.
Im 28, have a successful full time career, own a small US manufacturing company as a second full time job, and have found the love of my life. A little more than two years ago my significant other fell ill, very ill. She was bed ridden for months and unable to continue working. We saw doctor after doctor before getting the diagnosis of Lyme disease. I would not wish treatment for this illness on my worst enemy as it is both physically and mentally beyond brutal. As I write this she is using a PICC line to deliver intravenous drugs directly to her heart, a process weve repeated several times a day for years. Treatment involves a range of medications designed to reduce pain and treat many chronic symptoms. These have a number of incredibly undesirable side effects and some are very addictive. Kratom has lessened her dependence on pain killers and provided relief in ways prescriptions cannot. Even after seeing dozens of doctors across a wide spectrum of specialties we have not found anything that manages so many of her symptoms as well as kratom. There arent even any bad side effects to boot! She is no longer bed ridden, her pain is well managed, and her spirits are higher than ever. She has even been able to start a successful business thanks in no small part to kratom. She has her life back, I have my life back, please dont take it away.

documents.commentText:
In general, I reject criminalization of drug use by adults.  I specifically reject criminalizing Kratom when the real problem is that highly addictive prescription opioids are enslaving patients to drug companies. Patients are forced to exchange their money and accept severe addiction problems in return for pain relief thus insuring profits for the legal drug pushers.  Isn't this the same pattern we see with virtually all pharmaceuticals?  Few of them cure anything, instead many of them are designed to suppress symptoms while producing side effects that must be treated with other pharmaceuticals which produce side effects... This isn't health care! 

Please don't put Kratom on your ill-conceived Schedule I list.  Just because it is a safe natural product that provides relief to millions who reject dangerous, highly addictive prescription opioids is not sufficient reason to criminalize it.  

Criminalization of drug use has indisputably led to huge profits for private prisons, drug lords and at least in the past the CIA; and has also led to the creation of huge, expensive bureaucracies like your own agency. As far as I can tell, the war on drugs has not protected children or helped people who need pain relief or assistance with their suffering whether it be from PTSD, or mental or physical disorders.  Instead your policies have torn families apart while enriching those who prey on suffering people. Worse, your policies have set back research on powerful healing substances like marijuana by decades, leaving cancer patients for example with no real healing options and at the mercy of carcinogenic chemo and radiation treatments. 

Your proposed rule on Kratom is yet one more example of your failed model.  Please become part of the positive change we need in this country:  Put the people first.  Abandon the discredited and failed war on drugs.  "War is not the answer."  Start by withdrawing the proposed rule on Kratom.  Let people choose a safe, natural alternative to alleviate their suffering without risking jail time.  Don't insist the pharmaceutical industry modify Kratom so they can patent it and profit from it.  Just let the people use a natural, God-given pain reliever.

Please make a start toward helping solve the drug problem and our healthcare crisis by withdrawing the proposed listing of Kratom.

Thank you.

documents.commentText:
Hello and thank you this opportunity to share my experience.

I am a 50 year-old, drug and smoke-free professional in the marketing field. 

I strongly believe placing Kratom in a Schedule 1 classification isn't appropriate and, by doing so, is depriving millions of people from living more productive, drug-free lives, including freedom from, ironically, those in the Schedule 1 category. However there is so much more to this strong belief of mine.

I found Kratom a year ago after a 3 knee surgeries in 3 years and the subsequent prescriptions to pain-killers. The Vicodin made me dizzy, nauseous and lazy.  I did a lot of internet searches along the lines of "natural Vicodin alternative", etc. Up came Kratom and the hundreds of amazing success stories. My curiosity was piqued and I ordered a sample.

In short, not only was I able to toss the prescriptions for my pain, but it has also allowed changed my life with regards to my life-long struggle with severe depression and anxiety. it has absolutely been a "game-changer" for me. I now use it daily and have been doing so for a little over a year. I never "crave" it or "need" it. It doesn't impair me in ANY way. 

Were this plant to become illegal, I would be devastated. My fiancee with severe Lupus has also been able to throw away her Vicodin prescription. We (all Americans) have finally found a natural, non-addictive alternative to pain medication; one of the biggest addiction problems in this country. As if you didn't know that fact. :) But the list of OTHER medical benefits is astounding. 

My depression would resurface and it would lead me back to the fruitless search for more prescriptions that have never worked in 40 years. I feel so good about taking a harmless, non-toxic leaf... 100% natural. It has made me more effective at work, I have been more social, it allows me to actually look forward to the day. I am so grateful to have found Kratom. 

I ask that you read this very short summary of laboratory research on Kratom as an anti-depressant. https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/20869223

In conclusion, I urge (plead) you to consider my story amidst the hundreds of thousands you will see. There are people if far worse pain than me that have found freedom with Kratom. We are not a community of addicts. We are people that want to contribute more to society in a positive way. Please listen to us.

I sincerely THANK YOU for this opportunity to be heard. It is greatly appreciated.

documents.commentText:
Dear people of the DEA,

My name is Anderson Do Bui and I am 19 years of age. I'm currently studying for a bachelor's degree in Entertainment and Media Studies at the University of Georgia.

While I do not personally use Kratom, I believe that it has no place in being classified as a schedule 1 controlled substance.

I am of course, in no position to make any sort of medical claims about this plant. However, I can state with absolute certainty that more research on Kratom must be done. This would be impossible if Kratom was a schedule 1 drug.

Perhaps this current Kratom situation can be compared to the one of Marijuana's. Marijuana was illegal in all of the U.S. for many decades, until further research was done about it. Today we see that there are more than a few U.S. states that have legalized recreational Marijuana, yet none of them have reports of people suffering from what was once called "Reefer Madness." The cruelest part of this all is that there must have been people at some point in U.S. history that were suffering from daily seizures that could have otherwise found the help that they needed through Marijuana.

The real problem is that if Kratom is actually helping anybody at all, whether it is simply arthritic pain or a veteran with PTSD, then any premature decisions about it could be potentially depriving a U.S. citizen of a plant that is giving them the physical and mental relief that they need.

documents.commentText:
Hello,

I am writing out of concern over the proposed reclassification of kratom as a Schedule I controlled substance.

Schedule I drugs, substances, or chemicals are defined as drugs with no currently accepted medical use and a high potential for abuse.

This is definition is simply NOT applicaple to kratom. It is not addictive or dangerous. Furthermore, there have been multiple studies confirming beyond any doubt kratoms's effectiveness helping people suffering from opiate addition, and people suffering from depression and axiety. 

Opiate addiction in particular is a problem plaguing every corner of our country. I personally have lost a close family member to opiate addiction. I know that if he had access to kratom, there is a chance Michael may have been able to beat his addicition and he would still be with us today.

Opiate drugs like oxycontin have killed tens of thousands of people in this country, and has directly contributed to the heroin epidemic sweeping the nation. It is an absolute disgrace that this prescription drug that has caused so much pain and death remains legal and easilly accessible, while kratom, a substance that could help many such people recover, is being threated with a schedule 1 status.

In Alamaba, which banned kratom at the state-level, deaths from opiate use went UP afterwards. I must ask- do you WANT more Americans to die from opiate overdose?

Please do the right thing. Stop the DEA from ennacting this senseless reclassification of kratom, and contributing to more opiate-related deaths.

Thank you,
Joseph G.

documents.commentText: Hello --  I was so grateful to find kratom.  I've suffered from sciatica, fibro myalgia and other muscle spasms for 35 years.  I've had physical therapy, which is somewhat helpful,  but expensive and inconvenient; and I've been prescribed various drugs, which either did not help at all, or made me feel like a zombie while helping minimally.  Mostly, I just live with the pain.  I've had to miss out on many events with friends or family over the years, due to the difficulty of moving around, and how pain reduces sociability.   Having a job as a general manager of a small manufacturing facility for many years, the pain would have me limping through my days, and just collasping at night.  When I was pregnant with my first child, 12 years ago, the back pain was so intense I had to do something, but I did not want prescription opiods.  I did not know about kratom then, so I turned to marijuana.  It helped tremendously with the spasms, but I could smoke it only at night, right before bed, to avoid feeling "high."  Now, I am pregnant again, and I know I have kratom to rely upon.  I will be having my liver enzymes checked periodically to make sure my system is managing with the extra load from the pregnancy.  I have not had liver issues with taking kratom so far, but I am a cautious person.  We are middle-class, responsible homeowners.  I am not a party-goer looking for euphoria.   Please, please allow kratom to remain legal so we can have this choice for pain relief.   A simple, safe, affordable, and effective choice.  Thank you.

documents.commentText:
Docket No. DEA-442W

Thank you for taking the time to read my comment regarding the scheduling of the constituent substances contained within the kratom plant.

I am a 29 year old male living in Louisiana and have been consuming kratom for around 2 years. I first began using kratom to alleviate intense social anxiety, but have found it helpful in regulating my mood and relieving the pain I suffer in the form of TMJ. In the two years I have been taking kratom, I have never increased my daily consumption of 2-3 grams (a teaspoon) and have found it to be extraordinarily tolerable and effective for me.

Kratom is able to relieve my anxiety and pain in ways that many dangerous pharmaceuticals, such as benzodiazepines, can not. I have gone weeks without kratom and have never faced the harsh withdrawal effects that even mild antidepressants and stronger benzodiazepines have given me - kratom has allowed me to live a stable and productive life as a musician and full time employee of a local audio engineering business. 

I have been employed full time since I graduated summa cum laude from our local university, LSU, in 2009. I'm a BSA Eagle Scout and published musician with a happy relationship and strong friendships. I do not bring these points up to laud myself, but demonstrate that kratom users are productive members of society; in fact I would state absolutely that if it were not for kratom, I may not be in the fortunate position that I am.

I understand fully that kratom has risks, as does driving a car, taking cold medicine, eating red meat or raw sushi, drinking coffee, or any number of perfectly legal activities that can sometimes result in negative consequences. In all honestly, the worst I have experienced with kratom is a mild upset stomach and rare dizziness. However, I must admit that my experience is obviously not universal. However, as a kratom user and American citizen, I would like to see the below occur:

1. Kratom should be regulated to ensure purity and the absence of extracts or additives.
2. Kratom should be restricted to sale for anyone below the age of 21.
3. Kratom should be allowed to be studied further by academics to assess its usage and damage potential, taking into account thousands of years of indigenous use in Thailand and Indonesia.
4. Kratom should be treated similarly to other herbal remedies and supplements such as kava kava, St. John's Wort, ginseng, etc. 
5. The trade of kratom should be fair with nations that export.
6. Kratom, if necessary, should be taxed appropriately and funds directed to the common good, such as education or improvement of public transportation.

While it is obvious that there are grey areas when it comes to discussing how to classify kratom, it should be apparent based upon the existing evidence and public comments that:

1. Kratom is not harmful when used alone and when normally dosed.
2. Kratom does not form strong, life threatening physical addiction similar to synthetic opiates, opiods, benzodiazepines, etc. 
3. Kratom is not simply a "drug of abuse" but essential to the lives of many normal Americans suffering from pain, depression, and anxiety. Most kratom users are not chasing a high but simply attempting to alleviate pain. They come from all walks of life and all races, genders, professions, and ages. 

Given the third factor, I find it most pressing that the majority use case scenario be investigated for kratom users. All other points aside, it would be improper to remove kratom abruptly from law abiding citizens who are doing nothing besides attempting to live better lives. Regulation, education, research, and reasonable restrictions on kratom access are all perfectly acceptable options, but I respectfully ask on behalf of kratom users everywhere that this plant be allowed to be studied further and not ripped unduly from those who rely on it.

Above everything I have written, I want to emphasize however that kratom is not a public health crisis. There are concerns, but they pale in comparison to the concerns we face versus heroin and prescription opiate abuse. While I am not and have never been a prescription opiate user, many kratom users formerly were and use kratom to help stay away from these dangerous drugs. Abruptly banning kratom would almost certainly result in deaths, as those who had been abstaining via kratom could very possibly pick their habit back up - and they would have no tolerance to it. This would result in an outbreak of overdoses and deaths - a true public health crisis.

Thank you again for taking the time to read my letter. 

Best regards,
Travis Leeper

Please find my comments below on this issue:
-If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.

-Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

Thanks for considering.

documents.commentText:
The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement
kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v

There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

documents.commentText:
I recently became interested in Kratom because my Mother has suffered from addiction to prescription pain medications and has relapsed several times, on occasion seriously enough to require hospitalization.. I researched Kratom and then purchased it. I felt it was necessary to try it myself before offering it to my mother as an alternative. I have tried it several times and find that it offers a pleasant and mild full body numbing effect and increases mental alertness at lower does (2-4.5 grams). At higher doses (6-9 grams) I find the the numbing sensation is more pervasive and profound, and some lethargy or sleepiness is present. Effects tend to start 30 minutes from ingestion and last approximately 2-4 hours. I have never had any adverse reactions and on the lower doses I experience no lack of mental clarity. Similar to coffee or strong tea, Kratom at lower doses contributes to a minor elevation in mood lasting for several hours. Having conducted these personal trials I intend to introduce my Mother to Kratom in the hopes that if her chronic pain issues become acute she is less tempted to turn to prescription drugs which always lead to increased and dysfunctional levels of use. I may also offer Kratom to my father in law for knee pain he experiences as a result of an old knee replacement surgery.
There are a number of peer reviewed publications of scientific investigations into the potential medical uses of Kratom. These studies indicate there is considerable need for further research into the promising alkaloids found in the Kratom plant leaves. Anecdotal evidence and anthropological evidence suggest Kratom has been used as a folk remedy for a variety of ailments without significant public health concern in Indonesia for hundreds of years or longer. I strongly urge the DEA not to schedule the active ingredients in Kratom in anyway that would inhibit scientific research into its potential (and anecdotally demonstrated) benefits to US Citizens. I also encourage the US government and the FDA to fund research on Kratom.

documents.commentText:
Hello, 
I wanted to share some of what I know about kratom. I am a Social Worker and am specialized in addictions. I have heard from numerous clients of mine that kratom has enabled them to get their lives back. Reports include their being able to stop using heroin or even prescribed opiates. I see many clients who were initially prescribed an opiate pain medication and then became dependent. Some of them resorted to heroin to avoid withdrawal symptoms and ended up in my office as a result. When they began using kratom, they were able to stop using the narcotics and regain control of their lives and manage their pain. I think it would be a shame to ban this herb or assign a schedule to it when it helps so many people. There are always going to be people in our society who take things too far; shopping, eating, gambling...we can't (nor should we) make these things inaccessible or illegal.  Alcohol is legal, but I see people drinking themselves to death all the time. It doesn't mean EVERYONE who uses alcohol will. We saw how effective prohibition was and the war on drugs has failed miserably. It's time our country start addressing the individual instead of the behavior or substance in order to find a real solution to the disease of addiction.
Thank you for your time and consideration.
Sincerely,
Alanna Baker MSW, CACII

To Whom it Concerns,

My name is Jesse Szczygiel. I'm a live event professional and own a small business. I'm writing this in order to express my concern that the DEA is considering outlawing yet another plant that has had a positive impact in the lives of many in order to supposedly protect an irresponsible few. My experience with Kratom has been nothing short of miraculous. I have a chronic hockey injury that required neck surgery in 2010. Unfortunately, the neck surgery did not have the pain relieving result I'd hoped for. Finding the opiate narcotics prescribed for my pain to be dangerous, rampant with side effects and overtly addictive, I stopped getting those prescriptions for fear of being permanently addicted. I find that a modest use of Kratom is more effective as far as its analgesic effects vs. side effects. Kratom has allowed me to be more effective in my career, as the prescribed opiates had a decidedly negative effect on my job performance.

Regardless of my personal desire for a natural analgesic, there is a larger desire that I have... and that is to live in the land of the free. Please do not put Kratom on any schedule or make it in any way illegal. This plant is only a problem for a small subset of people... people who don't want a natural answer to opiate addiction. Let us live free. Don't force us to chose between pain relief and the law. Thank you.

documents.commentText:
Hello, my name is Adelle and i'm 38 years old. I have worked as a hairstylist in Nashville, Tn at the same salon since 2008. Over the past eight years i have worked with famous country singer songwriters, and up and coming Nashville artist. I am a responsible adult who works full time and a caregiver to my disabled mother. I take my profession and family responsibilities very seriously.

   I am writing in concern of scheduling Kratom (mitragynine and 7 hydroxymitragynine) as a schedule 1 drug. I strongly disagree with this scheduling and think that doing so would  only cause harm. There are thousands of people that benefit from this amazing plant on a daily basis and it personally saved my life. I was addicted to prescription pain killers for approximately 11 years. I was going nowhere fast!

   I was in desperate need of coming clean. I started researching natural ways to ween myself off of opiates and came across a Kratom forum. I was aware of suboxone and methadone but wanted to persue a more natural approach. After researching Kratom for about six months and discovering a close friend used it for chronic back pain i found a reputable vendor online and started my journey. At the end of 2011 i started to taper myself off of the painkillers and starting using Kratom in early 2012. After a few months on the Kratom i started to notice i didn't have the urge to take pills. I became very clear headed, happy, and focused more than i had in a decade. I took Kratom until February 2013 until i had no urge of taking the pills nor the Kratom. I lowered my Kratom dose daily until that February with no side effects.

    Today I am clean and sober and don't think that would have been possible without the help that Kratom offered me during that time. I truly believe by scheduling this natural, beneficial, safe dietary supplement will only cause harm and even a larger opiate epidemic. Please reconsider this scheduling and ban. Thanks for your time.

documents.commentText:
I am writing to oppose the chemicals in kratom becoming Schedule 1 drugs. Scehdule 1 drugs are drugs that have no health benefits and are highly addicting.  Neither of these is true for kratom as a whole leaf supplement.  If physical additction does happen through long term consistent use, it is mild and results in a day of flu symptoms when people come off it.  It is very hard to overdose on, almost to the level of cannabis.  In addition, kratom has many positive and well recorded health benefits.  It has been used for a very long time in its area of origin to treat pain, pain killer addictions, anxiety and depression.  It is helping many people recover from narcotic addiction and to stay off of highly addicting, side effect ridden, narcotic pain medications.

I have a personal story to share about kratom.  I suffer from many pain causing physical ailments like carpal tunnel, tarsal tunnel, bursitis, and a hiatal hernia among other things.  I also have bipolar 2 and anxiety.  Over the counter pain medications do absolutely nothing for my pain.  Getting narcotic medications which do help is close to impossible, due to the crack down on them, and they have nasty side effects I prefer to avoid.  The medications available for anxiety have very bad side effects for me as well.  I live in California, so I do use cannabis for some of my symptoms, but the "stoned" effect makes dealing with my special needs children and just generally getting things done difficult.  

I discovered kratom through an article I read online.  I then spent many hours researching it and reading articles written by people who use it.  I am very careful with my health.  I have no desire to take something that could make me worse and I tend to react in stange ways to medications.  I finally decided to try it, after discussing it with with a couple close friends and my husband and my mother-in-law (who both read the articles and are very careful about drugs).  

Kratom has very literally been a miracle for me.  I now have something I can take that will not only relieve my pain, but also helps with my anxiety and the depression side of my bipolar 2 without kicking me into hypomania and without leaving me "stoned" and with no energy.  I can focus and get things done without pain or negative thoughts.  The worst side effects I have personally gotten is a mild upset stomach and the jitters, but no worse than I get from too much strong coffee.  It has changed my life for the better in so many ways and, since there is a history of addiction my my family, it comforts me that it is highly unlikely I will become addicted.

When I heard that the chemicals in kratom were going to be made, through an emergency declaration, into a Schedule 1 drug I was appalled!  I panicked because I might lose this herbal supplement that has solved so many problems for me and for no good reason. I quickly ordered a lot so that I would have some for awhile until I could find another alternative to constant pain or being "stoned" (I wasn't very hopeful).  I still can see no good reason for this to be even under discussion other than some company somewhere wanting to get it off the market to make their profits on side effect ridden pain killers go up. There are almost no negatives to kratom and so many positives.  From what I understand in the areas where it has been banned heroin use has gone up and I also heard that in its native area it was banned because it was cutting into illegal and legal drug sales.

Please do not make the massive mistake of classifying the chemicals in kratom as Schedule 1 drugs.  They are not even close to the definintion.  If you do this you will be stealing from people like me, who have so few options for reliable and safe pain relief, the one thing we have found that can actually help us.  You will be sentencing me to a life of pain again, like how I lived before I found kratom.  I never want to go back to that place.  Living with constant pain is an awful, draining, weakening thing.  It takes away from all aspects of life.  Please do not consciously choose to make all of us who depend on kratom for pain, anxiety and depression relief go back to struggling through each day.

Thank you for your consideration.

Sincerely,
Christina Mulhall

Docket No. DEA-442W

documents.commentText: This comment is for the purpose of opposing the DEA's proposal to place the components found in kratom on schedule 1 of the Controlled Substances Act.  The kratom plant has apparently been beneficial to people throughout history, and is a naturally occurring plant.  The proposal to place this plant on schedule 1 seems like a blatant ploy to continue lining the pockets of pharmaceutical corporations, as they stand to profit greatly by kratom's criminality.  Anecdotal evidence suggests that people struggling with opioid dependency benefit greatly from this plant.  More research is certainly warranted, which is something not permissible once a substance is placed on schedule 1 of the CSA.  If appropriate medical studies determine this substance warrants no valid use, then the legislature should be the one to ban the substance, not the DEA.  The DEA should merely enforce the properly enacted legislation, not create new legislation, which is what this proposal would effectively accomplish.  I do not use this plant, nor do I profit from its continued use.  However, the citizenry of this country should retain the right to use a naturally occurring plant as they see fit, so long as no societal harm results.  Opiod abuse and deaths resulting therefrom are a scourge to this republic, and anything that can prevent further societal damage from this menace should be encouraged, not outlawed.  Please reconsider your proposal.

I am a 38 year old female, mother of 4, and full time healthcare worker. I was diagnosed with Hypothyroidism at age 15, which has come with a lifetime of ailments despite regular checkups and medication monitoring. I have long suffered chronic fatigue, body aches, joint pain, depression, and chronic daily headaches among a variety of other symptoms. I take a thyroid hormone replacement therapy,  and an antidepressant to manage my condition, but the fatigue and chronic daily headaches have become a severe struggle well into my adulthood.  I spent 5 years seeking treatment for the debilitating headaches, which included a wide variety of "migraine medications", pain block neck injections, and strong prescription pain killers. None of these things brought me any relief. The prescription pain medications worked at times, but they wore off quickly, and then led to even more severe rebound headaches,  which caught me up in a cycle of needing them more frequently and raising the strength of the dose to keep up with managing my pain just so I could work every day and take care of my family at home. I deeply feared addiction, and hated myself for resorting to this measure for finding a way to comfortably get through my day.  Then I discovered Kratom, when searching for a natural, safe way to manage my pain and symptoms of hypothyroidism.  Kratom changed my life. Kratom saved my life. Kratom relieves my headaches, combats my fatigue, soothes my depression, and I feel better knowing that I am taking a natural herbal remedy, so I do not fall into the spiral of dangerous and addictive prescription drugs. I do not hide behind the shame of my treatment any longer. I am proud to be one of the millions of Americans whom has been saved by Kratom. Please don't take that away from me. Thank you.

Sincerely, 
Miranda Stark

documents.commentText:
On the issue of placing Kratom on a banned substance list - I am opposed to this for the following reasons:

-Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
-If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
-Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
-Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
-Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
-Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

I'd appreciate these point being carefully considered.

I am the editor of a magazine in Utah. We keep white kratom in our office kitchen for our staff and to offer visitors who do not drink coffee. It is a smoothly energizing, mind-clearing alternative to caffeine    not delicious, but sometimes it is exactly what the brain/body needs.

While I have no personal need (or experience) of kratom for pain treatment, I know people  with pain issues who had negative side effects from pharmaceuticals and found subsequent relief with kratom. Occasionally they stop, and feel the equivalent of a mild caffeine withdrawal.

Having consumed kratom a fair number of times, now, I am at a loss to understand why anyone would ban it. It simply does not make sense from a health standpoint.

I suggest that those who will be deciding this issue have several "kratom breaks" before making their decisions. Certainly, with all the knowledge they will have acquired about this  botanical, there should be no fear in doing so. Let their own experience help inform their decision.  

Sincerely,
Gretchen (Greta) Belanger deJong

Hi, my name is Mariah and I am a 32 year old wife and mother. I am also an author and minister who goes into the local jails to help the incarcerated women change their lives for the better. I strongly oppose the banning of the Kratom plant and all its alkaloids. This will have devastating effects for people like me needing natural pain relief.

I came to learn about Kratom when I was getting desperate for natural pain relief. The doctors gave me Tramadol for my severe sciatica nerve pain but it only made the pain worse. Then I learned of the dangerous side effects of it (seizures) and got scared and wanted to get off. I was also being prescribed Imitrex for my severe migraines that I've lived with since I was 10 years old. The Imitrex works great and almost immediately, however, one of the side effects for that is rebound migraines. Which means I often lived in a perpetual state of constant migraine. It was this desperation of living in constant, debilitating pain that forced me to seek God on the matter. I prayed and prayed for days for Him to show me something natural to help me. 

Then I was researching and came across the American Kratom Association webpage... I started reading the testimonials and became hopeful! I then found my way about how to order Kratom. This was about a year ago.

Kratom helps me with my chronic pain. It gives me a lighter mood and cheerfulness, much like coffee does (Kratom is in fact a relative to the coffee plant!).. It eases my symptoms and allows me to function without ANY negative side effects. There were two times I accidentally took too much and one of those times I threw up... so I have learned that this plant CANNOT be overdosed on. You cannot "abuse" this plant. How wise is God's creation...

Thank you for reading my comment and giving us a chance to express our concern regarding the proposed decision to ban Kratom. Please don't ban it. Please listen to us, hear us, we are real people just like you who are productive, responsible adults wanting to not live our lives in chronic pain. 

God bless you and be with you as you make decisions that effect the entire country.

documents.commentText:
I have been using Kratom since spring 2015. I tried it after hearing some testimonials about it on Internet radio, and then doing research on its benefits and drawbacks before ordering some. I was mainly seeking to temper the mood swings of anxiety and depression that I've had for my entire adult life and even earlier. Although I suffer from joint and muscle pain, due to age and continuing athletic participation, I didn't expect results in this area. (I'm in my mid-50s.). This is not severe enough for me to require a special treatment for it.

Kratom has been like a godsend. While using kratom my mood is always much better. It's not a "high" in the usual sense; it's more like a mild feeling of euphoria, increased energy, and a 'forgetting' of negative thoughts I may have been having.. In this sense it's like the combined positive effects of caffeine and alcohol but without the side effects of those substances. There is no mental/physical impairment, increased recklessness, and depressive effect as with alcohol, and there is no anxiousness, hyperactivity, or loss of appetite as with overuse of caffeine. (Some people may experience loss of appetite, but it actually increases mine.)

Kratom also reduced inflammation and thus joint or muscle pain, while I am under its effect. But the pain-relief effect only lasts as long as the kratom effect lasts, which is probably 3-8 hours, depending on dose. Amazingly, I have found kratom to be wonderful for reducing or eliminating the symptoms of colds or sinus infections. This was an unforeseen benefit that I only discovered by trying it. This is great because I do not use OTC cold medications, but I will treat sinus problems with kratom.

For me, there are two drawbacks, both of which can be managed. One is that kratom does tend to make you constipated. This can be managed through diet. The other is that it is habit-forming -- to about the same degree as caffeine is for many people. This one is harder to manage, because the effects are so positive, and there are no direct side effects from its use (other than the constipation). In other words, there are no "hangovers" or "crashing" from kratom use. I feel about the same in the morning whether I used kratom the night before, or not.

I limit my use to 4 or 5 days a week, and never more than 3 days in a row.

And like I said, there is no impairment. It has no effect on driving ability or other daily skills. (I would not try to operate heavy equipment or power tools while on kratom, but if I was highly experienced in those, I might feel differently.)

In my opinion, kratom is far less unhealthy than using alcohol or tobacco, far safer than alcohol in terms of the lack of impairment, and no more addictive, and with less side effects, than caffeine. Ditto on all those points compared to pharmaceuticals. I hope it continues to be available for people like me, and people who use it to treat more serious conditions than I do.

documents.commentText: You guys at the DEA are obviously banning kratom because of influence from the pharmaceutical industry, not because you actually believe that kratom is an imminent threat to public health, or that by banning kratom you will have an overall positive affect on peoples' lives.  But if you had any morals, or dignity, or respect for the American public, you would base your assessment of the safety of kratom and other compounds on factual data and honest evaluation of the health effects related to consumption.  However, it is obvious that government corruption is common and widespread in the U.S. ( as we've already seen in the recent election), and now you're solidifying this perception with the ban of kratom.  But you know that you'll get away with this ridiculous ban with relatively little backlash, because so few people are aware of and educated about kratom, and also because Americans are ignorant and naive in general.  However, if you want people to respect you and your decisions, you must behave in a respectable manner and formulate sound and respectable regulation.  You are probably aware that drug prohibition has an overall negative impact on peoples' lives, but your job security depends on the restriction of these compounds, and you are probably also unrealistic idealists who are in denial about your role in the negative impact you have on peoples' lives through prohibition.  Once you make kratom a controlled substance and it becomes overly difficult for the average person to obtain, people will undoubtedly opt for far more dangerous, ( but easier to obtain ) substitutes, like suboxone and methadone, just as you are hoping for.  As for myself and like-minded people; however, we will choose heroin, and illegally obtained opioids and benzodiazepenes any day over prescribed opioids, because we refuse to play this ridiculous, unrespectable and childish game with you guys at the DEA and pharmaceutical industry.  Believe it or not, many of us illicit drug users are intelligent and discerning adults like you believe yourselves to be, and we are aware of the underlying diabolical, selfish and greedy reasons behind drug prohibition.  Furthermore, we know that we are far more knowledgeable about which compounds are safe for us to ingest than you guys are.  So congratulations; you've just made yet another another decision regarding prohibition that will cause people more harm than good, waste more tax dollars, and result in more disrespect by the American people for government agencies such as yourselves than before.  And all in the name of selfishness and greed!  Be careful; though, because as they say, "karma's a bitch," and history has shown that taking more than you need has a tendency to bite you in the ass.

To Whom It May Concern:
I wish to speak out in support of maintaining the legality of purchasing and possessing Kratom in the U.S. I have consumed Kratom (usually in an infusion) for more than 12 years. I find it very useful for maintaining energy and focus when needed. I also find it useful as an aid for stress. In addition, it is a great help in dealing with jet lag on long trips. It's effects are similar to coffee or tea but without the jitters. 
I have read that Kratom can be addictive, but that certainly has not been the case with me. More specifically, I have gone without any Kratom at all for periods of several days to a week with absolutely no symptoms of withdrawal.
If pressed to give up coffee vs. Kratom, I would give up Kratom first. But, inasmuch as coffee and Kratom are different in their effects, I strongly prefer to have access to both.
I understand that many people use Kratom for pain and other health purposes. Supposedly, Kratom beverages are loaded with antioxidants and that's a very positive benefit.
I strongly urge the DEA to refrain from scheduling Kratom and, in the process, creating the potential for another illegal drug trade that would benefit no one other than dealers. We have quite enough crime in this country already.

documents.commentText:
Hi, 
My name is Moni. I am 26 and I have a genetic condition called Ehlers Danlos Syndrome. This condition makes that all of the collagen produced by my body is defective. It's too stretchy, too soft. It does not hold my bones and joints in place like in a healthy person's body. I suffer from partial dislocations hundreds of times through the day. I have constant pain in all my joints, especially in my hands, ribs, neck, head, ankles, knees. My fingers hurt from typing or holding things and my doctors tell me I'm probably leaking cerebrospinal fluid because the sack that is supposed to hold it and your spine, called the "dura" is made of my faulty collagen and probably has holes. My whole life, I've been complaining of pain. Tylenol and advil are as effective for pain as m&ms. Stronger medications like vicodin somehow don't touch my pain, but give me new symtpoms like rotational vertigo and uncontrollable vomitting. Recently I've found out that people with Ehlers Danlos frequently don't process drugs properly, and this is why these drugs don't work for me. I've tried so many things to control my constant pain, but nothing seems to work at all. I'm always run down and tired from being in pain for so long. I'm grumpy because I'm just tired of pain. 

Kratom is a weird thing. It's different than the opiate pills from the doctor. Kratom tea takes all of my pain and turns it down, like a volume knob. I know my body won't respond to anything that I take day after day. However, this plant has been able to rescue me from 9-10 pain level when nothing else can. Without this tool, my only option is to bear this level of pain for hours, until it subsides. This level of pain, unfortunately, will trigger more severe pain. Because my body compensates for loose joints by creating protective muscle spasms, my muscles all tend to be very tight. Traumatic episodes such as vomiting or pain increases these spasms and knots, and this holds dislocated bones in the wrong place for longer. All of this increases pain, so it's important for me to try to avoid episodes of severe pain. This is an amazing tool to have in my toolbox. For people with chronic daily pain, it is very important to have a toolbox. When doctors get angry at you for saying medications don't work, they don't continue helping you find solutions. It's too bad, because patients don't always need more dangerous drugs. 

I don't think this drug should be schedule 1. It is not more dangerous than other drugs we allow (alcohol, tobacco). And more importantly, it has a true medical use. If the DEA believes it needs doctors to monitor usage of this medicine, to make sure people aren't using ever-increasing amounts or to make sure people aren't using it daily, I understand. 

But I think that removing this tool from the toolbox of chronically ill patients who cannot process regular opiate pills due to CYP2D6 abnormalities is truly cruel and a denial of medical services.

documents.commentText:
I am a 27 year old mother of two. I have a horrible condition where my neck and head are constantly in pretty severe pain. Because if my age and the fact that doctors really don't believe that you can be in constant pain without a specific test or MRI showing the pain. 

I've been to about 10 doctors just in the past year, trying to figure out why I've been in pain since I was 19. Not one of them take my pain seriously, they will not adequately treat it because they fear the government regulations. My pain is so bad that I can take 5 Tylenol and 4 ibuprofen and it doesn't even touch the pain. Why do I have to suffer my entire young adult life in terrible pain? It is because most doctors look at me like I'm drug addict who just wants a high. It is discrimination. 

I research a lot of different subjects online, medicine being my main subject. So about a year ago I was researching legal supplements that could treat my pain. I came across Kratom one day, I had never heard of it. I studied it thoroughly for several days, I found that it had strong effects on pain, it was legal and there were not an eighth of the side effects you see with prescription pain killers . I found so many forums where people gave their experiences on using this natural plant. To me, I am skeptical till I try it myself. So I bought some sample packs. 

I can't tell you how I felt after the first time using it (powder mixed with orange juice). First you have to understand the amount of pain I was in daily for 6-7 years. It's excruciating, I am not exaggerating. 
Now, I did not have high hopes for this, but I had to try it, just to see. 

After about fifteen minutes after drinking  the mixture, I was sitting on my couch watching a show I was really into. I started to feel the effects creeping in, I realized how comfortable I was for the first time in years.

 When the pain my neck started fading away, I cried. I had found a miracle for my pain, it was unbelievable that it helped more then all the anti depresssant meds, all the Lyrica (made me gain 30lbs in six months) I had been on for years. I have used it on my really painful days and it never fails to help me. It doesn't make me high, but it really helps my mood. I am happy when I'm on it because of the pain relief. I can do more now, with my husband and my little girls. 

I believe that it really is a godsend. I would be right back to the old me that couldn't do much of anything if this plant becomes illegal. I would be devasted because I would have nothing to help my pain. 

I'm urging the government to reconsider this ban. Kratom has been around for 2000 years. I'm sure if it was harmful you would hear a lot more complaints. If the 15 deaths is your reasoning(by the way everyone of those people were on other dangerous meds.), please consider that Tylenol Is more dangerous for you then this plant is.

documents.commentText:
Dear DEA,
 I am a 56 year old mother, and I am a teacher.  I oppose the DEA putting Kratom on the list of Schedule 1 controlled substances.  I have never had the need to use Kratom, so can't personally speak to how or why it works.  I have a 24 year old son that uses Kratom.  Three plus years ago he had an accident playing college sports, and hurt his back, he was in pain, but continued to go to classes and play sports.  Then he broke his hand and had to have 2 surgeries to repair the bones.  The first surgery had to be re-done because the plate connecting the bones bent, and he was in great pain.  After the second surgery he went into a deep depression.  He had to take medical leave from his college, and was still in great pain from his hand and back injuries.  He visited many doctors and pain clinics.  I'm not sure what medications were prescribed, and what medications he would take.  He couldn't keep food down and spent many days not able to get out of bed, sleep or work.  Our family make numerous trips to the east coast, where he was living, to see if there was anything we could do to help.  We took him to doctors, hospitals, clinics and  therapists.  He was in pain and very angry that no one seemed to understand or help.  He stopped calling, texting, and cut off communication to friends and family.  After 6 months of not hearing from him, he called to say that he was taking classes at the local college and was hoping to get enough credits to get back in good standing at his college and graduate.  He is now a second semester senior, and will graduate in June of 2017.  He is calling, going to class, eating, and he seems to have his pain under control.  He is using 
Kratom.  I'm not sure how or why Kratom is working for him, but I am so thankful that it is.  Please do not list Kratom as a Schedule 1 controlled substance; let Kratom remain available. Thank you for your time.

documents.commentText: Hello, I would like to first off state that i'm against the DEA adding Kratom to the schedule one. I deal with chronic pain due to a car accident. I work with a chiropractor, i have acupuncture done but i'm still left to deal with horrible chronic pain despite my best efforts to make my life more comfortable without a substance. I used drugs heavily when i was younger, i'm 27 now and clean for over two years. I still see a doctor and i do take Soma to help relax my muscles or flexiril  at times. But sometimes i need something stronger. I do not want to go to a pain clinic and have to take oxycodone every day. I have been there and done that. Having kratom as an option is a lifesaver sometimes. It is short acting and it works for pain. But it does not knock you out or disable you like Vicodin/Percocet or other opiates can. Plus it is easy to put down and not over use to use every day. There are so many things out there depending on the person people can get addicted to. That falls back on the person and there will and makeup. If they choose to abuse kratom just like anything else your body can get use to it and you can learn to depend on it. But those are not reason why it should be put on a list that includes drugs like LSD, Heroin, Crack or PCP. Taking this useful substance away from people is going to put people in a pinch to where buying heroin which is so prevalent everywhere these days or heavier pharmaceuticals because they could not get something as weak as kratom. I can only see worse happening in the world or illegal drug abuse if Kratom is made illegal. I hope that is not what you want for you fellow man. Please stop this non sense and worry about things that matter like actually stopping these cartels from flooding this country with dope or making pain relief easier for people of all ages threw the medical system.
