To Whom it May Concern,
   I'm writing this comment today in response to the proposal of banning mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine. Kratom is 100% natural and there are no harming effects. I would like to give a little bit of my background and how I discovered "Kratom". I've been in numerous car accidents and suffer with chronic pain. Since then, I've been prescribed harming chemicals to the body such as "Acetaminophen". I don't like it at all and I find that it does more harm to my body than good. I started looking for all natural medicines and was amazed after discovering there was this plant that had medicinal properties and had no toll on the body. In my opinion, this plant is a miracle and needs to be accessible to the public, not everyone likes putting chemicals in their body. I live a clean lifestyle and wish to keep it that way. I eat organic, exercise regularly and look for all natural remedies for all my needs. I don't understand why the DEA has any interest in banning this plant that does nothing but good. I use this plant for my chronic pain but there are many people that use it for other serious mental disorders such as depression, anxiety (which I suffer from as well), addiction and many more. I would like to reference a recent interview that President Barack Obama did with Bill Maher 11/16. In the interview, President Barack Obama said out his own mouth that one of our nations serious issues is Opiate addiction. Well, the solution to that problem is Kratom if really so. The DEA should be welcoming this miracle herb if their business really is keeping drugs off our streets, saving lives (protecting our American people) and stopping people from selling & abusing their prescription pills. I don't medicate with Marijuana because I find it to strong but look how far it has came in our society. The plant was banned but in states like where I live, California, its legal commercially. Why waste time and money and put Kratom in that class when Kratom is nothing like marijuana, not even close. As you all know by now, Kratom is a cousin plant to the coffee bean and has similar effects. We sell coffee on every corner in America, not to mention all the energy drinks we have on the market. Kratom doesn't make people hallucinate, it doesn't contribute to crime and it doesn't kill anybody. With all do respect, the Kratom community feels like we are being strong armed by the multi billion dollar pharmaceutical companies. Please, do not take this medicine away from us. Kratom has changed my life in many ways. I'm a better family man, patriot and all around American because of this plant. I would like to end this comment but I really hope my government does the right thing and works for the people. People will suffer if you take this plant away from us and I mean that. Thank you for your time and God bless America!

documents.commentText:
Hello,
I am a 47-year old winemaker living in Napa, CA. I started using Kratom three years ago to combat chronic pain from knee and back injuries. As someone who makes their living through physical work having a good method of pain relief that allows me to function normally at work is essential.
Non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs such as ibuprofen are not potent enough to be thoroughly effective and opioid painkillers are more strongly analgesic but at the heavy cost of incapacitating me (can't drive, think clearly, stay motivated, etc.)
Kratom has been a perfect solution that clears the pain, improves my mood, and leaves me sharp and mentally alert. 
I am strongly opposed to the DEA's proposed scheduling of Kratom alkaloids as Schedule I substances. While kratom should indeed be used responsibly by informed adults, it has no place alongside harmful and addictive drugs in the restricted category. Volumes of scientific research has been published in peer-reviewed pharmacology journals showing that kratom is quite benign and the potential for fatal overdose practically non-existent, particularly in plain-leaf form (concentrated extracts are potentially harmful, but unnecessary in my opinion).
I believe access to clean, unadulterated kratom should remain unhindered for all Americans and research into kratom's many potential medical benefits should be encouraged.
Thank you for considering my comments,
-Kurt Niznik

documents.commentText: While I believe that the DEA's power to schedule dangerous drugs on an emergency basis is a good thing, I also believe that there must be a high level of proof met before that power can be exercised (even if only temporarily). I don't believe that the DEA has met this level of proof for the alkaloids in kratom. As far as "no accepted medical use" is concerned, medicines have been synthesized using these alkaloids, as seen in the following references: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pubmed/18550129 and http://jpet.aspetjournals.org/content/348/3/383.full. As far as "high potential for abuse" is concerned, I don't believe that the DEA has provided evidence for this. A single death attributed solely to the use of kratom does not constitute an "imminent hazard to the public safety". By referring to these alkaloids as "opioids" in the original notice of intent reinforces my belief that the DEA prematurely intended to schedule without sufficient proof.

documents.commentText:
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, when the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.  Here is a past criminal justice system's corruption example ending with the incarceration of an innocent individual, which will continue with the expansion of the war on drugs:

When Rampart Police Department Officer Rafael Perez was arrested, it led to the biggest scandal in the history of the Los Angeles Police Department. Perez did what Rodney King couldn't do: bring the L.A. force under federal supervision.  Once a golden boy of the L.A.P.D., Rafael Perez has become a symbol of its decay. 
 
Javier Ovando was shot and framed by L.A.P.D. officers, then sentenced to 23 years in prison.  Tamar Toister, Ovando's public defender, asked judge Stephen Czuleger for a continuance to inspect the building. Judge Czuleger refused. When Toister tried to cross-examine the officers about discrepancies between their first report and their revised account, the prosecutor objected and judge Czuleger sustained his objections. Throughout the trial, Toister couldn't seem to catch a break. "What happened was dirty," she said later, "I did all I could but I wasn't allowed to put on a defense."
Ovando, stoic in his courtroom demeanor, was becoming increasingly desperate. To complicate things, Valenzuela (Ovando's girlfriend) had told him she was pregnant. "I became very sad," Ovando said quietly. "I cried. I admit I cried. What could I do?" The trial lasted a week and ended on Feb. 20, 1997 with the jury finding Javier Ovando guilty of all charges. Judge Czuleger sentenced him to 23 years in prison, declining a request for leniency because, he said, Ovando had shown no remorse for his crimes.

Perez's testimony was a series of lies, and the theory that Ovando was a gang assassin a total invention. When Toister learned of the frame-up, she said that she also felt like a victim. Judge Czuleger, who had prevented her cross-examination of Perez and Durden, apologized to the public defender. In an interview, Czuleger said that he was shocked by the injustice that had occurred in his court. "It was," he said, "the worst day of my judicial career." But it was worse for Ovando, who spent three years in prison and remains paralyzed. Judge Czuleger never apologized for destroying his life. 

Perez and Durden were polished, smooth liars. Nonetheless, it is appalling that despite having no prior convictions, Ovando was sentenced to the maximum by judge Czuleger because he "showed no remorse." It was equally appalling that the sham of a trial withstood appellate review and the conviction was allowed to stand.

(Excerpts from articles: "Rampart Hasn't Changed How Criminal Courts Do Business," September 21, 2000, by TAMAR TOISTER, a Los Angeles County deputy public defender, and Truthinjustice.org, The New York Times Magazine "One Bad Cop" By LOU CANNON.)

If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, the senseless criminalization of millions more innocent people will continue.

documents.commentText:
I would like to voice my opposition to the DEAs intent to schedule the alkaloids mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine, which would make Kratom (Mitragyna speciosa), a schedule 1 controlled substance with no medicinal value.  This would put Kratom, a plant helping millions of people suffering chronic and acute mental & physical conditions that is also safely easing the nation's opiate epidemic problem naturally, on the same level as illegal drugs like heroin.  It would also prevent further research which, to date, has shown Kratom to be an effective painkiller that does not cause respiratory depression; the main cause of death from opiate overdose.

I came across Kratom in 2010 as an all-natural, herbal option to the traditional pain medications currently running amok in our country.  I have been dealing with back pain for more than 15 years and have been prescribed everything in the physicians drug guide.  I battled and overcame an addiction to painkillers like hydrocodone and oxycodone.  At first, they seem like a miracle, but after prolonged use, I became fully aware of the dangers of these drugs.  Through physical therapy and a TENS unit, I was able to get my life back, but I was still having pain issues.

A friend asked me if I had ever tried Kratom, I told her I hadnt.  After her recommendation, I began researching this wonderful and healthy alternative dietary supplement.  After reading scores of personal stories, research papers and articles, I decided to try it out.  Long story short, I have finally found a way to live a normal life, free from almost all of my constant, physical pain.

I can take Kratom as needed, to help me through flare ups and then stop all together when I dont need it.  This is impossible with drugs being prescribed by doctors today.  Kratom has become an integral part of my life and to say I am distraught by this recent announcement from the DEA is putting it mildly.  PLEASE stop this from being banned for the millions who have regained control of their lives because of Kratom.

Simply put, there is no evidence to support a ban.  Kratom is a safe alternative to pharmaceutical drugs with important medicinal uses and it has changed my life.  The Kratom community is all for making it a regulated dietary ingredient.  I fear a ban by the DEA will only lead to more tragic deaths of victims of the opiate epidemic.  I know that my own quality of life as a productive member of society will not be the same without Kratom.  I will suffer and many will suffer far more.  You can stop this.

If you have questions about Kratom, please visit www.americankratom.org. Thank you for your time.

Sincerely,
Scott Albanese

documents.commentText:
My name is Janice.  I have a 21 year old daughter that has been ill with Lyme Disease for almost 5 years.  She has late stage Neuro Lyme which has  affected her brain, spinal fluid, circulatory system, nervous system, stomach, intestines, kidneys, gall bladder, pancreas, bladder, eyes, hearing, joints, and bones. 

This disease is not just one disease but a combination of many diseases (viruses, bacteria, parasites). Any vector born insect such as a tick or mosquito bites an infected animal then injects those organisms into a human through a bite. A person can have Lyme with numerous co-infections all with their own set of symptoms sometimes overlapping. My daughter has had as many as three type written pages of symptoms ranging from severe unrelenting head pain (for 5 years), seizures, hallucinations, cysts formed in her sacral spine from 5 lumbar punctures due to high spinal fluid pressure, extreme light and sound sensitivity, unable to walk,  confined to a wheel chair and her bed for the last two years.

  We have seen hundreds of doctors and have been told everything from "she needs to go back to school" to "are you aware of munchausens".  Most doctors think Lyme doesn't exist or it can be cured by 10 to 14 days of antibiotics.  Even  Doctors that are familiar with Lyme do not know what to do as it is so complicated.  Finally the small group of Lyme literate doctors are at odds with each other. Some feel IV antibiotic treatment is warranted, others still use multiple antibiotic rotation strategies , while others use more non-traditional methods employing a myriad of supplements, and "out of the box strategies. 

 The bottom line is this is not a simple or even highly recognized disease so the help you get from the medical community is slim to none. Which brings me to this:  THE PAIN is always there in varying degrees of intensity from a 6 or 7 to a 10 to 12.  Sometimes she curls up in a ball and cries for hours to make it stop.  As her mother I try my hardest to do that.  However, I have had to put her through withdrawal from sometimes well meaning pain medicine doctors.  They put her on oxycontin, oxycodone, dilaudid, morphine, etc. etc. etc. and then decide she has been on them too long and here we go again I have to put her through withdrawal and in the meantime THE PAIN is unrelenting.
 
Two years ago I was searching the web as I do nightly looking for something that would help her pain and I came across a blog discussing  Kratom.  I read the pros and cons and decided it was far less dangerous than the opiates she had been taking not to mention how hard the withdrawal process can be on the body.  So, I ordered some.  She took the pills. Had to take quite a few as her tolerance was fairly high.  We were amazed how much better she felt.  While it did not take away her head pain it did diminish her body aches and pains considerably. Within the last year we have switched to the tincture as it is more concentrated and seems to work faster.  I don't know what I would have done if I hadn't found Kratom.
I know, we would have continued to go to the ER's and beg for help with the pain and be on an endless cycle of medicate-pain-withdrawal.

My daughter does not get a "high", she merely feels somewhat better and can get through a day without wishing she were dead.  Kratom is a plant and I believe God put plants here for a reason not synthetic drugs with 10 to 15 side effects. If I can give her a small amount of relief with little to no side effects, while we continue to get treatment for her condition it has been well worth it.

I strongly urge you to reconsider your plans to make Kratom a Schedule 1 drug.  Its benefits, especially in  higher doses, can help reduce pain and make someone who is suffering more comfortable. The number one complaint of most patients to their doctors concerns pain.  There are thousands of people who cannot live normal lives because pain is a constant.  We need to begin to look at alternatives to fight these chronic conditions instead of opiates.  After all  the overwhelming increase of prescriptions drug abuse in this country starts with someone just trying to get relief from PAIN.

Thank you for reading my comments.

documents.commentText:
Re: Docket No. DEA-442W

I am a 61 year old female. I was diagnosed with fibromyalgia about 15 years ago. It causes widespread pain throughout my body. The pain I feel is similar to what a person feels when they have the flu or a fever. My body aches all over when I get a 'fibro flare'. I have also battled depression and anxiety and I get migraines often. I have been prescribed a lot of prescription medications over the years to help me. The drug Cymbalta was one of them, which is supposed to help with the fibromyalgia pain and depression. I have to admit it did help with the pain, but I felt like an unemotional zombie all the time. I really couldn't care less about anything while I was taking it. I also have chronic migraines. My health insurance company limits me to 9 migraine pills a month. That doesn't go very far as I get one practically every day. What am I supposed to do the other 21 days of the month?

After much frustration and angst in dealing with doctors and prescription drugs, around seven years ago I discovered the herb kratom. Kratom is a plant that has been used in Southeast Asia for centuries by people to help them with not only pain, but to give them energy and an overall good feeling. It also helps with a myriad of other symptoms, such as anxiety and depression. I've joined groups of other users of kratom and have learned a lot about it over the years. I've met people who have successfully used kratom to help them get off opiates, including heroin, as well as anti-depressants. Many of these people deal with chronic pain, like I do and are fed up with all the hoops a person must jump through to get pain killers from doctors. My doctor also recently mentioned that he will no longer be able to prescribe pain killers to me after the first of the year. I must go to a pain specialistjust to get a prescription! I have rather high co-pays with my wonderful supposedly 'affordable' health insurance, so this will just cost me more money and my husband and I are both out of work right now.

Kratom does not get a person high, even though it works like an opiate. I wanted to get off the Cymbalta. I didn't like being a zombie. So I stopped taking it. Kratom gave me the ability to do it without going through a tough withdrawal. I was terrified to go off of it because I had heard horror stories from others about how hard that is to do. By supplementing with this plant, it wasn't hard at all. Kratom gives me the ability to get out of bed in the morning. I drink kratom tea every morning, much like people who drink coffee. It allows me to function. It helps decrease my pain. It helps me to become productive. It makes me feel better. And best of all, there are few side effects other than a bit of nausea if I take too much.

Obviously the drug war in this country is failing. I read more and more each day about people overdosing on opiates (mainly heroin and fentanyl) and how it has become an epidemic. The use of opiates has become out of control. Many people who turn to kratom will have nowhere else to turn if it is banned. Many who have used kratom successfully to get off opiates will probably either live with their pain (which for some is unbearable) or go back to prescription pain killers or worsethey'll turn to street drugs if kratom becomes a Schedule 1 drug. What alternatives do people have? Isn't torture illegal in this country? To me it seems that people who are in chronic pain in this country are treated like criminals. To me, that is torture. To be in pain all the time is no way to live. I truly believe that people will die if kratom is banned. No one has overdosed on kratom. No one has died due to kratom use alone.

Vicki A. Charbonneau

documents.commentText: I am a 34 year old wife and mother of 3 small children. I have a college degree and spent many years working in the legal field. Approximately 10 years ago, I was diagnosed with endometriosis, a chronic disease that causes severe pain. While some women with endometriosis suffer minimal or no pain, I suffer pain and emotional distress every day from this disease. Some of my symptoms include severe stomach and back pain, headaches, fatigue, mood swings, muscle soreness, heavy bleeding, and feelings of hopelessness. Many call endometriosis an invisible illness because it cannot usually be detected or diagnosed without surgery. This makes the disease very hard to diagnose, and some women, myself included, endure years of suffering before getting a diagnosis. Menstrual cramps are bad, awful even for some women. Endometriosis causes extreme pain for many sufferers every single day of the month. Many doctors dismiss this pain, because they cannot see it. Many doctors label you as a drug seeker when asking for help managing this pain, because menstrual cramps are normal, and every woman deals with them. Women with endometriosis do not suffer from "normal" cramps. This is a debilitating pain which interferes with work and daily life. To have a doctor tell you the pain does not exist because they cannot see it is devastating. 3 years ago I discovered kratom. Kratom helps with many symptoms of my endometriosis, lessening the severity of the cramps and lifting my mood. I drink a cup of tea in the morning and I can face my day and care for my young children without being chained to my bed in pain. Kratom greatly improves my quality of life, and the lives of many other people who have it much worse than I do. To remove a supplement that improves people's quality of life is, in my opinion inhumane. I would agree with some regulation to avoid the altering of this natural substance, or even to restrict the use of it by people under the age of 18. I am strongly against placing a plant on any schedule, be it 1 or 5. I am a law abiding adult. I do not use kratom to get high, and if kratom was a product which had any sort of amazing "high" it would be much more popular with teenagers and drug users. The people you would be hurting by taking away kratom are the veterans, the chronic pain sufferers, and the people like me. I am against the DEA scheduling kratom, and I believe it's a gross overreaction to a product that should be available for the responsible adults who gain help from it. It's a cup of tea, and it improves my daily life.

My name is Dr Naida Singleton.  I am a dentist in South Carolina.  I also have a daughter who is a recovering heroin addict.  I am all too familiar with addiction.  Not only due I have a steady stream of drug seekers coming into my office, but I have suffered indescribable pain watching my daughter go through her battle with opioid addiction.  Kratom is very popular in the recovering addiction community because it offers both anelgesic properties and anti-anxiety properties without causing relapse in the recovering addict.  My daughter uses it along with all the recovered addicts she knows.  I also use it because I choose not to use pharmaceutical opioids (which has caused this epidemic in the first place) and because I don't like to overdue the NSAIDS or acetaminaphine.  Kratom is very benefitial, very safe (anything can be over done so lets be realistic here), and doesn't cause addiction.  The alcohol and cigarettes that are legally sold through out the world is exponentially more destructive than Kratom could ever be and yet there they sit - on the store shelves. Please don't take one of the only tools the recovering community has to help stay sober.  You say you are here to help stop addiction; however, the over 2 million opioid addicts still need to overcome their addictions.  Please help them to do so by giving them Kratom as an alternative pain medication.

Thank you for your time with this matter.
Sincerely,
Naida Singleton, DMD

documents.commentText:
Please do not make this illegal. It really helped me get out of a deep, dark depression. It is not extremely addictive, as I am weaning off of it without much difficulty, now taking it every other day instead of on a daily basis. I plan to continue to wean off of it because I want to be completely substance free (maybe one day without my prescribed Klonopin also. I should note that Kratom helped me lower my Klonopin dosage significantly to a level that I am more functional on and have less of a flat affect). 

My feelings about Kratom are mixed, because there is not enough research on it and I want to know what I am ingesting. Still, I was near suicidal ideation on a daily basis before my friend recommended this to me. I am so blessed that it came and helped me get out of such a tough, dark spot. I will continue to wean, but hope to know that I have this as a possible choice if things get so bad in my head again.

Because of its borderline legality, I did hide this habit from my family but was using on an almost daily basis this summer. My brother wrote me the nicest birthday note ever, about how happy he was to see me happy and that he wanted me to continue to be happy. It meant so much to me, that I had come from the pits of despair to a joking, appreciative person others would want to be around. The inner-me, my sense of humor, my interest in ideas and others that used to be there which had faded during college and during depression had returned. And I was so happy that I was happy. There may have been other factors - I see a psychologist weekly and try to live a healthy lifestyle. I have lofty goals professionally and personally, some of which I am surely on my way to accomplishing.

I would be in a worse place without Kratom. Today is one of my days that I will not take Kratom and I am doing just fine. The anti-depressant effects are longer lasting than when I am just affected by the substance. This helped get my life right on the right track, helped me appreciate what I have and know that things will work out for me. I have worried less and socialized more. This substance is mysterious and there must be more research done to see what capabilities and potential drawbacks this substance has. Anecdotally, it really helped me and I hope that it can continue to be a help to others with depression (and other conditions).

Thank you for reading my abridged story, and for considering the positive potential of this substance.

I am a 52 year old man who raised 2 children by myself. I have worked the same high tech job for 25 years. I currently own 4 houses all paid for. While I did not let this addiction destroy my life, I still wanted to get off the endless merry go round of pain meds and   even worse pills to get off of pain meds (methodone).  It was a vicous cycle. Those people who are lucky enough to never have been addicted to opiods cant understand the mental and physical suffering trying to quit. For 15 years I lost the battle.

Then I found Kratom 3 years ago. I found that taking a small teaspoon of kratom 1 to 2 times a day helped me fight my withdrawl symptoms. Both mentally and physically. I went from a 70 milligram a day vicodin habit to zero within a month and have never looked back. I feel strong and healthy and am a much happier person. I have never experienced any negative reaction to kratom and have stopped taking it at times without any form of serious withdrawals.

This leaf should not be banned or made a scheduled drug. It should be studied, it should be regulated to ensure what we are buying is pure kratom and it should be kept away from children except if their doctor recommends it. That is the path we as a nation should be taking with kratom.

Thank you for allowing this comment period.

My pain management specialist and my primary care physician have  prescribed all sorts of medications, all of which have numerous and varied side effects. I discovered kratom after searching for natural ways to help my conditions, and after months of research, I tried it and it was a life saving decision. Hey Guys,

My name is John Burford. 

I'm 26 years old. I graduated from Princeton University in 2012 and currently own an ACT / SAT / PSAT tutoring business called Magnolia Prep.  We do tutoring in 6 cities: Shreveport, Baton Rouge, New Orleans, Orlando, Phoenix, and Louisville.

I tried kratom for the first time in Fall 2014, and started drinking kratom regularly in December 2015. I started drinking kratom with my friends Richie (Lyft driver) and Sam (medical doctor, internal medicine specialty) to put us in a good mood before we went to the bars in Phoenix on Friday and Saturday nights.

I've used kratom for different things. First, it puts me in a good mood. Normally, if a certain day is "fine" (nothing terrible or great happening), kratom takes me from feeling sorta "blah" and puts me in a legit good mood. 

Kratom also helps me see things in proper perspective, mood-wise. If something small in the grand scheme of things is ruining my day, kratom makes it seem like it's really not a big deal and that everything will work out fine eventually.

Second, it helps me with social anxiety. Especially high-pressure environments like going to parties / clubs / bars / meetings where I don't know anybody and I want to be upbeat, relaxed, and social. Basically, it makes me the same way in a high-pressure environment that I would be if I was just chilling with my best friends around the house.

Third, it helps me get work done. It makes me content to just sit there and grind out work for 10-12 hours straight if I want to. I actually used it to start a 2nd business back in January.

My friends mainly use it for the same things as me: making work more fun, putting themselves into a happy social mood, etc.

I think that kratom should remain legal because there aren't any big downsides. I use it regularly and I know a lot of other people that use it regularly, and none of us have ever had any problems. It makes our daily lives better.

Sincerely,
John Burford

documents.commentText:
RE: Docket No. DEA-442W - my comments

Hello, friends at the DEA. 

 I have suffered many years from Autism and Carpal Tunnel Syndrome. Kratom has helped reduce the negative effects of those conditions for nearly 6 years now. It's efficacy is somewhere along the lines of taking any other number of dietary herbal supplements, and absolutely nothing like the substances it would be placed next to on the schedule one list, like cocaine and heroin.

Just because something has shown it can be effective for us does not mean it is dangerous and in need of regulation. As a taxpayer, there are better things for the DEA and law enforcement to spend their time on than battling against Kratom, like dealing with the prescription opiate epidemic.

Whatever the effects of Kratom are, they are certainly not overpowering, or dangerously strong. There are many other herbs with similar potencies, such as Kava, Cats Claw, Blue Lotus, etc that are not illegal. 

Our friend to the North, Canada, also does not consider Kratom to be a schedule-worthy plant, and we have long held a tradition of siding with them on Drug policy.

Rather than making Kratom illegal, I would like to see some regulation as to the manner in which it is processed - i.e. ensuring clean manufacturing facilities, the same way we regulate the production of wheat flour or bottled water. 

In summary, Kratom has helped me live a normal life, and be a functioning member of society. Less than half of all people with Autism find steady employment, and I have done not just that, but found it in a crucial and important field, with the help of Kratom, green tea extract, and my daily regimen of vitamins. Now, you want to take one of those away from me. Should this be the case, it is likely I would have no choice but to either suffer,  or move to Canada and renounce my citizenship. I have family here, and I love the USA! I don't want to do this, but I'm not sure what else I would do. What I do know is that Kratom is a dietary herbal supplement, has not been addictive in my experience over the past 6 years, and is absolutely not a drug. It has been very helpful for me and many others, and more importantly, has done no harm. Once again, it is an herbal supplement, not a drug. Please don't treat it like one.

Thank you for taking the time to consider what I've written here, and I do hope you decide to work for both the good of, and accurate representation of, we the people, and choose to keep Kratom legal.

Id like to tell you my story. At the age of 30 I developed an allergy to all NSAID medications. Ibuprofen, Asprin, Naproxin ETC. My throat swells shut if I take any. At the age of 34 I developed Chrons disease. This is an incredibly painful ailment. At the age of 36 I started dealing with gout in my knees and feet, also incredibly painful. Needless to say, with the exception of Tylenol and opiates there is not a lot the Dr's can do for me to treat pain. Kratom has been a God send for me. Kratom allows me to deal with the pain caused by these ailments without relying on highly addictive prescriptions that are also highly deadly. As a Kratom user for almost 3 years on and off again as needed I can say that it has helped in a way I never thought possible. I firmly believe the product should not be scheduled as any class of drug. The fact remains, its just not powerful enough. With the plant being from the same family as coffee any addictive properties are minimal at best. The plant simply is not something you can get high on. That is probably the reason drug companies are developing prescription painkillers based on the active ingredient in kratom and indicating they hold no addictive properties. I do find it odd that the emergency notice to ban Kratom came within hours of a drug company announcing said product was ready for FDA approval. This is highly suspect and immediately causes one to wonder if Kratom is being banned for monetary reasons.

Is this something that just anyone should have access to? Of course not. Smart laws regarding its use should be considered. Age restrictions would be wise. Regulations in regards to the processing and packaging should also be seriously considered. I hope that you will take seriously how many people are helped by this naturally occurring plant that grows in the wild. Prescription opiates and illegal drugs like heroin kill thousands yearly as well as ruin lives. With the crisis we have in this country, having something that allows someone to get their life back should be considered a good thing.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,
I am writing to you in regards to your recent and current efforts to potentially ban Kratom. I honestly cannot believe that I even have to write this letter. However, I feel my voice deserves to be heard as much as any voice. It is my only recourse to stand up to your potential actions against this plant, and to represent in the only way I can, the huge number of people who safely use this plant as a supplement on a regular basis, without any side effects or danger to their lives whatsoever. 

I am an older man, and my energy levels are not what they used to be. I work 64+ hours per week at my job, and have a multiple of projects that keep me busy at home. I work all the time. In fact all I do is work. I have been taking Kratom for over a year, and it helps me tremendously to stay focused and have an extra boost of energy, very similar to caffeine, except it helps me more to find motivation. There is no intoxicating effect whatsoever to this plant.

To say that this plant is an imminent threat to society is nothing short of a complete fallacy, and I can't help but wonder who's agenda these potential actions stand to serve, and who stands to benefit.

As for the potential for abuse; nobody could overdose on Kratom if they tried. If you ingest too much, your stomach will reject it and you will vomit. I will not elaborate further on that as I believe it has been fully covered in the information that has already been sent to you by the law offices of Hogan Lovells, which more than adequately refutes the claims you have made against this plant.

This plant is used by as many as 3-5 million people in the United States alone, who use it for a multitude of reasons. It is of great benefit to people suffering from depression, PTSD, fatigue, and those who use it for pain management, just to name a few. Nobody, to my knowledge, is out here advertising it as a cure all for all of life's ailments. However, it is a very important supplement that is used by many people, who use it safely every day, and who, right now, are quite simply terrified of you and your potential actions against it. 

I saw recently that alcohol kills 88,000 people per year, and tobacco kills 480,000 people per year. I don't see you trying to ban alcohol or tobacco. Yet you are calling Kratom a threat to society when it alone has never killed anyone?

You cannot turn on the television without being bombarded with non-stop advertisements for Pharmaceutical drugs with serious side effects that go on for half of the commercial. Yet here you are, targeting and threatening a natural plant in the same family of coffee, as if it is a threat to society. 

There are countless people who are simply terrified right now of your potential actions against this plant and the repercussions it could have on their lives. Yet many are also terrified to even speak up against you for fear of consequences of even speaking out.

If you ban this plant, you will not be helping anyone. What you will actually be doing is severely hurting hundreds of thousands, if not literally millions, of innocent people right here in the United States, who are just simply trying to survive in this world and lead full and productive lives.

I sincerely hope that this is not just an example of corruption run amuck and pandering to the pharmaceutical industry. I would like to think that we can have more faith in our Government than that, and that greed and control are not the driving force behind these potential measures.

I have seen videos of soldiers, who have been literally brought to tears and are truly shaking, because of YOUR potential actions against this plant. These are people that struggle every day to survive with the horrendous memories of things they have seen and experienced in their lives, which no person should ever have to experience. They are people that struggle with the prospect of suicide, and yet this plant has helped them to find purpose, maintain their lives, and try to move forward.

What I'm trying to say is, if you take this plant away from them, you will likely be directly responsible for causing the suicide of many American soldiers who will simply give up. For what? For who's benefit? Who gives you the right to take that away from them? What happened to a Government of the people, for the people, and by the people? When did it become a Government that rules the people? In case you have forgotten, this is a Constitutional Republic. It is not an Oligarchy. At least it is not supposed to be.

As for me personally, if you ban this plant, you will severely diminish my ability to maintain my active lifestyle, which I absolutely must maintain for the very sake of survival of my family. A ban on this plant would have devastating consequences on the lives of so many people in this country, and for what cause? For what reason? Who do you think you are? Who gave you the license to play dictator of all of the citizens?

documents.commentText:
To Whom It May Concern:

I suffer from chronic pain due a herniated disc in my back ten years ago. I suffer from debaliting pain everyday and it hinders my ability to do my everyday tasks. There is no long term cure that works for my condition at my age currently. There is no surgeons that is willing to operate on me due to my age, in addition, there is a two year waitlist for my first evaluation appointment, There are people who need care sooner than me.

I am a productive member of society and plan to explore my love of chemistry. I work, go to school, and participate in community events as much as I can. My pcp of 2 years has decided a state funded narcotic that I don't pay a dime for from the pharmacy is best solution. My doctor is always impressesed by my positivity and my attempt to find better ways to manage my pain ( I have not given up yet). What do I do when I can longer work or function because of the heavy narcotic dosing?

I believe in a mix of medication( all discussed my long lasting relationship with my pcp). I have taken X-rays, mri's and many courses of physical therapy all paid for by the state which I am so thankful for. I work with doctors at my job and they will all say that its not good practice to rely only on one medication for pain managemen because of tolerance - needing more of same drug for similar effects. My doctor and I have agreed that diversification of pain medication helps to reduce the risk of dependence on any one drug and therefore, allows me to function to now. 

The problem with Kratom is inconsistency, different give different effects and so controls are not well established. And dosing is hard. I will admit that. It is actually very annoying with each, but if you are careful and titrate your dosing without combining other drugs til you understand the power of the substance you are putting in your body

People lie, numbers don't. Let's look at statistics: 

1. Why do we consume 99% of the worlds production of hydrocodone? Those plants have to come from some where.

2. a) our synthetic opiod epidemic : these number are from the cdc.gov. I think that's a reliable source. 
http://www.cdc.gov/vitalsigns/opioid-prescribing/

Each day, 46 people die from an overdose of prescription painkillers* in the US.

Health care providers wrote 259 million prescriptions for painkillers in 2012, enough for every American adult to have a bottle of pills.

10 of highest prescribing states for painkillers are in the South.

 3. Number of poison control calls over 5 years

During the study period, U.S. poison centers received 660 calls about reported exposure to kratom. The number of calls increased tenfold from 26 in 2010 to 263 in 2015. http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/866904

4.

100000 people x 40 hour x 20 years - 80,000,000 lost earnings

And if they aren't making money then the state will pay 
Between 1960 and 2014, the portion of U.S. healthcare expenses paid:
directly by consumers decreased from 48% to 11%.
by government increased from 24% to 49%.
by private insurance increased from 21% to 33%.[14]Okay. 

I am thankful for the help to have the Medical care provided free of charge, but how long can this be sustained for our children?

I agree 660 (is a lot by itself but let's look at reality which is 11 calls a month as an average. Data from http://www.medscape.com/viewarticle/866904

In 2014, the 55 U.S. poison control centers provided telephone guidance for nearly 2.2 million human poison exposures. http://www.poison.org/poison-statistics-national


During the temporary ban, the DEA would conduct studies on this natural supplement. To me, it makes more sense to conduct studies and then come to a conclusion on whether or not to ban kratom. 
In conclusion, I urge the DEA to halt the ban until further studies can be performed do we can make America great again. I believe that I represent the majority of patients with chronic pain who use opioids. We are responsible and educated. Yes, there is an opioid epidemic in this country. Why not at least research it before the pharmaceutical version reaches the market as soon as patent goes through - as this less addictive, just as effective, and new pain med. We need to make the right choice instead of keeping stakeholders' interest a priority. Do the right thing and at least research the entire plant before making decision that affect a large group of people.

If you keep it legal then we can control it. every supplier has 2x/3x their price since this possibility of scarcity. 
Sincerely,

A concerned Citizen

documents.commentText:
Hello and thank you for taking comments regarding the ban of kratom. Briefly, I just wanted express my disdain for any type of ban or scheduling of the Indonesian leaf. Kratom, without a doubt, saved my life.

After graduating from college and unsuccessfully finding a job that not only provided a living wage, but was not even in my field of study, the opportunity to relieve my later to be diagnosed depression led me down the dark road of heroin abuse. After years of usage, withdrawal, and two arrests, I made the decision to kick the addiction. Unable to afford the process and costs of doctor assisted tapering, I discovered kratom. 

From the moment I began to use the plant over two years ago, I have been free from using heroin. I have been free from the withdrawals, the potential felonies and ODs, and have become a father to a wonderful 5 yr old daughter. I no longer live in my parents basement. I am a productive citizen again, all because of this tree leaf. Even more so, easing off of heroin with kratom was far easier, less costly, and more pleasant than the experiences I witnessed friends friends have using Suboxone or methadone.

There is no "high" with kratom. There are no deadly repercussions with kratom overdoses. there is simply no need to schedule or ban a plant less harmful than alcohol or cigarettes. 

In conclusion, I will disagree with and ask that no scheduling or banning of the substances found within the kratom leaf occur.

Thank you,
Tom Green

documents.commentText:
Kratom should not be banned for the following reasons:

Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it

If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.

Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.

Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.

Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.

Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText:
Docket No. DEA-442W

My name is Ashley, I am a 35 year old single mother and a chiropractor.

When I was in high school I was a cheerleader and I hurt my back pretty badly in a stunt and twenty years later, I still deal with the pain that fell caused me.  In addition, I was in a horrible car accident in 2010 which both compounded my pain and caused additional injuries.  After several rounds of treatment, I was left with nothing left but to be prescribed painkillers from a pain management doctor.  Over the years, I have been increased from low doses of hydrocodone to Fentanyl all with an incredible list of side effects which have negatively impacted my life on top of the pain.  One of the reasons I chose to be a chiropractor was to help people who have suffered as I have.

At the time of the car accident, I was still married and my then husband also suffered injuries similiar to mine.  He was also put on the same path of opiate painkillers but he ended up suffered from a higher tolerance than I and looked for options outside of medical treatment for his pain and ended up taking heroin like so many others.  A normally healthy, positive, kind, responsible man became a shell of himself and was on the verge of death when he decided to go to rehab.

When he got out of rehab, we both sought after something to assist with our pain that was not an opiate painkillers.  He could not take them anymore and I wanted to be done.  So, after much searching, we found out about kratom.  We bought some from a local herb store and it was actually very effective at managing our pain without side effects.  That was 4 years ago and we still both use kratom on a daily basis.  Kratom not only treats our pain at the effectiveness of most painkillers but also provides light stimulation, a mood boost, helps with anxiety, and concentration and does so without any kind of intoxication.

As a chiropractor, I see pain management patients several times a day and many of them are on opiate painkillers.  I hear their complaints about the side effects and how it loses its effectiveness overtime and their fears of addiction.  For all of these people, kratom provides them an option to treat their pain outside of this vicious circle our healthcare system as created.

Kratom has no risk of death, very little side effects, does not cause respiratory depression, and has not more intoxicating effect than a cup of coffee.  Scheduling kratom as a controlled substance is not only irresponsible but it goes against science which clearly shows that kratom does not pose the threat necessary to be added to that list.

Without kratom, my ex-husband and myself will be forced to return to opiate painkillers for relief.  When that happens, we will be on the road to tolerance and one or both of us will likely go to heroin to get the pain relief that we need.  When we do that, we risk our life every single time we use it.  What happens when our two daughters are left without parents because of a horrible decision by the government?  Who is going to explain why this happened to them?

documents.commentText: I think the main point I'd like to make is that citizens should not be legislatively restricted from the tools and the capacity to fend for ourselves and take care of our own needs. For a person who is struggling to stop using opiates and who has a desire to find a better way, I don't think there should be laws that restrict that person from tools like kratom that can assist in reclaiming one's life. Without legal kratom an opiate user would then be at the mercy of methadone clinics or other expensive and highly controlled pharmaceuticals often at the expense of the public health systems. We need to move towards individuals being responsible for themselves whenever possible and making kratom illegal is an unfair disadvantage for people who really need the help. I have seen addicts quit with only the desire to and the small help that kratom offers, just because jumping off cold turkey is scary as hell, and a thing like kratom is just as much a talisman for courage than it is some heavy drug that just replaces on addiction for another. Its addictive properties are very very minimal and ceasing kratom use is more on the order of obnoxious or frustrating, but nowhere near the nightmarish hellscape of opiate withdrawal.  It is mild, it is in the coffee bean family, and it does a vast public good when available. Ask us to be more responsible, and then do not take away the tools we need to be as such. Thank you.

documents.commentText: I am concerned that if Kratom is taken away the heroin epidemic that is consuming our nation and that has killed several of my friends will get much worse. The only thing that banning this natural plant will do is increase the use of illicit substances. I do not see the logic in doing this. Kratom has not killed anyone. The people who were supposedly killed by it all had other illicit substances in their system which is no doubt the actual culprit. Even if it had killed a thousand people, that is nothing in comparison to the deaths that opiates are responsible for each year. Placing this plant on a schedule will accelerate the use of dangerous drugs that actually do kill people, that seems like a very irresponsible action to take if you are actually concerned for the well-being of the people in our great nation. It has the same medicinal functions as the pain killers prescribed  to  as well as obtained illegally by people, without the harmful effects. documents.commentText:
Mitragyna speciosa (kratom) is a deciduous tree that grows in Southeast Asia.  Humans have used its leaves as a mild analgesic and mild sedative for thousands of years in indigenous traditional cultures.  In recent years, hundreds of thousands of Americans have used Mitragyna speciosa either recreationally like coffee, or as an herbal remedy, similar to the herbs Piper methysticum (kava), Scutellaria baicalensis (skullcap), or Hypericum perforatum (St. Johns Wort).  Now, the DEA wants to include Mitragyna speciosa as a Schedule I Controlled Substance, which would transform hundreds of thousands of Americans into felons.  

The DEAs push to criminally prohibit Mitragyna speciosa will cost the agency legitimacy with the American public.  Hundreds of thousands of Americans have used Mitragyna speciosa and found it to be mild and harmless.  How will we react when the DEA declares Mitragyna speciosa to be in the same category as dangerous man-made compounds such as heroin?  The absurdity of the situation will lead us to determine that the DEA is operating without regard to basic facts, scientific evidence, common sense, or the interests of the American people. 

Hospitalizations for Mitragyna speciosa pale in comparison to hospitalizations for coffee or energy drinks.  Clinical pharmacologist Megan Rech and four of her colleagues at the Loyola University Medical Center published a 2014 article in the journal Pharmacotherapy on Mitragyna speciose, finding: Serious toxicity is rare and usually involves relatively high doses (more than 15 g) or coingestants. Fatalities typically involve coingestants.

A 2015 literature review in the International Journal of Legal Medicine offers a similar assessment. Kratom is considered minimally toxic, write Florida forensic scientist Marcus Warner and two co-authors, although they add that research evaluating its toxic effects on humans is limited, with the vast majority of studies involving animals. Warner et al. say withdrawal symptoms are generally nonexistent to mild, even for heavy users and note that two Florida counties have deemed kratom not ready for regulation due to the lack of information demonstrating the substance as being unsafe or hazardous.  Warner and his colleagues concur with Rech et al. that theres little evidence kratom is lethal by itself. Although death has been attributed to kratom use, they write, there is no solid evidence that kratom was the sole contributor to an individuals death. In most documented instances, mitragynine was detected in combination with other drugs.

The DEA should focus on man-made compounds that are actually killing people, particularly heroin and fentanyl.  Plants such as Mitragyna speciosa come from nature and have been used in traditional cultures for thousands of years.  Conflating plants with dangerous man-made opiates is disingenuous and is an abuse of the DEA's rule-making authority.

Gabapentin, compounded back creams,  heat,  cold,  NSAIDS, etc. I didn't get a full nights sleep in three months,  until I found some kratom my friend had given me.  After finally being seen by a specialist,  I stopped my kratom usage with no side effects.  Almost a year ago,  the practice I was going to closed down suddenly.  My records are somewhere in a storage locker. I can't see another specialist without a doctor referral,  and I can't get a referral without my records.  I'm now stuck without proper treatment.  I have since only found partial relief from kratom.  It does not work as well as any medicine I've been prescribed, but still offers an inkling of relief.  I have stopped its use many times with no consequence,  aside from the pain returning full power.  I have not had any health concerns in my experience with kratom.  

I think scheduling this dietary supplement in any way is more harmful to our community than beneficial.  If anything, an age restriction on purchase would be acceptable,   but not a law banning it. Please do not schedule the alkaloids mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,

I first learned about kratom less than 2 years ago, but when I did finally decide to try it, probably about 16 months ago, I was AMAZED at what it could do. For most of my adult life, I have had mild depression issues and general lack of energy and motivation, but for the last 3 or 4 years since I graduated college, it was much worse. I would say more than half of every week consisted of "hard" days, days that I had trouble getting up and wanting to do anything. This is especially a problem when being self employed as I am. Kratom, almost single handedly, fixed that problem and allowed me to get out of the rut I was in. 

I took kratom a few times when I first decided to try it, and was impressed with how well it relieved my depression and anxiety and gave me energy and focus. At the time, I compared it a little bit to coffee but way more effective and much better at relieving anxiety (coffee can do the opposite I find). About 7 months ago, I decided to start taking it on a more regular basis in order to get more stuff done. I would take about 3 grams everyday for 4 to 5 days in a row before I would take a small 2 days break in order to avoid building any tolerance to it. IT CHANGED EVERYTHING IN MY LIFE! I went from having a couple good days a week (days that I felt good and capable) to pretty much all good days with just a few exceptions some days. This not only allowed me to get way more work done from the increased energy and motivation, but it gave me a whole new perspective on everything and what I could achieve in my life. It made me feel incredibly powerful and motivated relative to how I had been living for the past few year. Honestly, I was a little upset that I hadn't discovered Kratom sooner, because I lost at least a couple years of my life to those "bad" days. 

It has now been a couple months since I stopped taking Kratom regularly because I feel really great already without it. This is because Kratom allowed me to pull myself out of a hole I was in that just perpetuated itself. I COULD NOT HAVE DONE THAT MYSELF, believe me, I tried for nearly 3 years. I still take kratom on appropriate occasions, such as to relieve pain, which it is HIGHLY HIGHLY effective for, more so than anything else I've used, and when I have an espially long tedious task to do. I find it really great for manual labor and repetitive and tedious work. This is because it gives me a sense of well being no matter what I'm doing. 

A few more things I'd like to point out. I have NEVER taken kratom to "get high." In fact, the small handful of times that I accidently took too much, I felt very tired and nauseous and was highly motivated to AVOID EVER DOING THAT AGAIN (taking too much). This has been the experience I've heard from EVERYBODY I know who uses kratom. IT IS VERY DIFFICULT to get "high" on kratom without feeling completely shitty. I think that's great built in defense against those who just want to abuse kratom. But you must also realize, those who want to abuse kratom are just people who will find something to abuse, or are already abusing opiates or something else. To those people, I would have to say that kratom is probably a much better alternative since they are going to use something anyway. There is no danger of overdosing on kratom because it does not cause respiratory depression and is not toxic at any reasonable dose. This may just be an opinion, but I feel 100% confident that none of the 15 deaths "associated" with kratom are actually a result of the kratom. Unless something is specially allergic to kratom, it alone cannot kill you.

I'd also like to point out that I have never felt any sort of addiction towards kratom. I never felt dependent on it while I was using it regularly, and I had no problem at all when I stopped using it. I had no withdrawals or anything like that. But I also only used 3 grams a day, which is a pretty small amount, but not too small to have a amazing effect. 

The last thing thing I would like to address is the insane opiate crisis we have right now in America. This is a statistic from the ASAM (American Sociaty of Addiction Medicine): 

"Drug overdose is the leading cause of accidental death in the US, with 47,055 lethal drug overdoses in 2014. Opioid addiction is driving this epidemic, with 18,893 overdose deaths related to prescription pain relievers, and 10,574 overdose deaths related to heroin in 2014" 

That's almost 30,000 deaths in just one year from opiates, with nearly 19,000 from LEGAL PRESCRIPTION PAIN RELIEVERS! That's just ONE YEAR! And nobody has died from kratom alone in all of recorded history! There have only been 15 deaths that have some association with kratom, and in every one of these cases there was something else found in the person's system. You have to realize that if those people who died in 2014 would have known about kratom and would have taken that instead, they would all still be alive today.

documents.commentText: First and foremost I want to thank the DEA for their open-mindedness for once regarding substance abuse and remedies/treatments. Medicinal marijuana is spreading across America and yet it is still a schedule 1 drug.  This is a substance that can potentially reduce America's #1 drug problem: opioid addiction.  People are not being introduced to LSD by a 'hippie culture' in this case.  They are being introduced to opioid use (by and large) BY DOCTORS!  This is common knowledge and yet we are not handling this epidemic with common sense.  We cannot wait for the government to play catch up while an epidemic is at hand.  Kratom and its benefits are far more well-known than the government can imagine.  In Detroit MI, where I reside, it is used daily by people dealing with alcohol and drug addiction, all the way to anxiety and depression.  We need to stop waiting for Big Pharm to find a way to capitalize on something before we allow it to REMAIN legal.  They created this problem and now they need to answer to it!  TOUGH IF THEY DON'T MAKE MONEY OFF IT BECAUSE THEIR R&D HASN'T FOUND A WAY TO PROFIT FROM IT!  The people come first in our beautiful country.  Not the money.  Do the right thing and please leave this life saver alone.

documents.commentText:
First Id like to introduce myself.  My name is Dale Profit, Im soon to be 50 years old and I currently reside in Caldwell, Idaho.  Yes, thats right the great state of Idaho.  Born and raised.  So I imagine you have the same image as most people.  Farms and ranches, mountains & streams, hunters and hikers.  Well, that pretty much sums up my life.  The rugged outdoors. I raised livestock, rode pens, buckarood and even tried my hand at saddle bronc riding in rodeos. Due to that up-bringing and lifestyle I have sustained numerous bone fractures & injuries.  So I guess I lived the simple life.  Only after numerous injures, some more severe than others.  Some requiring surgery, others casts, splints and such, but all of them required dealing with levels of pain on a daily basis.  
Sadly most every time I was prescribed pain medication.   I, like so many others, became addicted, it was quite frankly a double edged sword.  I needed the pills to function in my everyday life.  I was getting a prescription of a 120 Norcos a month, and to be honest, it was NOT enough.  I became addicted and sick.  I was sent to a pain management clinic, but was told its arthritis exercise and a life time of medication.  I developed high blood pressure, headaches, all requiring more medication.  If I didnt have the pain meds then Id have withdrawal symptoms.  A vicious cycle for sure.
But, three years ago, I discovered Kratom.  Finally a product that relieved my back pain to a tolerable level.  It wasnt mind altering and based on my own personal research, had little to no side effects.  Who would have thought after 30 years of pain?  I even talked to my physician about Kratom, who said he thought anything natural that would help, along with alleviate any long term side effects that the pain meds caused, he was all for it. 
Chronic pain is tough enough, but addiction?  Its much worse.  When you take away the pain pills and leave me with withdrawals and then, still suffering from the chronic pain, how am I supposed to deal with that?  Thats why its so important that you understand how much Kratom has helped me.  Its not a quick fix its a daily regimen.  I would equate it to someone whos on a vitamin regimen.  My wife was diagnosed with a B-12 deficiency, so if she doesnt take her B-12 shes very ill.  Ive known people who have taken Saint Johns Warts for depression & anxiety, because pharmaceutical anti-depressants have far too many side effects. That is my plight with Kratom.  Without it, I am in constant and intolerable pain.  But with it, I am truly a functioning member of society, who has manageable pain levels without unnecessary side effects.
Please do not place Kratom as a Schedule 1 drug.  It saves far more lives than it is said to damage.  

Sincerely, 

Dale E. Profit
2322 Polk St
Caldwell, ID 83605
Email: deprofit67@gmail.com

documents.commentText:
Hello,
I'd like to voice my opposition to the DEAs Intent to Schedule the alkaloids Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine, which would make Kratom (Mitragynaspeciosa), a schedule 1 controlled substance with no medicinal value. This is a decision that affects countless Americans, and should not be unilaterally made by the DEA. Their action would put kratom, a plant helping millions of people suffering chronic and acute mental and physical conditions-- that is also safely easing the nation's opiate epidemic problem naturally--on the same level as illegal drugs like heroin. It would also prevent further research which, to date, has shown kratom to be an effective painkiller that does not cause respiratory depression; the main cause of death from opiate overdose. We cannot cut this research off at the knees.

I discovered this incredible herb after  suffering a bad break in my knee in  2013. I was on prescription meds (Hydrocodone) for several months and I was looking for a safer, non-addictive alternative to ease the pain from the break (and accompanying osteoarthritis). Little did I know that it would have such an enormous benefit. You see, I also suffer from Crohns disease (since 1991). What I didnt expect from Kratom, on top of the moderate pain relief it offered me for my knee, was that my Crohns symptoms would almost disappear. This has changed my quality of life in an incredible way. I cant begin to describe how beneficial this has been for me over the last few years. I find that it is no more addicting than coffee (and is more gentle on my system). In addition, and through my experience with it, it is impossible to take too much (overdose).  At the most, it causes sleepiness and some nausea. It does not get you high. There is too much misinformation out there and this substance needs research and regulation, not banning.

For me, kratom is a much safer alternative to pharmaceutical drugs with important medicinal uses. It has changed my life for the better. I fear making kratom a schedule 1 substance will only lead to more tragic deaths of victims of the opiate epidemic (I believe this could lead some people back to illicit drug use). I know that my own quality of life as a productive member of society will not be the same without kratom.

documents.commentText:
My name is Brent Kuzmanich and I'm a Software Developer from the Portland, Oregon area where I live with my wife and 3 daughters. I am completely against the proposal to make Kratom a schedule 1 substance. I've been using Kratom since Fall of 2013 and have nothing but good things to say about it. 

When I was 16, I was involved in a boating accident which left me with a fractured vertebrae and a herniated disc (L5-S1). By the time I was 22, I had already endured countless treatments for my chronic pain including surgery (Lumbar Discectomy/Laminotomy). Though this fixed the mechanical problem in my back, I was left with considerable nerve pain. 

Initially, I relied on prescription pain medications to manage the pain, but eventually I was taken off them to prevent addiction. Without access to pain medication, I began self-medicating with alcohol. Over the course of about 5 years, I became an alcoholic. Alcohol was ruining my life in many ways. I was always either drunk or hungover, I gained approximately 60 lbs, and I was severely straining my marriage. 

In the Fall of 2013, I was actually reading online trying to figure out a way to illegally buy narcotic pain medication when I stumbled upon Kratom. I read about people using it to treat pain, depression, anxiety, and even opiate withdrawal. I decided to try it. From the very first time I used Kratom, I was amazed at the effects. It reduced pain and inflammation better than any opiate pain medication I had ever used. Even more impressive was that I didn't feel like I was in a stupor like I did on pain medications. Over the last three years, I've never even had to increase my dosage to get the same effects and I've completely stopped drinking alcohol.

Now here I am three years later facing the very real possibility that my miracle plant might be categorized in the same group as Heroin. This is insane. Kratom has made every aspect of my day-to-day life better. Everything from sitting at my desk at work to playing with my kids in the yard is more enjoyable as I'm less inhibited by my chronic pain. Please, consider my situation as you come to a conclusion about the future of Kratom.

documents.commentText:
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it.
If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
Many people struggling with opioid addiction have turned to kratom to help them cut back or quit, but now all promising scientific studies on kratom's role in opioid treatment could be immediately shut down.
Side effects of kratom are minimal, and its withdrawal symptoms are weak and nearly inconsequential compared to the suffering of people trying to quit opioids.
Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.

documents.commentText:
I am writing to oppose the chemicals in kratom becoming Schedule 1 drugs. Scehdule 1 drugs are drugs that have no health benefits and are highly addicting.  Neither of these is true for kratom as a whole leaf supplement.  If physical additction does happen through long term consistent use, it is mild and results in a day of flu symptoms when people come off it.  It is very hard to overdose on, almost to the level of cannabis.  In addition, kratom has many positive and well recorded health benefits.  It has been used for a very long time in its area of origin to treat pain, pain killer addictions, anxiety and depression.  It is helping many people recover from narcotic addiction and to stay off of highly addicting, side effect ridden, narcotic pain medications.

I have a personal story to share about kratom.  I suffer from many pain causing physical ailments like carpal tunnel, tarsal tunnel, bursitis, and a hiatal hernia among other things.  I also have bipolar 2 and anxiety.  Over the counter pain medications do absolutely nothing for my pain.  Getting narcotic medications which do help is close to impossible, due to the crack down on them, and they have nasty side effects I prefer to avoid. The medications available for anxiety have very bad side effects for me as well.  I live in California, so I do use cannabis for some of my symptoms, but the "stoned" effect makes dealing with my special needs children and just generally getting things done difficult.  

I discovered kratom through an article I read online.  I then spent many hours researching it and reading articles written by people who use it.  I am very careful with my health.  I have no desire to take something that could make me worse and I tend to react in stange ways to medications.  I finally decided to try it, after discussing it with with a couple close friends and my husband and my mother-in-law (who both read the articles and are very careful about drugs).  

Kratom has very literally been a miracle for me.  I now have something I can take that will not only relieve my pain, but also helps with my anxiety and the depression side of my bipolar 2 without kicking me into hypomania and without leaving me "stoned" and with no energy.  I can focus and get things done without pain or negative thoughts.  The worst side effects I have personally gotten is a mild upset stomach and the jitters, but no worse than I get from too much strong coffee.  It has changed my life for the better in so many ways and, since there is a history of addiction my my family, it comforts me that it is highly unlikely I will become addicted.

When I heard that the chemicals in kratom were going to be made, through an emergency declaration, into a Schedule 1 drug I was appalled!  I panicked because I might lose this herbal supplement that has solved so many problems for me and for no good reason. I quickly ordered a lot so that I would have some for awhile until I could find another alternative to constant pain or being "stoned" (I wasn't very hopeful).  I still can see no good reason for this to be even under discussion other than some company somewhere wanting to get it off the market to make their profits on side effect ridden pain killers go up. There are almost no negatives to kratom and so many positives.  From what I understand in the areas where it has been banned heroin use has gone up and I also heard that in its native area it was banned because it was cutting into illegal and legal drug sales.

Please do not make the massive mistake of classifying the chemicals in kratom as Schedule 1 drugs.  They are not even close to the definintion.  If you do this you will be stealing from people like me, who have so few options for reliable and safe pain relief, the one thing we have found that can actually help us.  You will be sentencing me to a life of pain again, like how I lived before I found kratom.  I never want to go back to that place.  Living with constant pain is an awful, draining, weakening thing.  It takes away from all aspects of life.  Please do not consciously choose to make all of us who depend on kratom for pain, anxiety and depression relief go back to struggling through each day.

Thank you for your consideration.

Sincerely,
Christina Mulhall

Docket No. DEA-442W

documents.commentText:
I'm the successful CEO of a major corporation in Beverly Hills and hold multiple degrees from Stanford University. I'm a Lutheran, married with one young child and a responsible citizen. I mention this because I don't think there is a single type person who uses this medicine. Additionally, I'm not pro-legalization of other drugs and am not a supporter of cannabis legalization (although I do believe it should be decriminalized). 

I was injured in two separate no-fault car accidents and went through years of surgeries and physical therapy. The doctors prescribed me large amounts of addictive painkillers. I managed to wean myself off them before they could cause serious damage to my system. Kratom was a miracle cure. Not only did it help with the problems caused by the painkillers, but it allowed me to work and sleep normally again without any "fogging" of my brain or negative side effects. Since the effects of the medicine at high doses are incredibly uncomfortable, to me there was never a risk of becoming addicted to the plant. 

With the help of this plant, my life normalized. While I still suffer from severe pain, I can manage it without side effects and have started a healthy exercise routine to improve my core to better support my back. Once more, I've becoming a fully functioning member of society who runs charities in my spare time, rather than being a bedridden trainwreck. I'm also able to care for and play with my child much more than was possible when I was hobbling around with a cane. I also reduced my alcohol intake to drink only socially and occasionally rather than sometimes relying on alcohol to take the edge off of my pain. For me, this plant is a lifesaver.

documents.commentText: My name is Frances Elaine Reed. I am 69 years old. I live in Sheridan Wyoming. I have been a registered nurse for 28 years. documents.commentText: I would like to leave a comment in regards to the scheduling of kratom from the perspective of a political activist and not a drug user/consumer of kratom. I want to leave the subjective and anecdotal effects out of the equation. Some people find cigarettes euphoric, and others find them repulsive. The capacity of a compound to induce habituation is irrelevant to me from a legislative standpoint. You, the reader, may not be libertarian. You may feel it is your duty to legislate what the citizens of a government put in to their body. While I would disagree with you, there are factual reasons that kratom (m. speciosa) should not be prohibited. Its inability to consistently produce central nervous system depression makes the drug an anomaly for its mechanism of action. On top of this, the Thai FDA proposed to legalize the compound because if its recognition as a medicine, most notably a pain killer. It is important to consider the current opioid epidemic and the role kratom plays in it, especially for maintenance. I fear that there will be a surge in opioid use by people kratom for maintenance, and the people who can no longer access kratom could turn to deadly compounds and we may see a rise in deaths. This makes the DEAs attempt to ban kratom unethical at best, and deadly at worst. I spoke to Senator Joe Donnelly in regards to this, and will continue to reach out to representatives in all areas of government to just simply request that they make sane decisions and not criminalize a non-violent percentage of our population that are less likely to endanger themselves imminently than tired drivers,

I'm a 42 year old successful business man with a wife and two children. I'm educated, I hold a Masters Degree in Finance, and very active. I played football in college and in the process severely injured my neck and lower back. I was prescribed prescription painkillers for years and was dependent on them. I tried everything I could think of to stop the medications and had a friend tell me about Kratom. I was desperately trying to stop taking prescription painkillers so I decided to try it. Kratom absolutely saved my life! It helps with the pain and, for me, 100% stoped withdrawal symptoms from prescription drugs. What it DOESN'T do is just as important, it doesn't make me "high" or "out of it". When I take Kratom it has the same effect as if I were to drink a cup of coffee. Because of Kratom, I've not taken a prescription painkiller in over a year. My injuries are getting better each day because with Kratom I have the energy to workout and take care of my physical health. PLEASE do not ban this plant or schedule it as a "drug". Kratom has been and still is one of the best supplements I've ever taken with zero bad side effects or negative health problems. 

Thank you for taking the time to read my short note. I appreciate everything the DEA does everyday to keep harmful drugs off of our streets and away from our children.
