documents.commentText:
I am a physically disabled Father of 4 daughter's. I suffer from chronic pain partially from moderate to severe Kyphosis which causes spasm's in my thoracic region whenever I use my hands and arms for any amount of time. I also have a fusion in my lumbar between at my L5-S1 vertebrae from a car accident. Since the car accident in 2011 I had no choice but to take prescription painkillers. They cut the edge but always seemed to never be enough. As my tolerance seemed to grow at an exponential amount. 
Being a father of 4 it was hard having such a life changing event take place. The opiates I would take would put me on a roller coaster effect giving me some days that I felt like Superman and would end up hurting myself trying to do more. The opiates also would do nothing for my spasms in my thoracic region, having to plug myself into a wall attached to an I.F. unit. The kratom kicks in faster and keeps my thoracic region from spasming. Which no amount of Norco or Percocet would touch. With kratom I am able to keep a stable therapeutic level, and not have to worry about poisoning myself if I need to take an extra dose. I have been taking it for 3 years, in the beginning I would take more when I weened myself off of Percocet.  Now I take about 4 grams 4-6 times a day. It also helped me to learn my physical capabilities, as I am able to make dinner for my family 6-7 days a week now. When on opiates alone I was only able to make dinner 2-3 times a week.  Another benefit is I am not having narcoleptic like attacks when I am driving or every time I sit down. I am here for my children now. Which is a serious blessing.  The kratom also has helped my rectal problems. Helping me to stay regular and helped me get off of heart burn medication/P.P.I.'s which had started to deplete my potassium and other mineral levels. My wife Thanks God every day that I have found a healthier alternative to the prescriptions I was taking that had some value but kept me unpredictable.

documents.commentText:
A - Nothing seems to be "temporary" with the federal government. This will be no different.
B - What exactly is your reason for trying to put this into schedule I? 
C - If you follow the money, you'll likely see that it can somehow threaten the already obscene profits that Big Pharma is raking in from the people who are impoverished by the greed of Big Pharma
D - This substance has been shown to be more effective and less problematic than opiates in a wide variety of areas.

And finally, E - it's a frikken herb, for God's sake!! Haven't you folks learned ANYTHING at all about things that grow naturally?  Marijuana has been demonized - WITHOUT ANY VALID REASON - for decades. It is incredibly useful for a wide variety of issues, and has been scientifically shown to be far safer than alcohol for recreation use.

Placing this into schedule I will have two effects. First, it will make all of you look like damn fools. Second, it will create a "black market" where people will find and get what they need regardless of your regulations. If course, the actions of your agency will now create a new criminal class where none existed before.

Is that really what you want to do?
Do you want to knuckle under to pressure from Big Pharma?
Do you want to show that you're spineless simps who won't think and research for themselves?
Do you really want people to look at the DEA and say, "Yep, they sold out again. Someone got greased to get this change put in place.  Looks like the DEA is still the whore of Big Pharma."

Think about it before you do something incredibly stupid.

The DEA should stop any and all consideration of banning the herbal supplement
kratom. There should be no prohibition. While the FDA is looking into it as well, most Americans have never heard of it. Why? Because there's NO REAL PROBLEM with it! Quite the contrary...

Kratom seems like a solution to a number of issues, including various forms of drug addiction and chronic pain. Plus, it can perform the pain-killing work of morphine without dangerously depressing breathing -- the way opioids do.

Here's how Kratom works...
It uses a pathway that mediates many of the undesirable effects of traditional opioids such as constipation, respiratory depression. In fact, this knowledge is spurring additional research by pharmaceutical companies.
http://bit.ly/2c8UTI6

About Kratom, a leading researcher notes...
Thailand is considering legalizing kratom as a safer alternative for meth addicts. U.S. researchers are trying to study its potential to help opiate abusers kick the habit without withdrawal side effects.
http://bit.ly/2c8SI7v

There are anecdotal reports of addiction risk. But it appears the addiction can be broken without withdrawal symptoms. Meanwhile, the painkillers currently being used are more addictive, dangerous, and harder to kick. Yet...

The FDA and DEA both appear ready to ban kratom and effectively kill research to further develop this substance. Is the DEA is running cover for a Big Pharma company that wants to monopolize kratom?

As I consider these actions by the FDA and DEA I'm forced to wonder -- WHAT ARE YOU PEOPLE SMOKING?

I would be distraught if I wasn't able to use the one thing that's helped me overcome my intense and horrific weekly migraines. Kratom is not dangerous or bad for a person. Thank you for reading.

documents.commentText:
Hello,

        Kratom, Mitragyna Speciosa, has a history hallmarked with safety. As with any psychoactive substance, similar to tobacco or alcohol, it can be or has been abused. The average person who drinks kratom tea does not abuse it. This is my experience and I've been reading about kratom since 2013. I believe kratom should be regulated but a schedule one recommendation I think is a little too harsh for the amount of research conducted. 
       We don't know how safe kratom is but we can't be sure it's a complete poison at this point. If kratom is anything like coffee then it should be treated like coffee but it may be more kin to alcohol or tobacco so an age restriction might be appropriate. 
We know tobacco and alcohol directly and indirectly cause many problems with health and safety, we know kratom has some psychoactive effect but it may not be more intoxicating than alcohol, research will tell us. 
       I cannot emphasis enough the importance of research to me and my colleagues of this plant. It has novel pharmaceutical value and we shouldn't eliminate the opportunity to effectively and easily document it's facilitations on the human body. Especially in a time when  opioid addictions are seen in alarming rates across the nation, we need to allow for the innovation around this plant to continue. 

        Sincerely thanks for your time

-Liam Niedrich

documents.commentText:
I am a 23 year sufferer of chronic back and hip pain sustained during a sports injury in my teen years.  It has derailed my career and personal life. I do not like taking prescription drugs of any sort due to the damage that prescription pain killers cause to your liver, kidneys, stomach and mental health and of course addiction. I have already been down that dead end and survived.  

After listening to people who I respect speak about how Kratom has positively changed their lives and state it is not addictive nor does it provide a euphoric high yet still provides profound pain relieving qualities should alone warrant this to be opened up to an immense amount of research at the very least. To list this as a  schedule 1 drug  is borderline criminal. I need and many other people need a non-narcotic option to pain relief.  I spend two to three hours a day doing yoga, stretching, core work and cardio vascular work just to maintain my pain at a moderate level.  I am not looking for a short cut. I do all that while maintaining what most would consider a successful business career at a Fortune 500 company even though it is far less from what I am capable of due to dealing with my constant chronic pain on daily basis and can't put the time or focus  into my career and can't get the quality of life without pain I so desperately need. 

Although, I am not a medical marijuana user,  I do not want to see what happened to marijuana decades ago happen to Kratom.  I know as an American we do not see our government as an organization that learns from our past mistakes but I ask you to please learn from that one and at the very least open up Kratom to research and not criminalize the people who have found relief in it.

Thank you for your time and consideration.

documents.commentText:
I have 2 main points to address with regard to Docket No. DEA-442W - the scheduling of mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine, the main components of the Mitragyna speciosa plant (commonly known as Kratom), as a Schedule 1 drug.  

The first condition needed to meet Schedule 1 classification states that the "drugs, substances, or chemicals are defined as drugs with no currently accepted medical use."  While the primary constituents of Kratom are not currently used in medicine, there has been very little research towards its benefits.   Despite the limited amount of scientific research, I would like to point out the potential for relevance in medicine considering US Patent US3324111 A, held by SMITHKLINE BECKMAN CORPORATION, originally Smith Kline & French Laboratories.  The patent states Kratom's potential for medical use from "a crystalline alkaloid produced from leaves of Mitragyrva speciosa, a plant of the Rubiaceae family. This alkaloid has useful pharmacodynamic activity, particularly analgetic and antitussive activity." The "crystalline alkaloid of this invention is an orally effective analgetic and antitussive agent as shown by animal experimentation." The data here points to strong potential for medical use, which is in line with the thousands of firsthand accounts from users of kratom.  

The second condition to meet Schedule 1 states "high potential for abuse," putting this in the same category as heroin, lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD), 3,4-methylenedioxymethamphetamine (ecstasy), to name a few.  These drugs have widely circulated as recreational drugs, proving them to warrant this classification, as well as undergone rigorous research to prove the lack of medical relevance.  It is not as though Kratom has been unavailable for a similar timeframe, in fact kratom has been available and used as far back as 1846.  Considering the long term availability, and how few accounts of abuse are documented for Kratom, it seems perhaps it is one of the least abused available products.  This suggests Kratom actually has a very low potential for abuse and is important as an herbal medication to users who choose it over other (and more harmful) medications such as Tylenol.  One study reported an average of 44,000 emergency room related overdoses from Acetaminophen each year1 and results in an average of 460 deaths annually, compared to a total of 660 emergency room visits from Kratom over a 5 year period, which averages to 132 per year and has resulted on ZERO related deaths.  With Acetamenophen being an over-the-counter, widely available medication, it seems a drastic move to place Kratom into the strictest scheduling.

In summary, not only does the preliminary research on kratom suggest significant medical benefit and a low potential for abuse, the body of research needed to prove any medical or abusive risk is lacking in this respect.  The strictest scheduling of this drug will cease all current research on the substance, halting any progress made in the understanding of its uses and risks.

1. Manthripragada AD, Zhou EH, Budnitz DS, Lovegrove MC, Willy ME, "Characterization of acetaminophen overdose-related emergency department visits and hospitalizations in the United States." Pharmacoepidemiology and Drug Safety, 2011.

Now I can proudly report that my daughter is communicating on a much higher level of functionality and enjoying school with the possibility of being in a mainstream classroom next year; a dream that almost felt impossible a few years ago. Though my daughter and I worked extremely hard, I truly believe it was that simple Asian plant, Kratom, that made all the difference because without it I would not have been able to work and push as hard as I did. Thank you for reading my humble story.

documents.commentText:
Dear DEA,

I understand and do honestly appreciate the work you do. I understand that drugs can cause major problems and you people have devoted yout lives to cleaning up the mess. And In my opinion, the DEA is not my enemy. However, i must object to the scheduling of kratom. I am currently working on a degree that will place me in the law enforcement field, and as a future law enforcment official, i beg you to reconsider. Here is why:

I will be honest with you: at one point in time i struggled with alcohol. I was quickly headed towards alcoholism and kept making increasingly poor choices, ultimately culminating in a DUI. It was one of the lowest points in my life. I drank to deal with my anxiety, which i have struggled with my whole life. I also drank to get to sleep at night because often times it was the only way to calm my racing mind. Fortunetaly, i made the choice to clean up my act, and on the road to recovery were many things: counsling, friends family, and kratom.

 I honestly do find that kratom is able to keep me away from liqour and has improved my quality of life significantly. In the past hear i have been using kratom, i have gotten a promotion at work, began feeling healthier, and most imlortantly gone back to school to complete my bachalors degree in a law enforcment field. I find that a small dose of kratom is able to calm me down when stress gets to be overwhelming and is able to help me sleep. That is it. I experience no high or euphoria from it. I do not get inebriated. It is simply a herb that helps me be a better person. The alprazolam that i was prescribed to fight anxiety only made me feel like i was walking through a fog after a six pack of beer. It didnt allow me to complete my homework or wake up for work on time. Kratom does not have any of these negative side effects but still contains all of the positive.


I was very surprised to hear about this effort to illegalize kratom. I have never thought of myself as a criminal, and i hope and pray that the scheduling of kratom does not make me one.  As a future law enforcment official to another: i urge you to reconsider. Without kratom i am afraid i will be pushed back into drinking, and that is the last thing i want. I cant stress enough that i do have respect for what you guys do. You are not my enemy, and i shouldnt be yours.

documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,
 My name is Jason Mehalik. I am a coal miner from Fayette The County, Pennsylvania. I became acquainted with Mitragyna speciosa - also known as Kratom- a leaf cultivated and indigenous to South East Asia when my cousin started drinking the tea form for symptoms of PTSD that had disabled her for over seven years. I am commenting here believing that my words will be read and considered. 

What I mean by my cousin's symptoms being disabling is that she had become unable to hold a job, cooperate in meaningful relationships and developed a quality of life that was detrimental to her health and distressing to both herself and the many people who loved her. She worked very hard to find relief with traditional methods, such as therapy and psychotropic medication, to no avail even though she was very proactive in trying to get better. About a year ago she discovered Kratom tea. Although we were all very skeptical it turned out to give her tremendous relief. She now works. She no longer receives disability benefits. She is once again an active and loving daughter, cousin, friend and citizen. She is also falling in love with who we all have reason to believe will be her husband - this is no small thing.  The positive effects of this tea has been an answer to prayer. 

It is for these reasons, and the lack of a scientific basis for the allegation that Kratom is dangerous that I am against the scheduling of Kratom. The undiscovered possibilities for this plant are too important and should be studied scientifically. I live in a county that once was a hub of coal mining activity. Now that the coal mining industry has all but disappeared, the people of this area are turning more and more to drugs and it is a terrible thing. I believe if it wasn't for Kratom, my beautiful cousin would have either died or turned to street drugs in desperation. I am thankful to God that she found Kratom. Taking this harmless medicinal substance away from people who depend on it is sinister and cruel. I expect that the DEA will remember whose interests they serve and make  the right decision not to schedule  Mitragyna speciosa. Thank you for your time.

Kratom is a godsend in the way it lifts my mood and allows me to be a fully functional individual and maintain my job. If the DEA were to schedule kratom I would be faced with a decision that is unimaginable to me. documents.commentText:
To whom it may concern,

I am a 35 year old self employed contractor in Great Falls VA.  I will keep this short. 
Banning Kratom would be doing a great dis-service to the people who use it to battle addiction  pain and depression.
Kratom is not the boogie man substance that everyone claims. People would have you believe that it is dangerous and addictive and needs to be scheduled. I can assure you that in its original (ground leaf form) that it is not. If you examine the cases reported where people have been harmed you will see that there were other factors that were to blame and not the Kratom itself. 
 
 I was a functional binge alcoholic for many years, beginning when I was 15 years old up until the time I was 30. I would drink just about every day after work and on Weekends. It cost me my relationships, my family and prevented me from ever moving up in any of my jobs.

About 5 years ago a friend of mine introduced me to Kratom. He was a frequent drinking partner and it was beginning to cause problems for him as well.  While in Asia for work he had been introduced to Kratom as a natural drink for pain relief. It worked so well he did research on it and then he learned that people in Asia have been using it for over a 1000 years to treat different ailments including opiate withdrawal and alcoholism.

I tried everything for 15 years to stop drinking and my other self destructive behaviors, counseling, rehab, interventions, prescription drugs, medical help, and nothing worked. I would always return to drinking . 

I take Kratom Twice a day. One teaspoon in the morning with my coffee @ 5am and one teaspoon in  the afternoon with lunch @ noon. I function perfectly and the effects are so subtle I cannot even feel them. All I know is that my mood is pleasant, I no longer get anxiety and I am now active in my 9 year old daughters life.

My cravings for alcohol are gone. I can go to bars and restaurants with friends and family and socialize with no issues and I am still able to socialize and interact normally. Without Kratom If I set foot in a place that served alcohol, especially in a social setting, drinks would most surely follow.  Kratom has allowed me to start a business, get my priorities straight fix my financial issues and I credit it 100% with my successes over the last few years.  My biggest regret in regards to Kratom is not finding it before my daughter and her mom left me because we would still be together. I have my daughter on the weekends and her mom often tells me that I am now the man she always wished I would become. (unfortunately while I was finding myself she re-married) 

There is another benefit that deserves mentioning. In addition to ending cravings for alcohol my cravings for cigarettes are gone as well. I feel like there is one negative side effect that I should mention. I have gained about 20 pounds since I started taking Kratom which I cant seem to loose even though I live an otherwise active and healthy life. I went from 180 to ~200 pounds at 5 foot 10 inches. I am not sure if this is because I eat more now that I dont smoke or if this is a natural part of aging now that I have fallen into a routine and no longer run around all night.

documents.commentText: From the age of 18 to 26, I was heavily addicted to opiates. I ruined family and friends relationships. My life was also in financial ruin. At the age of 26, I joined a 2-year rehab facility. Once completed, I immediately moved from Ocean Springs, MS to Columbus, OH. Here I had the heavy support of family. I also met my wife. As soon as I moved to Columbus, I started from at a community college and transferred directly to Franklin University where I will be graduating with a Business/Marketing BA in May of 2017. During my time in college, I picked up a part-time job at a local deli. After I met my wife, we needed more money to share expenses. So, I took over full-time management at the deli and was almost immediately given the title of General Manager and I helped to build a new deli location across town. Now I was in school full-time and also salaried 50 hours a week, all the while trying to plan a wedding. Needless to say, my stress in my personal life was too much and I started using opiates again. I only used opiates for a 1 month period, but the addiction had gained enough ground that I could not just simply stop without having to quit my job and drop out of school. I just happened to live near a methadone clinic. I joined the methadone clinic for over a year. I lowered my dose to a very small amount, then I moved to a suboxone doctor. This was supposed to be a low dose to help me finish the progress I had already made by tapering down from the methadone. Well, suboxone doctors are not geared that way. Whether they think they no better, or they simply just want more money, it was impossible for me to have a voice in my treatment. I quickly learned that suboxone was causing more harm than the methadone was. I completely lost my sex drive, my energy was depleted, depression set in, and it was far more expensive. Since the doctor would not respect my wishes, I began looking for alternatives. This is when I learned about Kratom from online forums. I searched my city and was disappointed that it was sold in local head shops. It gave me the impression that it must have been another one of those synthetic drugs that just had not become illegal yet. I still gave it a shot because I was desperate. I went home and tried it. It certainly was not comparable to any type of "high" or opiate that I had tried. But, I felt It helped to give me the confidence and the energy I needed to kick the doctor out of my life, which I did. Many people say that they use Kratom and they see no withdrawal symptoms. This was not true for me. But, like I said, It helped more than any other solution I have tried from the Pharma companies. I could have saved myself 2 years of grief if I had learned of this plant sooner. As far a regulation, I am aware personally of any negative effects. However, just to error on the side of caution, I do believe that individuals should be 21 years of age before purchasing this product. When I was in high school, it was much easier to buy Marijuana than Alcohol. That's true for many people I have spoken too. So, if you are worried about children, that's the best bet. One last note, I have been suboxone free for only 3 months now. My life is back on track and I owe it all to Kratom. Please, do not ban kratom.

If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.

documents.commentText:
I am a decent, responsible, 33 year old, contributing member of society with a masters degree, a good job in healthcare, a mortgage, and two young children. I am also a recovering alcoholic and someone who suffers with bouts of debilitating depression and anxiety. Since I discovered Kratom three years ago my quality of life and overall level of functioning has significantly improved. Believe me, I have tried the gamut of psychopharmacological options over the years with no relief. In fact, I found the side effects, withdrawal symptoms, and addiction potential to be much greater among benzodiazepines and antidepressants as compared to Kratom. Unlike sedating drugs like alcohol or Xanax, Kratom (even in large doses) has not caused me to have memory problems, respiratory depression, impaired motor skills, or impaired decision making. I can take it when I need it and stop when I don't. Stopping completely after prolonged use has resulted in minor withdrawl symptoms on par with quitting caffeine, while taking too much at once has resulted in only temporary stomach upset.

Kratom has helped to virtually eliminate my urges to drink alcohol. I am no longer crippled by social anxiety and I actually look forward to the day ahead of me when I wake up in the morning. All this is a result of my hard work in improving my lifestyle choices and the wonders of this herbal supplement. Contrary to many of the false claims made in the media, there is no intoxicating euphoria associated with Kratom; only a relatively mild lift in my mood and a boost in my overall sense of well-being. 

Should I chose to continue to consume Kratom following this hastily proposed ban, the police will be forced to convict me as they would a heroin addict. There are literally thousands of other hard working, contributing members of society like me out there that stand to potentially lose everything by being branded as illicit, drug-abusing, criminals. A ban on Kratom would surely result in a sad continuation of a long list of failed drug policies in the US, much like we have seen with marijuana prohibition and the over-prescription of opiates within the medical community. I urge you to look deep into your conscience, withdraw this proposed ban, and allow this plant to be utilized as the miraculous herbal supplement that it is. documents.commentText:
To The DEA and FDA:

My name is Micah Doughty. I am 36 years old, a college graduate (Biology), and I recently suffered a traumatic injury that rendered me disabled. Before the injury, I had always been a productive member of society. I always maintained full-time employment, donated my free time to many volunteer organizations, and remained active in my civic duties. 

I am vehemently opposed to the DEA and FDA seeking to list Kratom and it's active alkaloids as  Schedule 1 substances! This natural plant has been used safely for thousands of years by the people of South East Asia,  and more recently, by millions of people around the world. The DEA, recklessly and without forethought, tried to place Kratom under an "emergency Schedule 1 listing" back in September, claiming that it was "an imminent threat" to the people of the US. The people of this country (myself included) rallied in the thousands to make absolutely sure they did not get away with this. The DEA has done absolutely no research or studies to back up their claims. All of their data was incredibly false and seemed to be collected by searching for "Kratom" on Google. I hate to think about the same type of people, who would make such unfounded claims, as being in charge of positions in our government that are supposed to be looking out for our best interests. The claims of deaths attributed to Kratom usage were erroneous and always described people using Kratom w/ other deadly drugs in their systems. No deaths, ZERO, have been reported/attributed to Kratom alone in the thousands of years it has been used by humans. The supposed jump in Kratom related calls to poison control centers are completely insignificant when compared to the number of calls received daily from things like Tylenol, alcohol, and especially prescription opiates. All of these substances are legal, yet cause hundreds or thousands of deaths each year! It makes me suspect that there must be some other agendas behind the push to ban the safe and effective use of Kratom.

I have used Kratom here and there for nearly two decades. I recently began to use it on a  regular basis after my accident in March 2016. Since my accident, I have suffered from  constant, severe, and debilitating pain in my right arm, hand, leg, and foot. Doctors have tried to prescribe me all sorts of synthetic drugs to try and quell the pain, but none of them have helped and have left me with severe side effects. I choose not to take any prescription opiate medications because of the severe risk of addiction and the first-hand knowledge of the horrible consequences it can cause to the people who are prescribed them. If you are looking for an "imminent threat", go after the doctors and pharmaceutical companies which are legally pushing these deadly substances on the American people! Kratom has naturally helped relieve my pain, with absolutely no side effects what so ever. It has allowed me to focus on my physical/occupational therapies. And I have been able to make significant progress in my rehabilitation! My doctors have been amazed by the speed of my recovery, and I have told them about my use of Kratom. They are behind me 100% in my usage of this safe alternative to pharmaceutical pain medications, and have begun to research the benefits themselves. I have been able to use Kratom daily without the build-up in tolerance that is commonly attributed to opiates. And I am also able to stop taking Kratom at any time, without going through any sort of withdrawal effects besides the return of my pain. Kratom does not cause any respiratory depression, which is the leading cause of overdose deaths from pharmaceutical opiates. 

I think our government would be making an incredibly huge mistake by making Kratom illegal! Doing so would cause so many users to fall into the use of legal and illegal substances, which cause so much harm to people already, in a search to relieve the pain, anxiety, and addictions that plague them. I suspect a rapid increase in crime and overdoses from other deadly substances if our government decides to go through with the ban of Kratom.  I am worried about the prospect of losing the ONE thing that has helped me relieve the pain from my injuries! I I sincerely hope that the DEA and FDA do some actual research into this plant and come to the same conclusion as the millions of Kratom users around the world. There are so many greater threats to our society that need the attention of our government. Do not take away the right for people to safely use Kratom!

Thank you for listening to the public outcry over an emergency ban of Kratom, and allowing this comment period! I hope the DEA and FDA do what is right, and continue to allow the safe use of Kratom by the people!

documents.commentText:
In reference to Docket No DEA -442W
My name is Becky Heft. I am a 48 year old mother of four. Kratom helped me break free from the grip of opiods back in 2009. In desperation unable and unwilling to subject myself to inpatient detox I found out about Kratom through a google search and lots of subsequent personal research. Kratom did not cure my addiction issues but allowed me to stop taking the large quantity of opiates my body had come to rely on without trading that addiction from one substance to another as in suboxone treatment. It permitted me to continue to work, be an active Mother and productive member if society, while having a clear head for the first time in years. I utilized Kratom as a tool and ceased its' use within a short period of time. My story doesn't end there. Addiction as we know is a disease. And as previous stated Kratom is not a cure but an effective tool to mitigate the horrible physical dependency of opiates. Several years went by while i tried to address the underlying issues that added to my genetic predisposition to addiction. I sought the help of multiple psychiatrists. Was diagnosed with untreated and unresolved trauma from being sexually abused as a child. Accepted that i also had Major Depressive Disorder with Anxiety and followed doctors orders. I tried dozens (literally) of different antidepressants and anti anxiety medications as well as different combinations of said medications. Utilized talk therapy in addition to drug therapy. I never once during that time had a symptom free day. I had plenty of drug induced thoughts and my depression deepened. As i struggled with depression and anxiety, my addictive personality led me to begin self medicating for relief of my symptoms. I drove into alcoholism and a new habit for the benzodiazepines from my doctor. Here i sat struggling, miserable, sad and unproductive, lost and without hope. I had to do something this was no way to live. I was unable to care for myself let alone my children or perform the duties my job in property management. In 2012 i hit rock bottom again and Ceased all medications prescribed to me. Stopped drinking and began working a 12 step program. I patiently awaited for my brain chemistry to return to its' normal state after spending years putting all my hopes into the pharmaceuticals my doctor prescribed.  I thought i was going to have to learn to live with my deep depression and ever growing anxiety. I stopped working, lost friendships, and became a shut-in to reduce the severe anxiety. I spent four years as a prisoner to my symptoms. Then in one of the numerous searches for a natural alternative to the mind numbing and addictive pharmaceuticals i had been prescribed, i remembered my experience with Kratom. During my previous use and cessation of Kratom earlier in my life i knew it was mood lifting and also not habit forming. I started researching its' effectiveness in helping with depression snd anxiety. While i had struggled to stop using alcohol, benzodiazepines, antidepressants as well as opiates during my life, i hadn't struggled to stop taking Kratom. It never once made me fuzzy headed , dopey or drunk. It only provided relief. So in 2016 i began using Kratom again as a way to mitigate the symptoms of my depression and now severe anxiety. Within a short time i was able to live a productive and happy life. Rejoining society and filled with hope for the future. I am now Relatively free of the symptoms of depression and anxiety. There is plenty of good science out there that supports my points and experiences. Taking Kratom off the market and placing it on the list of scheduled drugs will be detrimental for me as well as others. I will not return to a life of dependency be it pharmaceuticals or alcohol. So my life without Kratom will result in a return of my depression and anxiety symptoms. A lonely isolated life filled without hope. Please do not change the legality and availability of Kratom. While i fear for myself i also fear for others whose lives have been improved by this non-addictive and benign plant. Thank you for taking the time to read my story. Sincerely Becky Heft

documents.commentText:
I'd like to urge the DEA to reconsider its proposed ban on kratom.  I believe there is very little evidence to support a ban on this substance. 

 

For centuries, kratom has used in Thailand and in the last few decades it has become known to people around the world, including to millions of users in the United States.  It is a mild substance with minimal side effects.  It's is known to be only very mildly addictive and have nearly inconsequential withdraw symptoms, especially compared to those who are suffering opioid withdraws.  I mention this because kratom is used by some who are suffering opioid withdraws.  In the United States, we have a serious problem with opioid addiction and it seems to me that if there is anything that can help, such as kratom, it is worth keeping around, perhaps even promoting.  Besides, if kratom were truly a dangerous drug, there would have been reporting on it years ago.  We all know there is significant risks posed by "spice", or synthetic marijuana.  Spice has been reported on frequently by news outlets because there are serious, deadly risks.  Coverage of kratom in the media is almost unheard of because there isn't anything negative coming from its use.  

 

Public support for the War On Drugs (WOD) is at an all-time low.  States all around the country are passing laws legalizing marijuana.  In many ways, this is because the WOD very unpopular and perceived to be unjust.  Adding another fairly innocuous substance to the WOD does not make any sense.  The last thing we need right now is to be filling our prisons with kratom users who are not causing anyone any harm.  Please do not ban kratom.

documents.commentText:
My name is Hazel I'm 28, Female - Mental illness runs in my family: Bipolar, schizophrenia, depression, agoraphobia, social anxiety, and general anxiety. ADD, Migraines, and general tension headaches have also been diagnosed in my family. You could say I'm genetically hardwired/predisposed to Mental disorders and related issues.  

Unfortunately I was diagnosed with Major Depressive Disorder, Social Anxiety Disorder, and Generalized Anxiety Disorder - With the possibility of Bipolar Disorder and Attention Deficit Disorder at the age of sixteen. However, issues had been noted as young as eight when I was placed in 'play' groups to help overcome my anxiety. 

The disorders quickly became increasingly disabling and I was later diagnosed with Post Traumatic Stress Disorder after experiencing traumatic events over a four year period in my early twenties. I was suicidal, had trouble with sleep, drank too much alcohol, and self harmed (cutting and bruising). I had been unable to work or go to school since I was eighteen. I was nearly homeless on several occasions. 

Medically I've tried just about everything to overcome and cope with my disorders. I went through a long list of anti-depressants, mood stabilizers (e.g. Venlafaxine, Seroquel, Paroxetine, Fluoxetine, Lithium, Vaproate, etc.), and therapy (e.g. Cognitive Behavioral Therapy, Exposure Therapy, Relaxation Techniques, Group Therapy). Nothing was helping and I was becoming desperate. 

A year or so ago, in my desperation, I was looking online for other options. I found out about Kratom and after doing my research I purchased some from a reputable vendor online. Kratom has completely turned my life around. I take one gram of white veined Kratom in the morning by placing the powder on my tongue using a spoon and washing it down with juice. It has a very subtle effect that starts to kick in about fifteen minutes after. At night I take one to two grams of red veined Kratom which helps me sleep. I do this every day although I have gone a week or two without or a day or two here and there without issue. 

The effect of Kratom on me is subtle, kind of like drinking a strong cup of coffee. The white veined kratom gives me better focus, energy, but most importantly a sense of calm wellbeing/contentment without the zombie feeling antidepressants tend to give. Red veined gives me that same sense of calm but makes me sleepy instead of energetic. It does not give a high it's more like it stabilizes me. The couple of times I took slightly too much I felt like vomiting. I can't imagine anyone could overdose on Kratom because of that.

Since I started taking Kratom I've been able to work, enjoy my hobbies again, and attend social events. It makes me feel normal and I can finally live my life as a productive member of society. I believe that banning Kratom would take me back to the way I was before and that idea terrifies me because I don't think I could do that again. I think I would stop trying. 

I don't think the ban is warranted because the effect is milder than alcohol and the antidepressants I took before. It doesn't affect capability or productivity negatively (in fact it has the opposite effect). The change has made a huge difference in my life and has benefitted me enormously, in a medical sense. I'm no longer anxious all the time, not constantly depressed, it helps with muscle pain from stress, I get less migraines, I feel calm but productive, I sleep better. I wouldn't say it's a cure but it is the best medication I've tried and the only one that really made a difference without a disabling effect. 

I am 100% against the ban. I find the claims that Kratom on its own is deadly hard to believe. I think the evidence for it is lacking. Kratom should be studied more because I believe it could help millions in a safer way than a lot of other medications currently do. If it were to be banned it would be too hard for those studies to be done. I also believe that banning it would cause the deaths of more people than it claims to safe and cause the suffering of thousands of people, without good reason. The current reasons given are inadequate and not properly supported by evidence. 

I do support some regulation to ensure quality and that the Kratom is unadulterated; some oversight would be preferable, provided there won't be a huge increase in cost. Kratom should remain affordable and accessible. It's a natural plant and the pharmaceutical companies should not be allowed to patent it to make a profit and decrease accessibility. I don't see a need for going  through a doctor to obtain Kratom because it's just too mild to be necessary. It would be like going to the doctor to get a Red Bull, unnecessary. Better labeling would be nice however. 

I would like to say to those who support the ban to try a gram of Kratom for themselves before judging. You'll see how harmless and mild this medication truly is. Thank you for reading.

documents.commentText:
I have used Kratom for over five years now, sometimes each day and other times sparingly maybe once per week.  The effects of Kratom, unlike drugs of abuse in the often-compared opiate class, are mild, and the euphoria of the drug, if experienced at all, is very limited even in first time users.  Additionally consuming excessive amounts leads to nausea and worse feelings; that is, it is a self-limiting substance much like caffeine.  Just like it does not make one feel a cocaine rush to consume 20 cups of coffee in rapid succession, consuming tens of grams of Kratom will not result in an heroin-like high but, on the contrary, nausea and discomfort (not death mind you -- please refer to the scientific literature for overdose characteristics).  As such Kratom needs no additional law enforcement to limit its use in adults because it limits its own consumption, much like coffee.

In addition to the simple fact people enjoy taking Kratom for the clarity of thought and the peaceful feelings it imparts without physical impairment, it can unfortunately be addictive.  I attest to this reality, but the level of addiction and subsequent withdrawals if one stops taking it, are relatively minor for the vast majority of users as compared to hard drugs. There are other ways Kratom can actually even help society.

Opiates, for example, do endanger the lives of people who become addicted to them, and that is sad.  However, even here Kratom has a use: it provides a way for people so entrapped by the cycle of opiate abuse to get off those drugs or greatly reduce their use and, thus, reduce the harm even death they can pose to the abuser.  Kratom does this by helping curb the strong and horrifically painful withdrawals that opiate abusers feel when they are getting off their dope without having to shame or suffering the stigma of getting outside help.  It empowers people to fix themselves while not spending tax dollars or wasting the limited time of our policemen and women doing other jobs, the judicial system's available time, and jail's limited space.

Additionally Kratom can help people, such as the elderly and our vets who bravely served our country so we may enjoy its freedoms, who deal with pain daily by providing a way out of opiate use, thereby reducing the strain our healthcare system must endure for more risky treatments such as opiate prescription, treatments that render the user less mentally acute to enjoy life and work.  

So my experience has shown me the simple truth that Kratom has a medicinal use and overall strongly benefits society, not harms it.

documents.commentText:
Good day, 
I am writing today in regards to your intent to place Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine aka Kratom, into Schedule I. I do understand the need to control substances as there are segments of our populous who will abuse. I am not one of them nor do I support their desire to get high. People will abuse if its in their nature and we cannot stop them if their intent is to harm themselves, call it natural consequences if they do cause harm to themselves. 

I am a 55 year old grandmother of five (soon to be six). I have a desk job for my countys Coordinated Care Organization for the Oregon Medicaid Program known as the Oregon Health Plan. My position is Out of Area Provider Specialist. I do not do work that demands from my body, I have had too many injuries over life that wouldnt allow it anyway. I spent 15 years in a domestic violence marriage, 12 years in the nursing field and recently had a not-at-fault collision where my GMC Suburban was totaled. You know how hard it is to total a Suburban? This accident resulted in two surgeries for my injuries. 

I like so many others have discovered Kratom to be a legitimate source of pain relief. I recently ended my contract with a local pain manager, a Physicians Assistant at a clinic in Coos Bay, OR. After a period of almost a year, I didnt want to continue with the Opiate therapy I was on. I was prescribed Norco 5/325 (hydrocodone bitartrate and acetaminophen), 1 tablet every six hours for pain. Thats 120 tablets in a 30 day period. Thats a lot of Norco that also describes my pain level. Thats a lot of pain. 

Among my diagnoses, the ones that give me daily pains are:
Spondylosis with myelopathy or radiculopathy, cervical region. I have had the surgical option to repair this and it will not progress further (the damage) but there is damage that remains and will not regenerate to a point of no pain. 
Thoracic back pain. Due to 12 years in the nursing field. 
Complete tendon tears of the left rotator cuff (its been repaired twice, failed.)
Additionally in all I have had 16 separate surgeries over my lifetime, nothing chronic, just life. 

Please, I am begging you to keep Kratom available to the community of our country. Do what you must to monitor, but this is truly a safe alternative to the narcotics prescribed to us by our medical experts. I love my doctors for treating me to the best of their abilities and thank my country for all the exceptional levels of care available to me, but I need Kratom. With Kratom I am in NO danger of an accidental overdose. I am in no additional danger of other health problems arising out of using narcotics. I am terrified of using narcotics because of the danger they hold, to my physical health, my mental and emotional health. 

I work in the medical industry and I know the opiate abuses that are plaguing our communities. Kratom is not the enemy here. Opiates are. This is not an opiate. 
Thank you for your time to read my story.

Sincerest regards
Valerie Palmer

documents.commentText:
My name is Eric Ashton, I'm a 27 year old restaurant manager and from Kansas City. I'd like to voice my opposition to the DEAs Intent to Schedule the alkaloids Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine, which would make Kratom (Mitragyna speciosa), a schedule 1 controlled substance with "no medicinal value". This would put kratom on the same level as illegal drugs like heroin, despite the fact that it is a plant that's helping millions of people suffering chronic and acute mental and physical conditions that is also safely easing the nation's opiate epidemic problem naturally. It would also prevent further research which, to date, has been very promising and positive.
Mitragyna Speciosa is truly a life-saving plant. Humans have been benefiting from it for millennia, and Americans have for decades. I personally suffer from depression, anxiety, and back pain. I've had these conditions all of my adult life, and have tried prescription medications (antidepressants and painkillers) but they were terribly addictive or altered my mind in a really negative way.  I discovered m. speciosa 5 years ago at a botanical shop and have taken it since without adverse effects. This plant has allowed me to live a normal life and be a functioning member of society. Kratom, for me, has eased my pain and minimized my depression and anxiety, and has changed my life and the lives of countless other people across the world. I'm asking you to please stop the ban, or at the very least help us to reach some kind of compromise (age limit, regulated as an herbal supplement, or a situation similar to kava kava, for example). Free Americans have the right to decide what is best for their personal health. It is important to know that this is NOT some kind of synthetic chemical or a plant sprayed with chemicals, it is purely a plant from Southeast Asia, full of beneficial natural compounds. Kratom is a natural remedy  that has greatly impacted my life in a positive way, and taking it away would be devastating to the masses of people like myself. Please refer to www.AmericanKratom.org/science for more information about this plant, specifically a list of studies on the alkaloids in m. speciosa. 
Thank you for your consideration, I hope the correct decisions will be made in this matter to preserve the health and freedom of Americans like me.

documents.commentText: I have not taken this product but through research I have come to the conclusion that this could help people more than we are seeing. I think it should be researched fully and used to its highest potential to help people with opiate addictions.

documents.commentText:
It is ridiculous that these substances, mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine  and the plants or plant products in which they naturally occur, kratom, are being considered for placement into schedule 1. 

The effects are generally mild, and results from overdosing are not life threatening. While mitraginine and 
7-hydroxymitragynine can be habit forming, building up a physical dependence on the substances is very difficult. In addition, for those who have managed to become dependent, withdrawal is in no way as disruptive to one's well-being and ability to function normally as the class of drugs they are normally compared to, opioids, and can be managed via tapering off of the substances without much difficulty. 

In terms of positive effects that this substance can bring, it has been widely praised as a natural solution for chronic pain management, which is a boon considering the prescription opioid crisis in the United States. Any potentially less harmful and disruptive alternatives to prescription opioid pain relievers is a big plus. In addition, many people who have developed a physical dependence to opioids, either prescription and street varieties, have been able to successfully use mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine  to cease use of opioids without the need for going through the horrible symptoms normally associated with opioid withdrawal.

Lastly, and with the positives previously outlined in mind, keeping mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine legal allows for taxation of kratom and its derivatives, and regulation of the industry as a whole. While I'm not certain that scheduling these substances will create the same kind of black market that other scheduled substances have (owing to the generally mild effects of mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine), scheduling them seems to be akin to throwing the baby out with the bathwater.

Please reconsider placing mitragynine and 7-hydroxymitragynine, and the plants in which they naturally occur, in schedule 1. The magnitude of their effects are not consistent with the other substances in schedule 1. They have highly positive effects for the vast majority of people using them. And finally, the negatives associated with other schedule 1 substances, such as highly disruptive withdrawal symptoms, possible long term harm or death resulting from overdose, or habituation leading to difficulties maintaining a normal work or home life, are simply not there for these substances. Placing them into schedule 1 is vastly unfair and shortsighted, considering their benefits.
documents.docketTitle: Schedules of Controlled Substances:  Temporary Placement of Mitragynine and 7-Hydroxymitragynine into Schedule I
documents.title: Comment on FR Doc # 2016-24659

documents.commentText: I am absolutely bewildered as to how the DEA could believe they are performing their duty by putting yet another completely safe substance at the Schedule I level. It is absolutely reckless to compare something completely unharmful and unaddictive to drugs such as heroin and methamphetamine. It is unjust to people who enjoy the wonderful benefits of kratom to be put in the same class as junkies. I have never even tried the substance, but I have read about and heard nothing but wonderful testimonies in its favor. If kratom is scheduled as the DEA hopes to, it will just be another failure in their never-ending chain of disregard for public health and education.

documents.commentText: As a single mother of two Kratom has saved me from anxiety and depression. I no longer rely on xanax to feel relief. No longer need dozens of pain killers from the body aches, please keep Kratom available for our kids!

documents.commentText:
If kratom is added to any one of the five drug schedules, people who use it will be criminalized and locked up behind bars.
Kratom has been used safely by millions of people in the U.S. and evidence supports kratom's potential as a pain reliever and opioid replacement.
Banning kratom expands the war on drugs, while the public overwhelmingly supports ending it. Kratom should be legally regulated, allowing for quality control measures and product labeling requirements.
Prohibiting kratom will worsen the country's problems of opioid addiction and overdose.
